They have pictures of him with and without a beard, and they think he might have removed his beard before leaving the hospital. They also believe he may have some trouble learning and understanding things. The police want to find him quickly because he needs to be watched carefully.

A Los Angeles judge has ordered V. Stiviano to repay over $2.6 million in gifts received from Donald Sterling, after his wife sued her for targeting wealthy older men. The court ruled in favor of the Sterling family, setting a precedent that the injured spouse can recover damages from the recipient of ill-gotten gifts. This comes after Donald Sterling's racist remarks led to him losing ownership of the NBA team Los Angeles Clippers.

Thierry Henry has criticized Arsenal's recent transfer dealings and urged the club to sign four top players in the summer. He believes that Arsenal need a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder, and striker to have any chance of winning the Premier League title. Henry also questioned whether Arsenal can win the title with Olivier Giroud as their first-choice striker. He suggested that the team needs to sign players of similar caliber to Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas, and Diego Costa to compete for the title.

A young woman who was abused by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn for years has shared the severe impact it had on her life. Van Ryn pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim is scared for her future relationships and didn't understand why she was targeted. She didn't know the abuse was wrong until she heard he had been caught and attempted to take her own life since then. The hearing continues.

The passage discusses the recovery of Arsenal teenager Serge Gnabry, who has been out for over a year due to a serious knee injury. The 19-year-old midfielder impressed last season but was sidelined after the Champions League match against Bayern Munich in March 2014. Gnabry recently played 90 minutes for Arsenal Under 21s against Reading and is now over his injury concerns, feeling better and looking forward to future games.

A 23-year-old accountant, Jacob Phillips, fell to his death after running from a taxi to avoid paying the fare. He had been out with friends in Penarth, South Wales and didn't have enough cash to pay for the cab. After jumping out of the taxi and over a fence in the dark, he plunged down a 70ft cliff. The taxi driver chased him but was unaware of the danger Phillips faced. His body was found by a dog walker the next day on a rocky beach at the base of the cliff. The coroner recorded a verdict of accidental death, stating that Phillips likely became disoriented and couldn't have known the danger ahead.

Last summer, thousands of holidaymakers faced passport delays and many had to pay extra to get their travel documents rushed through. Despite the passport agency making a Â£42 million profit during the chaos, only 2,191 compensation applications were approved, with an average payout of Â£92.68. Ministers rejected a demand for blanket refunds, and managers at the passport agency received bonuses up to Â£3,500.

A 1930s timewarp home in Horfield, Bristol, with original features such as stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, and retro food jars, is up for sale. The semi-detached property has a guide price of Â£200,000-Â£250,000 and includes the original bathroom, kitchen, and vintage cupboards. Despite some upgraded features like double glazing, potential renovation costs may deter developers. The house will be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick started as a backup to Alex Smith but became the 49ers' starter in 2012 after Smith's concussion. He led the team to their first Super Bowl since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice is an author who was born in New Orleans and lived there as a child before moving to Texas and then San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey that connects the New Jersey Turnpike to New York State Route 495 inside the Lincoln Tunnel, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language television network owned by Comcast through NBCUniversal division NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in East London and Essex, attended Stanway School where he met Graham Coxon and formed Blur. Their debut album Leisure was released in 1991 with mixed reviews. The band's self-titled album in 2001 was a worldwide success. Albarn's solo studio album Everyday Robots, co-produced by Richard Russell, was released in 2014 featuring collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir.

Mogadishu, also known as Hamar, is the capital and largest city of Somalia. The city is home to many important national institutions due to its status as Somalia's capital.
The song "Happiness in Slavery" is by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails and is featured on their debut EP, Broken, released in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker is an American screenwriter born on August 14, 1964, who has been nominated for a BAFTA award.

The passage describes two different works: a 2007 film called "Shooter" and a TV series with the same name. Both feature a character named Bob Lee Swagger, who is an expert marksman. In the film, Swagger is framed for murder by a rogue private military company unit, while in the TV series, he is living in exile and returns to action when he learns of a plot to kill the president.
House, also known as House, M.D., is an American television medical drama that aired on the Fox network for eight seasons from November 16, 2004 to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was found guilty of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder in 1971 for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate. He instructed members of his group to carry out the murders. Manson also received first-degree murder convictions for the deaths of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. After being charged, recordings of his songs were released commercially.

Sean Penn is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist born on August 17, 1960. He began his acting career in television and made his film debut in 1981's drama Taps. Penn gained critical attention for his roles in crime dramas like At Close Range, State of Grace, and Carlito's Way. He became a prominent leading actor with the drama Dead Man Walking, earning his first Academy Award nomination and winning the Best Actor Award at the Berlin Film Festival. Penn received two more Oscar nominations for Sweet and Lowdown and I Am Sam before winning his first Academy Award for Best Actor in 2003 for Mystic River and a second one in 2008 for Milk.

Sir Donald Bradman, also known as "The Don", was an Australian cricketer and is widely considered the greatest batsman of all time. After retiring, he continued to hold a prominent position in the game through his work as an administrator, selector, and writer for three decades.
L.A. Reid is a prominent figure in the music industry, having held leadership positions at various major record labels including Epic Records, Arista Records, and Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is a drummer known for his work with Rage Against the Machine (1991-2000, 2007-2011) and Audioslave (2001-2007). He began his career with Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha in 1991. As of 2016, he plays in Prophets of Rage alongside Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord.

The Millers is a multi-camera series that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013 to July 18, 2015. It had 34 episodes over two seasons. CBS canceled the show on November 14, 2014, after four episodes into the second season.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards, an American politician and Democrat, was the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995. She gained national attention as the state treasurer of Texas and delivered the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. Richards was the second female governor of Texas and known for her outspoken feminism and witty one-liners. She was defeated for re-election in 1994 by George W. Bush.
Summary: Drake Bell released an independent EP called A Reminder in 2011.

The passage provides information about the 1979 American drama film, Boardwalk, which was written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman and directed by Verona. Additionally, it offers details about Janet Leigh, an American actress, singer, dancer, and author who wrote four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.

SimoÌn JoseÌ Antonio de la SantiÌsima Trinidad BoliÌvar y Palacios, also known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader who played a leading role in establishing Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama as independent sovereign states, free from Spanish rule.

The Bermuda Triangle, also known as the Devil's Triangle, is a region in the western part of the North Atlantic Ocean where numerous aircraft and ships have reportedly disappeared under mysterious circumstances.

Colin Kaepernick started as a backup to Alex Smith but became the 49ers' starter in 2012 after Smith's concussion. He led the team to their first Super Bowl since 1994, which they lost to the Baltimore Ravens. In the 2013 season, Kaepernick helped the 49ers reach the NFC Championship but lost to the Seattle Seahawks.
The passage provides a brief description of the film "Marnie," stating that it is a 1964 American psychological thriller directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

The passage defines advertising as a nonpersonal, openly sponsored form of marketing communication that promotes products, services, or ideas through various mass media channels. It is different from personal selling and can be found in both old and new media formats.
Private Lives is a comedy of manners written by NoÃ«l Coward in 1930. It was later adapted into a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.
Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton, was a British Conservative politician and statesman who served as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from January 10, 1957 to October 19, 1963.

Aristotle was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist born in Stagira, Chalkidice in 384 BC. He joined Plato's Academy in Athens at 17 or 18 years old and stayed until he was 37. After Plato's death, Aristotle tutored Alexander the Great at the request of Philip II of Macedon starting in 343 BC.

David Mordechai Packouz, born on February 16, 1982, is an American who has been an arms dealer, musician, inventor, and entrepreneur. He invented the BeatBuddy, a guitar pedal drum machine, and is now the CEO of Singular Sound, a music technology company.

Magic Johnson, a former point guard for the Lakers, won multiple championships in high school and college before being drafted first overall by the Lakers in 1979. He achieved great success during his 13-season career, winning five championships and an NBA Finals MVP award in his rookie season. After retiring and returning to play several times, he finally retired in 1996. Johnson is also recognized as one of America's most influential black businessmen and has various business interests, including part-ownership of the Lakers.

Tenacious D is a comedy rock duo from Los Angeles formed in 1994, consisting of Jack Black and Kyle Gass. They have released three albums and gained popularity in 1997 through their TV series and support for large rock acts.

James VI and I was King of Scotland and England, ruling both kingdoms in personal union. He advocated for a single parliament for the two nations but faced challenges in England, including the Gunpowder Plot and conflicts with the English Parliament.

Big Brother 2017, also known as Big Brother 18, is the upcoming eighteenth series of the British reality television series Big Brother. It is hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley, a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist. Bentley has been narrating the UK version of Big Brother since its inception in 2000 and is known for his Geordie accent, which has made him one of Britain's most recognizable voices.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked federal state in Germany, bordering Brandenburg, Saxony Anhalt, Thuringia, Bavaria, Poland, and the Czech Republic. It is the tenth largest state in Germany with an area of 18,413 km2 and the sixth most populous with 4 million people. Saxony has a history spanning over a millennium and is known for its quality wine production. It is one of the northernmost wine regions in Europe and the only two located in former East Germany.
East End Park is a baseball park in Cincinnati, and "In the End" is a song by Linkin Park.
Mel B Brown started her solo career by releasing "I Want You Back" with Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and sister of Miley and Trace Cyrus.

Mohra is a 1994 Indian action thriller film directed by Rajiv Rai, starring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah. It became the second highest grossing Indian film of 1994 and received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. Divya Bharti was initially cast as the female lead but was replaced by Raveena Tandon after her death. The film is also known for its popular songs from that year.
The song "Hourglass" is by the British electronic duo Disclosure and is featured on singer-songwriter James Taylor's fourteenth studio album.

Shane Black is an American screenwriter, director, producer and actor born on December 16, 1961. He is known for writing the 1987 action film Lethal Weapon and directing the film Kiss Kiss Bang Bang in 2005.
A View to a Kill is the 14th film in the James Bond series and the last one featuring Roger Moore as James Bond.
Papua is the biggest and easternmost part of Indonesia, including most of western New Guinea. It used to be called Irian Jaya, West Irian, or Irian Barat, and it was all of Indonesian New Guinea.
Augustus likely died of natural causes, but there were rumors his wife Livia may have poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez is a singer and actress who started her music career in 1999 with her debut album "On the 6." James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum, an American sculptor, photographer, author and engineer, is best known for overseeing the completion of the Mount Rushmore National Memorial after his father Gutzon Borglum's death in 1941. The film "Underdog" is directed by Frederik Du Chau and written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams. It stars Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton with voice talents from Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

The Freeport Doctrine was presented by Stephen A. Douglas during the second Lincoln-Douglas debate in Freeport, Illinois on August 27, 1858. These debates, also known as The Great Debates of 1858, occurred between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate from Illinois, and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas, the Democratic Party candidate. Easy A is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck, written by Bert V. Royal, and starring Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice, born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien on October 4, 1941, is an American author known for her gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. Rice was married to poet and painter Stan Rice from 1961 until his death from brain cancer in 2002.

The passage provides information about Camden, a city in Camden County, New Jersey. Bret Easton Ellis is a writer who wrote the screenplay for a movie called The Canyons. The Canyons is a 2013 film that didn't get good reviews and it's about some kind of thriller-drama thing.

Audioslave is a four-piece band featuring Soundgarden's lead singer/rhythm guitarist Chris Cornell and Rage Against the Machine members Tom Morello (lead guitar), Tim Commerford (bass/backing vocals), and Brad Wilk (drums). Aaron Burr was a prominent political figure in the late 18th and early 19th centuries. He served two terms in the New York State Assembly, held the position of New York State Attorney General, and represented the state as a U.S. senator. His career culminated in serving as vice president.

The Soyuz rocket was commissioned for the Soviet human spaceflight program, with 8 unmanned test flights followed by 19 manned launches. Rage Against the Machine broke up in 2000 due to tensions and de la Rocha's departure. The remaining members formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell, releasing three albums before disbanding in 2007. The S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as the BSE 30 or SENSEX, is a free-float market-weighted stock market index consisting of 30 financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. Tata Motors, listed on the BSE and a constituent of the BSE SENSEX index, is also listed on the National Stock Exchange of India and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia, with an estimated 92.7 million inhabitants. It is bordered by China, Laos, Cambodia, Thailand, and the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia across the South China Sea. Vietnam's economic growth rate has been among the highest in the world since 2000, and it had the highest Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies in 2011. The country remains one of the world's four remaining one-party socialist states officially espousing communism.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film written and directed by John Gatins.

James VI and I was King of Scotland as James VI from 1567 and King of England and Ireland as James I from 1603 until his death in 1625. He advocated for a single parliament for both countries. During his reign in England, he faced numerous challenges with Parliament.

Margaret Thatcher was a Prime Minister who created policies called Thatcherism. She is considered one of the most important and talked-about politicians in British history, but people still argue about Thatcherism today.

Valencia is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia in Spain, with around 800,000 inhabitants. It is the third largest city and metropolitan area in Spain after Madrid and Barcelona. The population of the Valencian Community ranges from 1.7 to 2.5 million.

Speech recognition is a field that uses technology to turn spoken language into text. It involves knowledge from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Applications include voice user interfaces, search, data entry, document preparation, and more. The field has seen growth through academic papers and industry adoption of deep learning methods by companies like Google, Microsoft, and Apple.

Richard Alf, born on January 26, 1952 and died on January 4, 2012, was an American businessman and former comic book store owner. He co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International in 1970 and served as its chairman. The convention was initially called the Golden State Comic Book Convention and was founded by a group of San Diegans including Shel Dorf, Richard Alf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry. It later became known as the "San Diego Comic Book Convention."
The passage describes a remake called "Fist of Legend", which is based on the 1972 film "Fist of Fury" starring Bruce Lee as the main character.

In the given passage, French golfer Dubuisson and South African Van Zyl are tied for the lead at 16 under par. McIlroy, a four-time major winner from Northern Ireland, is one stroke behind at 15 under par along with Thailand's Kiradech Aphibarnrat. McIlroy is aiming for his first title since May and believes there is a low round in store for him. Despite some setbacks during the game, he managed to hit an eagle on the 12th hole. McIlroy had previously suffered a ligament rupture in his left ankle in July, causing him to miss several tournaments. He is now targeting a third Race to Dubai title in four years and currently leads England's Danny Willett by 271, 214 points with three events remaining after the Turkish Open.

The passage discusses the political situation in Bahrain, focusing on the need for national dialogue and concrete solutions from the government. Sheikh Ali Salman, a key opposition figure, believes that engaging with reformists within the royal family, such as Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa, is crucial for meaningful dialogue. Hardliners, however, are opposed to this process. The al-Wefaq leader acknowledges the lack of trust between opposition leaders and the government but insists that dialogue and negotiations are necessary. He also calls for the release of 13 opposition leaders and human rights activists who have been imprisoned.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and one of the most influential exponents of the early-music movement, has passed away at his home in Cambridge after a long illness. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directed it for 30 years across six continents. The AAM produced over 200 CDs, including the first-ever complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Hogwood was also a tutor at Harvard University, honorary professor of music at the University of Cambridge, and a professor-at-large at Cornell University in the US. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service to be held at a later date.

In the year ending March 2016, Scotland recorded its lowest number of homicides (57) since 1976. The most common method of killing was using a sharp instrument, with knives accounting for 90% of these cases. While alcohol and drug influence among the accused remains largely unknown, 31% were identified as being under the influence. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson emphasized the need for continued efforts to reduce violent crime and support at-risk communities. Scottish Labour's justice spokeswoman Claire Baker cautioned against overconfidence in the statistics, noting that last year's figures were revised upward and pointing out a rise in sexual crime and violent crime rates.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland, making them the first team to lose to the Black Cats in the Premier League this season. Despite creating numerous chances and scoring only one goal, coach Howe remains confident in his team's abilities.

The Australian government's policy of detaining and processing migrants offshore to prevent deaths at sea has been described as "brutal" and "inhumane" by the New York Times. Despite criticism, Prime Minister Tony Abbott defended the policy, stating that it has successfully stopped boat arrivals in Australia. He also angered Australian Jewish groups by comparing the actions of the so-called Islamic State to the Nazis.

The US has suspended talks with Russia over Syria due to the intensifying attacks on civilians and the bombing of Aleppo. Washington blames Russia and the Syrian government for the escalation of violence, while Moscow accuses the US of shifting blame for the failed ceasefire. Hundreds of people have died in Aleppo since the end of the ceasefire, and 250,000 are trapped in the city. The US is also withdrawing personnel that had been sent to establish a joint implementation center with Russia. Despite this, both sides will continue discussions on counter-terrorism operations in Syria to prevent clashes.

The Policy Exchange think tank proposes selling high value vacant social homes to raise Â£4.5bn a year, which could fund the construction of 80,000 to 170,000 new social homes. The report suggests that this move would create the largest social house building program since the 1970s and help reduce the number of people on the waiting list for social housing by about 500,000. However, Labour argues that this policy would force hard-working families on low wages out of expensive areas and create segregated communities. The National Housing Federation warns that such a move could lead to the "cleansing" of lower income families from affluent areas.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, a 25-year-old from Swansea, passed away last week amidst an ongoing measles epidemic in the city. The exact cause of his death remains uncertain as further tests are required. Since November, 83 people have been hospitalized due to the outbreak. Mr. Colfer-Williams had recently been treated for asthma at Morriston Hospital before developing a rash and eventually being found dead in his flat. Public Health Wales confirmed he had measles but could not determine if it was the main cause of his death. His family is unsure how he contracted the disease, as no close family member has it, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter. An inquest will be opened and adjourned to allow for additional testing.

Vincent Hudson, 54, has been charged with a historical offence against a boy under 16 years old. The alleged attack was reported to have occurred in 2001 and Mr. Hudson is scheduled to appear in North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Guiseley and Gateshead played to a 1-1 draw in the National League. Guiseley took the lead with a goal from Jake Lawlor, but Gateshead equalized with a goal from Wes York. Both teams had opportunities to score more goals, but strong defending and goalkeeping kept the score level. The match ended with both teams still unbeaten in their respective runs.

Bristol Sport Ltd, the owner of a football club, plans to replace two stands to increase capacity instead of building a new stadium at Ashton Vale. The project was approved by Bristol City Council in November and will begin in May if no judicial review is filed by March.

Cuadrilla, a firm conducting shale gas drilling or "fracking" tests, has suspended operations as a precaution after a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months. The British Geological Survey (BGS) will examine data before the company decides whether to resume. A similar tremor occurred on 1 April. Fracking involves shattering hard shale rocks underground to release gas using hydraulic pressure or tiny explosions. The process has been controversial due to environmental concerns, but the Commons energy select committee supports it with proper regulation and good industry practice. The BGS is monitoring fracking as a precaution and has recorded two small earthquakes in Lancashire since fracking began there in March.

Angus Carpenter, a bagpiper who has played in Liverpool for over 30 years, was found guilty of one count of fraud. He was accused of collecting money for the Hillsborough Justice Campaign while performing with a banner featuring the charity's name and logo. Carpenter claimed he was simply busking and had permission to display the banner as a tribute to the victims. The jury cleared him of two other fraud charges. He will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3-0, with goals from Grant Ward, Luke Varney, and Tom Lawrence. QPR had few attacking opportunities and failed to score, while Ipswich could have scored more goals. The win moved Ipswich up four places to 14th, while QPR slipped to 15th. QPR manager Ian Holloway criticized his team's defending and mental toughness, while Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy praised his players' performances.

Summary:
The passage discusses the impressive performance of Wells, aged 23, in the T20 Blast last season where he scored 373 runs at a strike rate of 138.66. He expresses excitement about the club's direction and praises the elite performance environment created by the coaches.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured a second consecutive win by defeating third-placed Chinnor 29-12. Key players Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams played a crucial role in the victory. Churcher praised their performance and highlighted the importance of the front row and front five's contribution in making over 70 tackles during the match. The Reds have seven games against lower-ranked teams and league leaders Old Elthamians coming up. Although they won, Churcher believes there is still room for improvement and emphasizes the need to build on their recent success to avoid wasting the progress made last weekend.

A 28-year-old man named Nazrul, also known as Nazu, has been accused of raping a 74-year-old nun in Ranaghat town, India. He was arrested at a railway station in Kolkata and is the sixth person to be arrested in connection with the crime. Police have identified eight suspects, with two still untraced. The incident led to widespread protests across India. Money was stolen from the convent school during the attack, and the building was ransacked before the nun was raped in the convent itself.

The passage discusses an interactive video featuring Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London. He explains the reasons behind changes in consumer purchases, such as the introduction of domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports. The video also explores shifts in brand ownership and rankings among the top 20 consumer brands in the UK. A non-interactive version is available for users with older browsers.

The passage describes two incidents where individuals were scammed by callers claiming to be from BT technical support. In the first incident, a 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills was tricked on September 15th, and in the second incident, a woman in Stranraer lost money on September 22nd. Both incidents involved the scammers gaining remote access to the victims' computers and stealing substantial amounts of money. PC Siobhan Pellett warns people to be cautious when receiving cold calls asking for remote access to their computer and never to give out banking details or account numbers over the phone.

Duffy, a 37-year-old former professional rugby player, has signed a one-year contract with third-placed Championship team Featherstone after leaving Swinton Lions. He will lead the team in their final league game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers. The chairman of Featherstone praised Duffy as a fantastic coach and expressed excitement about his future with the team. Duffy had previously played for Leigh, Widnes, and Salford during his 16-year playing career and was replaced by Stuart Littler at Swinton.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, along with a medic and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter, were dispatched to Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve on Sunday at 12:50 GMT. The rider had sustained head injuries and was suffering from hypothermia after being unconscious on the wet sand. After receiving treatment, she was airlifted to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales for further care.

The UN conference in Geneva decided to dedicate part of the radio spectrum for a global flight tracking system, aiming to improve the current tracking system that relies on ground-based radars. MH370's disappearance in 2014 revealed weaknesses in worldwide air navigation systems, prompting Malaysia's communication minister to urge the ITU for real-time flight data transmission solutions. The new system will enable satellites to receive transmissions from aircraft, allowing "real-time tracking of aircraft anywhere in the world." The UN's aviation arm, ICAO, has set a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines, including aircraft sending their position every 15 minutes or more during emergencies.

A long-missing child, Julian Hernandez, has been found at the age of 18 living with his father in Cleveland. The FBI received a tip about his possible identity after he faced issues applying for college. The agency worked with local police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children to confirm his identity. His mother has been notified of his recovery. Julian's father, Bobby Hernandez, is charged with tampering with records to obtain a driver's license in 2012 and is being held at Cuyahoga County Jail with a $250,000 bail. Authorities had suspected him as the culprit since the time of the boy's disappearance.

A fire at Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited's site in Duncan Street on 2 March led to train service disruptions and travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended the company from accepting waste, as they were "broadly compliant" with fire safety law. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) had visited the premises nine times in the last year and found the site operators, Asset and Land Group, to be broadly compliant with fire safety legislation. The EA decided to revoke the environmental permit after concerns raised by GMFRS about the impact of a fire on nearby residents, transport, and the environment. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia proposed two bills related to Ukraine's Crimea region, where pro-Russian feelings are strong. One bill suggests new provisions that could be triggered by a referendum or a plea from territory leaders, allowing part of a neighboring state's territory to become a new "subject" of the Russian Federation. The other bill aims to speed up the process for issuing Russian passports to Ukrainians, removing requirements such as paying a state tax and having previous residence in Russia. The fast-track procedure for passport issuance was announced in Sevastopol, with several Russian MPs, including celebrities, supporting the move.

The passage discusses the history of McLaren in Formula 1, highlighting their past successes and current struggles. Despite having won 182 grands prix and 12 drivers' world championships, McLaren is currently experiencing a slump due to issues with their Honda power-unit. The team's last constructors' title was in 1998-99, and they have not had a win since 2012. The passage also mentions scandals involving illegally possessing Ferrari technical information and misleading stewards. Ron Dennis, who has held various roles within the team, believes that McLaren will break Mercedes' hegemony in F1 and return to winning ways.

Thomas Baker, a 44-year-old man from Everton, was found badly injured at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on January 27th after being shot in the head and chest. He later died in the hospital. Three men from Liverpool, aged 29 and 32, have been arrested and remain in police custody for questioning. Detectives believe the suspects had been waiting outside Phoenix Gym for about an hour before the shooting occurred. A silver VW polo, which "left the scene at speed," is still being sought by officers. Merseyside Police are urging anyone with information, especially those who were captured on CCTV near the meat market, to come forward as they may have key information for the investigation.

The passage discusses various ways to enjoy Christmas online, including virtual church services, a Bible-themed fantasy game for children, and nativity videos. It highlights the success of a German marketing company's digital story of the nativity and the use of Manga as a medium to share biblical stories. Additionally, it mentions how social media platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram are being utilized by various groups to connect with their communities during the holiday season.

The eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is discussing a proposal to take over 250 hectares of common land, with backers offering 320 hectares of replacement land. Experts have given conflicting opinions on the potential damage to habitats and plant life. Natural Resources Wales finds it difficult to conclude if the replacement land is of equal value but does not oppose the development overall. An ecology report from developers claims a "net gain" in biodiversity due to enhancement work on nearby habitats, which the Gwent wildlife trust disagrees with. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation after the inquiry, with Welsh government ministers having the final say on whether the plans can proceed.

Chechen Muslim clerics have called for retribution against journalists after a report by Novaya Gazeta revealed the detention and torture of over 100 people on suspicion of being homosexual. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report, but Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations. The paper's editor urged dialogue and said journalists would continue investigating human rights abuses in Chechnya. The LGBT Network is helping people flee persecution and may file a case at the International Criminal Court if Russia fails to prosecute anyone.

Investing Solutions, a letting agency, has been receiving housing benefit payments for the past two years by housing single homeless men in properties sourced by Fresh Start Housing, a charity. The company and charity are not acting illegally, but a homeless group claims their relationship is unethical. Investing Solutions makes a profit by housing several unrelated people in one house and charging housing benefit for each person, resulting in higher payouts than rent fees passed to landlords. Both organizations are based in the same storage unit in south London. Investing Solutions is one of the largest recipients of housing benefit in the UK and focuses on providing housing to single homeless men over 35. However, they have been criticized for poor living conditions in their properties. Wandsworth Council has paid Investing Solutions over Â£2.1m in the past two years, while other councils have dedicated teams to ensure private sector housing is safe and affordable.

In a closely contested game, the Netherlands defeated Great Britain 79-75. Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and NBA player Ben Gordon added 13 for GB. Coach Joe Prunty's team led for most of the first three quarters but lost momentum in the last 10 minutes. GB begins their Eurobasket qualifying campaign with a midweek game in Hungary. Prunty emphasized the importance of giving their best on every play and maintaining intensity on both ends of the floor. Despite a late comeback attempt, the hosts couldn't overcome the Dutch lead, who were led by 18 points from Worthy De Jong. Prunty praised Gordon's performance, stating that he had a good showing and contributed well to the team.

A former five-weight world champion submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) for a bout at 154 lbs, which requires 10oz gloves. The NAC will debate the matter on 16 August and decide whether to allow lighter gloves. Lighter gloves offer less cushioning but can lead to more punishing punches. The fighters' health and safety is the top priority. McGregor, who has used 4oz gloves in his UFC career, welcomed Mayweather's Instagram post about using 8oz Grant gloves. The NAC will publicly debate the issue before announcing its decision.

The last two journalists have left Fleet Street, once the hub of British journalism with nearly every national paper and several provincial newspapers having offices within a half-mile radius. The first British daily newspaper was published here in 1702. At its peak, it was known as "the Street of Shame" and was synonymous with the nation's biggest newspapers. However, media tycoon Rupert Murdoch moved his papers to Wapping in east London in 1986, leading to a bitter dispute which ended in defeat for the unions and most national newspapers moving away from Fleet Street by 1988. The buildings they left behind gradually morphed into other uses.

The Harry Potter author, J.K. Rowling, faced criticism on Twitter for her political views and donations to the campaign for a No vote in the Scottish independence referendum. She revealed that she had been called "a traitor" and blocked some abusive users who she believed were supporters of the Scottish National Party (SNP). Rowling also mentioned that she had discussed common political ground with other SNP supporters.

A study by the University of Edinburgh found that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action for the same crime as better-off children. Poverty also increases the likelihood of violence among both boys and girls. The study tracked 4,300 young people in Edinburgh since 1998 and found that household poverty is an exacerbating factor for young people offending. Additionally, the recent fall in crime rates in Scotland has not benefited areas with the most chronic rates of crime, and crime tends to be highly concentrated amongst poor people and within poor neighborhoods.

Mr. Haugh, 25, was stabbed in a laneway in the Marian estate early Sunday morning. Robbie Walsh has been charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr. Haugh and is remanded in custody until next week's court appearance. Two other men were arrested and released without charge, with files being prepared for the Director of Public Prosecutions. It is alleged that Mr. Walsh and two other males entered the Marian Estate looking for Mr. Haugh, resulting in a fight where weapons were used, leading to Mr. Haugh's death. A knife handle and blade with blood were recovered at the scene. The judge remanded Mr. Walsh in custody due to tension in the area following the killing.

In May 2014, Fermanagh MLA Phil Flanagan tweeted about Tom Elliott's appearance on a BBC radio program, questioning his involvement in the UDR and suggesting he harassed and shot people. Mr. Elliott served in the UDR between 1982 and 1992 and is now the MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone. The High Court heard that he has a clear MoD record. Flanagan deleted the tweet within an hour of posting it. He later apologized for the untrue and baseless comment. Mr. Justice Stevens reserved judgement on compensation. The insurance firm covering MLAs at Stormont refused to cover Flanagan for this case, leading him to challenge their decision in a separate court action. Mr. Elliott expressed disappointment in the time it took to resolve the issue but was ultimately vindicated by Flanagan's admission of falsehood.

Hawick Knitwear, a company with a history dating back to 1874 and currently employing over 230 staff, has increased its production of sweaters in response to higher demand. The company, bought by managing director Benny Hartop in November last year, has seen growth in both its private label business and the newly launched Hawick Knitwear-branded range. Production has risen from approximately 7,500 sweaters per week last year to 9,500 sweaters each week to meet demand. The company sells its products in Europe and other markets including the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being hit by Brian Wright's car outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright, 55, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see Mrs. Blackburn, who was escorting a woman and her daughter across the road. He denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving but has expressed remorse for his actions. The trial is ongoing.

The passage discusses a Nato exercise named "Dynamic Mongoose," which focuses on anti-submarine warfare and is aimed at countering the growing threat from Russian submarines. The exercise involves 10 Nato warships, including the Royal Navy Frigate HMS Portland, searching for a German U-boat acting as an unseen enemy. The exercise highlights a gap in Britain's defences, particularly the lack of maritime patrol aircraft, which used to be provided by the Nimrod. This vulnerability could allow Russian submarines to track the UK's nuclear deterrent as it leaves Faslane naval base in Scotland. The passage also mentions Russia's increasing military strength, with a fleet of around 60 submarines, and their advancements in submarine development.

The United Nations has warned that the violence in South Sudan could lead to genocide and ethnic cleansing. Since July, 340,000 people have fled to Uganda due to the escalating violence, making it the largest refugee crisis in the world this year. Ethnic violence has been a major factor in the conflict, with Dinka, Nuer, and Equatorians being targeted. Uganda is coping well with the influx of refugees but is beginning to struggle as nearly a million refugees have arrived. The UN is urging the international community to pressure South Sudanese leaders to stop the violence against civilians.

McKenzie, a former footballer turned professional boxer with a record of eight wins and one draw, will fight Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight championship at York Hall on 12 November. He is the son of former British and European champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The coalition is investing Â£330m in new NHS facilities across England, including a new Bridgwater Community Hospital with 30 inpatient beds, a maternity unit, minor injury unit, X-ray facilities, and space for mobile scanners. The current hospital, built in 1813, is cramped and outdated. The project costs Â£33m, with the remaining balance covered by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The new hospital aims to provide a more modern and comfortable environment for patients and staff. Planning permission is required for the construction on land at Bowers Lane, with a target completion date of autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe. He was found with a gunshot wound to his chest and later died at the Northern General hospital. The victim was in or near his black Mercedes when the shooting occurred. Local residents said the man was part of a family who were having a celebration nearby when the attack happened. There have been several shootings in Sheffield recently, but this is the first one in the Upperthorpe area.

The passage discusses the activities of various virtual warriors, including the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International. These groups engage in hacking and cyber warfare to gather information, disrupt their opponents' activities, and spread their message. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops focus on disrupting separatist funding and monitoring rebel movements in eastern Ukraine. Cyber Berkut is anti-Western and aims to thwart Ukraine's military plans. Anonymous International publishes leaked documents from the Kremlin and focuses on Russia's domestic affairs but also covers Ukraine.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick shed tears during farewell speeches by veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former first minister Alex Salmond, who are among those standing down as MSPs ahead of the May 5th election. Salmond used his valedictory address to emphasize that Scotland is diverse but not divided, and welcomed the transfer of powers to Holyrood under the Scotland Bill. He also joked about competing with a major attraction down south and wished everyone in the upcoming election good luck. McNeil warned that Holyrood could learn from Westminster's committee system and stressed the importance of accountability and scrutiny.

Older People's Commissioner for Wales Sarah Rochira is gathering experiences of residential care from pensioners and their families to create recommendations for care providers and public bodies. This is part of her review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She will highlight good care but also show the impact of poor care on older people. The review will consider factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Care providers, social care staff, and public bodies will also be consulted. The chair of Care Forum Wales, Mario Kreft, supports the review but feels that the advisory panel lacks representation from those with direct experience in managing or owning a care home.

Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, experienced an increase in pre-tax profit by Â£800,000 to Â£3.5m for the year ending June 2016, despite a decrease in turnover by Â£1m to Â£100m. The company's international sales grew in Europe and new markets. Harbro manufactures and supplies feeds for various sectors and operates 19 shops under the Country Store brand in Scotland. The outlook for agriculture is uncertain, but the company remains confident in its ability to face challenges such as Brexit.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, and another man in his 80s was taken to the hospital. Police are searching for 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, in connection with the death and warn people not to approach him. The investigation is ongoing, and anyone with information is urged to contact the police or Crimestoppers. Additional patrols have been conducted in the area to provide reassurance to residents.

David Lipton, the second in command at the IMF, spoke about global economic risks at a speech in Washington. He mentioned that the latest reading of the global economy shows a weakening baseline and that we are at a delicate juncture. This comes after weaker-than-expected trade figures from China showed exports plunging by a quarter from a year ago. The IMF is likely to downgrade its current forecast of 3.4% for global growth when it releases its economic predictions in April. This dismal picture has ongoing ramifications for businesses and industries that bet on China's growth story.

The council discussed problems with a new ferry, including breakdowns, groundings, and suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency. Council leader Dave Stewart announced that the crossing at Cowes would be free until 2 July for feedback and to address issues. A review of the project by auditors has been ordered. Local businesses are affected by the problems, and compensation is being considered. Councillor Ian Ward acknowledged teething problems but said they have been rectified.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday, resulting in a 32-year-old man's death. A 33-year-old man was arrested for causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook for investigation until early evening.

Matching Models, an international temp agency based in London, has been criticized for its advertisement of a personal assistant position requiring a "classic look" and specific cup size. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) called the ad "appalling, unlawful, and demeaning to women," while women's equality campaigners likened it to outdated 1970s practices. The EHRC plans to ask Matching Models for clarification on their hiring practices. Employment lawyer James Lynas stated that the ad is clearly unlawful and could lead to sex discrimination claims. Under the 2010 Equality Act, employers cannot discriminate based on factors such as age, sexual orientation, or disability. Matching Models founder Nathalie Jansen defended the ad by stating that clients have specific requirements related to appearance.

A shooting occurred at a hostel attached to the Pragati Residential School in Bangalore city, involving an office assistant named Mahesh. It is unclear what prompted the shooting, but Mahesh allegedly shot two students, one in the head and another who suffered severe injuries. He was arrested after a manhunt. Gun crime at schools and colleges in India is rare.

The advocacy group Glaad analyzed shows between June 2016 and May 2017, finding 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters. The number of transgender characters increased from seven to 16, but over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off. There is a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television due to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. Glaad's study is based on scripted broadcast, cable, and streaming series already being shown or for which casting has been confirmed.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced his decision to not seek re-election ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be opposed. This comes after criticism of his involvement in a loan to Northampton Town FC when he was leader of the borough council. About Â£10.25m of the public money loaned is missing and subject to a police investigation into alleged financial irregularities. The football stand remains half built. A majority of his party's local executive council said they would vote to deselect him.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old former police officer, fired a rifle into a car killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards in Balch Springs, Texas in April. The incident occurred during a response to reports of underage drinking at a house party. Initially, police claimed the vehicle reversed "aggressively" towards the officer, but footage discredited this claim. Oliver was fired for policy violations and charged with four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon by a public official. He faces five to 99 years in prison if convicted of murder. This would be the first police officer convicted of murder in Dallas County since 1973.

The president-elect's wife, Melania Trump, and their son Barron will move to Washington after the school year ends. Some people criticized this decision on social media, but others defended it. There have been other First Ladies in history who did not live in the White House during their husbands' presidencies, such as Martha Washington and Anna Harrison. Families have coped with moving to the White House in different ways in the past, and Melania has said that Barron is her top priority. The role of the First Lady is mainly ceremonial, but some have also taken on public roles and supported causes like education and anti-drug campaigns.

The man died in Inverness on 27 October. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc) is scrutinizing the initial police response to the man's call. Police Scotland is cooperating with the investigation, and a report on the commissioner's findings will be submitted to the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS).

The passage describes a yellow wind warning issued for several counties in the west of the mountains, with gusts up to 75mph possible due to an unusual easterly direction. This may cause disruption to travel on roads and at sea. A tree has already fallen due to the winds, closing a main route into Menai Bridge on Anglesey. Clean-up work is expected to keep the road closed for most of Monday.

The Giants won their opening game against the Panthers with a short-handed goal by Derrick Walser. Jeff Dimmen equalized for the Panthers in the first period. In the second period, Mike Forney scored a powerplay breakaway goal making it 2-1, but Andy Bohmback equalized soon after. Mike Radja and James Desmarais then scored for the Giants, making it 4-2. David Ling of Nottingham got one back before the end of the match. The two teams will face each other again on Saturday night in their second match of the double-header. Currently, Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 points and Belfast with 25 points.

Paul Merson criticized Andros Townsend's late substitution in Tottenham's 0-0 draw with Burnley and questioned his presence in the England squad. After Townsend scored an equalizer for England against Italy, Merson admitted his mistake and praised Townsend's performance. However, Merson couldn't resist another jab at Townsend following the Burnley match.

Chelsea has made a formal offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, according to the club's president Naoki Ogane. If the move is completed, Muto will join Chelsea's Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season. The deal is not connected to Chelsea's Â£200 million sponsorship agreement with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber. Muto has scored 16 goals in 37 appearances for FC Tokyo and earned 11 caps for Japan, scoring once.

A large-scale study has found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers. The Finnish researchers compared the weight and height of over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds with records on antibiotic prescription and found that one in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese by two years old. Children who had taken antibiotics as young babies were particularly likely to be overweight, and repeated prescriptions before the age of two also raised the odds of being a fat toddler. The study suggests that antibiotics may contribute to the obesity epidemic by killing off gut bacteria that would normally feed on some of the food eaten, thus freeing up more food for the body and potentially increasing appetite.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard, in front of hundreds of tourists. The incident was caught on camera by a tourist and the embarrassed soldier quickly got up as his colleagues continued marching. The unnamed soldier is thought to have slipped due to metal protectors on the soles of his boots.

A&E networks are remaking the 1977 miniseries "Roots," which had over 100 million viewers, about an African-American slave and his descendants. The remake will be simulcast on A&E, Lifetime, and History in 2016, drawing more from Alex Haley's novel. LeVar Burton, who played Kunta Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce. The new version aims to be "original" and "contemporary," with added authenticity from consulting scholars in African and African-American history.

Police are investigating claims by a former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, that palace aides tried to force him into an orgy in the 1970s. Lawler said he was pinned to a chair and groped by a male member of staff on his first day working at Clarence House. His complaints were ignored for months before the police were finally notified. The incident left him in tears and he left the job the same day. After hearing about the probe into historical cases of child abuse last year, Lawler wrote to the Palace but was initially rebuffed. Months later, the complaint was finally passed to Scotland Yard. A retired royal aide has been interviewed but denied involvement as he was working for the Queen in Balmoral at the time. The Royal Household has stated they will work 'exhaustively and co-operatively' with any police probe.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy in a rap video set to the theme song of '90s sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video has garnered over 1.7 million views on YouTube. The couple shared a sonogram of their unborn child at the end of the clip. The video was made for family and friends who live far away to share the news.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind was auctioned for $137,000. The gray jacket and skirt ensemble, featuring a black zigzag applique, was part of a private collection of James Tumblin, who began collecting memorabilia from the film in the 1960s. The outfit has faded from its original slate blue-gray color to light gray due to age. Other top selling items from the auction included a straw hat worn by Leigh, a suit worn by Clark Gable as Rhett Butler, and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland as Melanie Wilkes.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the edge. The toddler's mother was holding him and another child when he slipped and fell between 10 to 12ft into the pit. The child was rescued by his parents before firefighters and paramedics arrived on the scene. He suffered from minor bumps and bruises and was listed in stable condition at the hospital. The cheetahs did not approach the boy or his parents while in the pit, according to zoo officials. Cleveland Metroparks Zoo has plans to press child endangerment charges against the family.

A speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham was angled directly at a house after not working for two years. The camera, previously enforcing the 30mph speed limit, was turned off along with around 300 other speed and traffic cameras in the West Midlands in March 2013 due to outdated technology. Mobile camera units, motorway fixed cameras, and traffic officers have been used for enforcement since then. Birmingham City Council is aware of the re-pointed camera and plans to remove it. There are no plans to include this camera in a new pilot using digital technology.

Usain Bolt will participate in the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3 as part of the Jamaican team. He expressed excitement about being part of the team and is looking forward to contributing to Jamaica's strong relay tradition. The full Jamaican team list for the competition will be announced soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves showed support for Barcelona's basketball team by attending El Clasico, where Barca won 85-80 against Real Madrid. Neymar also helped Brazil win against Chile, while his sister Rafaella joined them at the basketball game. Before the international break, Barcelona had won their El Clasico match in La Liga. They will return to La Liga on Sunday to face Celta Vigo as they continue to compete for a treble of trophies.

Italy is dealing with a rising number of migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe. From Friday to Monday, 8,480 migrants were rescued by the Italian coast guard, which received SOS calls from 20 boats in distress on Monday alone. Save the Children fears that 400 migrants may be missing after a ship carrying 550 people capsized in the Mediterranean Sea. However, the Italian coast guard has not yet confirmed this incident or found evidence at sea to support it. There has been an increase in migrant boats crossing the Mediterranean into Italy, with over 10,000 migrants arriving in the first three months of 2015. At least 480 migrants have died while crossing the Mediterranean since the beginning of the year due to bad weather and overcrowded vessels used by smugglers.

Arsene Wenger is glad that Alexis Sanchez chose to join Arsenal over Liverpool, but admits he doesn't know the exact reason for his decision. Sanchez had a choice of clubs after leaving Barcelona and ultimately decided to continue his career under Wenger's guidance. Wenger believes Sanchez's quick adaptation to English football proves he is one of the best around. The Arsenal boss also played down any talk of a potential summer transfer move for Liverpool forward Raheem Sterling.

Sir Bradley Wiggins will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner aims to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes at the Lee Valley VeloPark. Wiggins, who finished his Team Sky career in the Paris-Roubaix race, is expected to set a mark which will last for some time. He will hope for a capacity 6,000 crowd to spur on his attempt, with tickets going on sale from April 19, while the event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports.

Serena Williams struggled to beat Sara Errani in the Fed Cup, calling it an 'eye-opener' as the clay court season begins. Despite eventually winning 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3, Williams was not impressed with her performance. The US team was defeated 3-2, and Williams admitted she needs to adjust her mindset for the clay court season. Her doubles defeat blotted an otherwise flawless Fed Cup record, leaving the US facing a battle to get back amongst the elite nations next year.

River Plate wants to sign Radamel Falcao, a soccer player from Manchester United. He used to play for them before and they would like him back. The vice president of River Plate said they are open to having him return. Falcao has had some trouble scoring goals while playing for Manchester United this season, but he is doing well playing for his home country, Colombia. He played for River Plate when he was younger and scored 34 goals in 90 games.

Ella Henderson, a finalist from the 2012 series of The X Factor and pop star, has become the face of dry shampoo brand Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign. This marks her first brand collaboration at the age of 19. The partnership between Henderson and the UK's number 1 dry shampoo brand was facilitated by the MILES agency, and the international campaign launched with a TV advertising campaign featuring the singer's latest single, Mirror Man.

A billboard featuring officer Pablo Torres, who fatally shot Aaron Siler in Kenosha, Wisconsin on March 14, has been erected by the Kenosha Professional Police Association. Siler's family and friends find the billboard disrespectful and are asking for it to be taken down. The police association claims the billboard was meant to thank the community for its support and had no ill intentions. Officer Torres is currently on leave pending investigation into the shooting.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Pakistan border. The attack was carried out by a group called Jaish al Adal, which is an anti-Iranian group that has emerged in Balochistan province. Three of the militants were killed by Iranian forces, and the rest are believed to have fled back into Balochistan. Pakistani authorities condemned the attack and promised to apprehend any surviving assailants if they entered Pakistan.

The passage discusses a political discussion in Japan about the possibility of extraterrestrial unidentified flying objects (UFOs). In response to a query from a lawmaker, Defense Minister Gen Nakatani stated that Japan's Air Self Defense Force has never encountered a UFO from outer space. The lawmaker, Antonio Inoki, had asked if aircraft were ever scrambled to meet extraterrestrial threats and if research was being done into alien visitors. Inoki claims to have seen a UFO with his own eyes but doesn't know personally if aliens exist. This exchange isn't the first time Japanese politicians have discussed the implications of visitors from another planet.

A 35-year-old passenger, Jin Pai, was hospitalized with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after breaking a toilet he was squatting on in Hefei Xinqiao International Airport. He did not want to let his bottom touch the seat due to cleanliness concerns. The porcelain toilet tipped over and shattered, causing injuries that required dozens of stitches. Initially, Jin claimed he was sitting when the accident occurred, possibly to avoid paying compensation. Authorities believe it was an accident and remind people to use toilets for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, a 56-year-old man from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested for allegedly sexually abusing a girl over a four-year period and filming her and others with a hidden camera in the bathroom. He faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. The investigation began when the victim, now 15, found the hidden camera in her bathroom in March. Rebbie admitted to filming several victims, including other juveniles, but had purchased the camera specifically to record the now-15-year-old victim. His preliminary hearing is on May 1, and he is being held on a $500,000 bail.

Japanese photographer YÃ»ki Aoyama captures fathers leaping into the air next to their daughters in a series of images from his latest book, Daughter and Salary Man. The daughters pose po-faced while their fathers pull energetic poses in sharp suits, allowing them to express their fun side. The photos are taken in front of various Japanese landmarks and have gained interest online for their curious nature.

The passage discusses the dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director and the focus shifting to the start of the county championship season. Kevin Pietersen is highlighted as he poses for the Surrey team photo, reflecting on a potential return to the England set-up after being controversially axed in 2014. Pietersen rejoins Surrey in an attempt to force his way back into the Test set-up as England hopes to regain the Ashes this summer.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a Romanian club facing relegation, has fired their Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. Initially let go due to a poor run, he was reinstated by the owner Angelo Massone but then dismissed again after a loss to FC Botosani. The team is currently 16th in the standings and six points from safety. Ze Maria will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao's former Monaco teammate, Nabil Dirar, believes the Colombian striker must be regretting his failed loan move to Manchester United. Falcao struggled during his season-long loan and was not happy in France before the move. Despite this, Dirar thinks Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco as he would have played and participated in the Champions League. Manchester United is unlikely to make Falcao's transfer permanent due to his poor performance, having only scored four goals all season.

A man wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and fluoro orange sweatshirt robbed a Christchurch dairy, making off with the till and $1500 in cash. The owner's daughter was threatened during the incident, and the robber remains at large. Police are appealing to the public for help in identifying the suspect.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested for the second time amid claims of having sex with a 15-year-old student on two consecutive nights in January. She was initially arrested in March for an inappropriate relationship with another 15-year-old student and released on bail. The new allegations came to light after a school police officer learned of a possible relationship between Granado and one of the boys last month. Granado admitted to kissing the first student and allowing him to touch her breasts in April the previous year. She was suspended from teaching and put on administrative leave by school officials.

A video of a large crocodile swimming through a public marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico with a dead pet dog locked in its jaws has gone viral online, viewed over half a million times. The dog, belonging to the local bike shop owner, was curious and went to the water's edge but was caught by the crocodile. New Zealander Tim Weston witnessed the incident while on holiday and described the crocodile as keeping the dog in its mouth for ages without moving. Crocodiles are common in Puerto Vallarta due to the resort being built amongst their natural habitat, and they can reach lengths of up to 6 meters.

Steve Bruce is confident he can keep Hull City in the Premier League despite their current struggles. With six games left, including difficult fixtures against top teams, Hull is just two points clear of the drop zone after a 2-0 defeat by Southampton. Bruce believes that nine or eight wins might be enough to stay up and is convinced they can achieve this with a positive attitude. He attributes their difficulties to long-term injuries to key players. Meanwhile, Southampton moved up to fifth in the table after their win against Hull.

A teacher named Ian Guffick allowed students at Mitton Manor Primary School to change their exam answers after the test session ended, leading to the invalidation of the school's SATs results. Guffick also altered some of the pupils' answers himself. The Department for Education annulled all SATs exam results for the entire school as a result of the investigation. Guffick admitted to unacceptable professional conduct and was banned from teaching for at least two years.

Anders Lindegaard, Manchester United goalkeeper, enjoyed a day off with his wife Misse Beqiri in Cheshire. The couple, who married in Mauritius last year, have a son together and have been dating since 2012. Despite struggling for playing time at Manchester United, Lindegaard reminded fans of his marriage to the Swedish model through Instagram.

The glowing blue letters that once lit up Yankee Stadium failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction, despite expectations of $300,000 to $600,000. Reggie Jackson, the current owner and Yankee Hall of Famer, purchased the 10-feet-tall letters for an undisclosed amount after the stadium's final game in 2008. He hoped a new generation would own and enjoy this iconic piece of Yankees and New York City history. The letters were installed in 1976 and taken down in 2008.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has reminded Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their professional responsibilities after they were exposed for inhaling nitrous oxide and seen with shisha pipes. Rodgers spoke to the players but decided not to discipline them, urging them to learn from the experience. He emphasized the importance of understanding the responsibilities that come with being an elite sportsperson. Liverpool faces Aston Villa in the FA Cup semi-final, with Steven Gerrard available after a three-match suspension. Rodgers did not reveal whether he would give Gerrard an immediate recall.

Arsenal's Mesut Ozil enjoyed his downtime at home in London with his dog after playing in Germany's 2-0 win against Georgia in a Euro 2016 qualifier. The midfielder, who missed Arsenal's last game due to illness, is expected to play against Liverpool at the Emirates Stadium. Ozil has been adjusting well to English football and has contributed three goals and four assists since January.

The Barcelona club president, Josep Maria Bartomeu, has stated that the La Liga leaders have no intention of replacing Luis Enrique and are very happy with his performance. Despite speculation about Enrique's future at the club, Bartomeu refuted these claims and praised the manager for his work. Enrique is currently focused on La Liga and preparing for upcoming games, with a contract until 2016.

Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract with Liverpool, worth around Â£100,000-a-week and running until the summer of 2020. The club's vice-captain had 14 months remaining on his current deal and is set to sign improved terms. Henderson has been one of the most improved players under Brendan Rodgers' watch and is expected to be considered for the role of club captain when Steven Gerrard moves to LA Galaxy.

Filipe Luis wants to stay at Chelsea until the end of his contract, despite Atletico Madrid considering bringing him back. He signed a three-year contract when he moved from Atletico last July but has struggled to secure the left back position at Stamford Bridge. Atletico hopes this may give them leverage, but Luis insists he is happy at Chelsea and wants to stay. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is focused on winning every game in the Premier League title run-in, and Luis believes the team is prepared for the challenging situation ahead.

Nathan Hughes had his three-match ban overturned on appeal after an outcry in his favor. He was initially suspended for being 'reckless' and knocking out George North, but the appeal panel concluded that the incident occurred accidentally with no act of foul play. Hughes is now free to return to action immediately, missing his club's Champions Cup defeat to holders Toulon last Sunday.

The passage describes a series of stunning sunsets in Washington, caused by wildfires in parts of Siberia. Farmers burning grass in their fields led to uncontrollable flames that destroyed dozens of villages and spread smoke across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest. The red and orange colors in the sunsets are due to smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelength colors from sunlight. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve and the fiery sunsets will lose their reddish hue.

Missouri mom Becky Schoenig's brand new 2015 Ford Fusion was stolen from her driveway, only to be found later with red spray-painted rims, red detailing, and orange accents. Instead of being upset, Schoenig thanked the thieves on Facebook for "pimping out" her car and is now getting it professionally cleaned. She is also creating a smoothie at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, in honor of Mick Sexton, the man who located her car and notified police.

Manchester City players stand to lose Â£500,000 each in bonuses if they fail to qualify for the Champions League this season. The club has incentivized contracts with star players like Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, and Yaya Toure to meet financial fair play requirements. With their European hopes still uncertain after a loss to Manchester United, City is currently in fourth place and faces a tough battle to secure a top-four finish. The top three Premier League teams automatically qualify for the Champions League, while the fourth-place team must win a qualifying round. In total, the City squad has around Â£12 million resting on reaching their European target.

Manchester United's Under 18s defeated Manchester City's Under 18s 1-0 in a local derby match held at Moss Lane. The match had free entry and attracted close to 1,000 spectators. Callum Gribbin scored the only goal with a well-taken free-kick. Both teams played with a high level of skill and commitment, showcasing potential future talents for their respective clubs.

Joe Hart praised Gianluigi Buffon as a "legend of the game" after the Italian goalkeeper earned his 147th cap. Hart, who celebrated his 50th cap for England, expressed admiration for Buffon's continued dedication and performance at the age of 37. Both goalkeepers played in the 1-1 draw between England and Italy.

Chipotle has partnered with Postmates to offer delivery for online and mobile orders in 67 cities, entering the $70 billion food delivery market. The service will include a nine per cent service charge and delivery fees starting at $5, depending on distance and demand. This move comes after Chipotle previously declined offers from other third-party delivery services. Other franchises like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also exploring delivery options.

The parents of the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, Martin Richard, have urged the Justice Department to take the death penalty off the table for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was found guilty on all 30 charges related to the bombings and subsequent violence. Bill and Denise Richard wrote in a Boston Globe opinion piece that they understand the heinousness and brutality of the crimes committed but are in favor of Tsarnaev spending the rest of his life in prison without possibility of release or appeal, as further pursuit of the death penalty could lead to years of appeals and prolong their pain.

A mystery billionaire has spent Â£400 million to convert a Boeing 747 into a luxury home, complete with bedrooms, multiple lounges, an onboard restaurant, and even an aeroloft with eight full beds. The custom-built jumbo jet took three years to build and was designed to fit the owner's specifications exactly. It can accommodate dozens of guests and features a large dining room, a lounge, a state room, and a conference room suitable for meetings. The interior design resembles a luxury hotel, with plush seating and over-the-top decorations.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed Dragon cargo spacecraft to the International Space Station. The launch was successful, but the company failed in its attempt to land the rocket on a floating barge for the first time. SpaceX plans to keep trying and eventually land rockets on the ground to cut costs.
