The Dragon will deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies to the space station and later return with science experiments and trash. This is SpaceX's sixth mission to the International Space Station.

Priscilla Presley will be a witness at the first wedding to be held at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas. The chapel is part of the Westgate Hotel, where Elvis performed over 830 sold-out shows. One lucky couple, chosen from an Elvis-themed contest, will win a free wedding reception, hotel suite stay, airfares, and concert tickets. Priscilla has been involved in designing the chapel and ensuring it is not a joke or impersonator-focused. Couples must submit a video or photos with an explanation on why they should win the ultimate wedding experience.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can catch up with Manchester City in the Premier League after their 2-0 win against Newcastle United. Both Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet played their 47th game of the season, equaling the record for appearances in the top five European leagues this campaign. Despite recent poor results against Manchester United and Arsenal, Liverpool is only four points behind City in the race for the Champions League.

Roma ended their four-month winless streak at home with a 1-0 victory over Napoli in Serie A, thanks to Miralem Pjanic's goal in the 25th minute. Goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made several crucial saves in the second half to secure the win. The victory moved Roma provisionally four points ahead of Lazio and into second place. Napoli's winless streak extended to five matches, and they remained fifth in the league. Security was tight for the match due to a previous fan incident, but there were no reports of problems. Roma played without injured captain Francesco Totti and fellow forward Gervinho, while Napoli had Lorenzo Insigne return from injury late in the game.

Doncaster Rovers are having an unimpressive season, currently mid-table in League One. Their match against Fleetwood Town ended in a goalless draw, leaving the media team with a challenge to create highlights for the club's YouTube channel. The resulting video was only 27 seconds long, featuring 14 seconds of match action.

Roland Giroux has a unique relationship with his blood parrot cichlid, which he showcases in a video where he gently strokes and massages the fish. The fish initially moves away but returns to rest between Giroux's fingers, seemingly enjoying the interaction. Giroux began interacting with the fish after noticing it was being bullied by other fish in the tank, eventually leading to a daily routine of playing with the fish for at least 15 minutes.

The passage discusses Ben Stokes' return to the England cricket team and his reputation as a fiery character. It highlights the importance of channeling his aggression in the right way and the need for careful man-managing. The author believes that Stokes should be allowed to maintain his natural exuberance and desire to take someone on, but his aggression must be controlled. The article also mentions Stokes' clash with Marlon Samuels and how England's coach, Peter Moores, had a long chat with him after the incident. The author concludes by stating that Stokes can use his aggression to bring runs and wickets to the England team and that he is an exciting prospect for the future.

Wales' crunch Euro 2016 qualifier with Belgium on June 12 is a sell-out with 33,000 tickets sold. Both teams have 11 points, but Belgium ranks fourth in the world and leads Group B due to superior goal difference. Wales' recent 3-0 victory over Israel has raised expectations for their potential to qualify for a major tournament for the first time since the 1958 World Cup. The Football Association of Wales stated that general admission tickets for the match at Cardiff City Stadium have sold out due to high demand. Despite speculation, UEFA rules prevented the venue from being changed from Cardiff City Stadium to Millennium Stadium.

England's Under-17 team, coached by John Peacock, has announced its squad for the upcoming UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria. The defending champions have a 100% record in qualifying and are placed in Group D with Holland, Italy, and Republic of Ireland. They will play Italy on May 7 to start their campaign. The squad includes young talents from various Premier League clubs such as Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi, and Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold.

Manchester City wants to sign 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered a top talent from the club's youth system. Arsenal and Barcelona have also shown interest in him. Despite attracting attention from Barcelona's La Masia academy at age 12, he declined due to family wishes for him to focus on his studies. City is discussing compensation with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock as they aim to secure Patoulidis for their future plans under Manuel Pellegrini.

A 23-year-old man has been arrested in connection with the death of Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old transgender escort from Mexico who was found strangled and beaten in a Â£400,000 flat in Fulham, south west London. The man has been bailed and is due to return to a London police station for further questioning at a later date. Scotland Yard is appealing for anyone who had contact with Miss Santillan in the hours before her death to come forward. Miss Santillan worked as an escort in London, Paris, and Miami and had moved to London from Mexico. She spoke of her love for London and Paris online in the weeks before her death. Police are urging anyone with information to help them understand why this happened.

A woman named Dawn, who had suffered seven miscarriages, was devastated when a family friend, Jamie, stole money set aside for her babies' grave stone. After confronting Jamie and his girlfriend Carol, Dawn appeared on The Jeremy Kyle Show where a lie detector test revealed that Jamie had indeed taken the cash. Dawn was left feeling betrayed and heartbroken as the money was meant for a gravestone to honor her child.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, mostly women and children, who were captured during the group's attack on northern Iraq last summer. The release was coordinated with the help of Arab tribal leaders, but the reason for the release is unclear. This follows previous releases of Yazidis by ISIS, including scores of children and the elderly. The Yazidis are a minority group of Kurdish descent whose religion is considered a pre-Islamic sect drawing from Christianity, Judaism, and Zoroastrianism. They have long suffered persecution and have been referred to as devil worshipers by some Muslims.

Harry Kane, a young Tottenham striker, has had an outstanding season and is now nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards. He has broken into the first team and Roy Hodgson's England side during this remarkable season. A new animation by Copa90 features some of Kane's best goals and celebrations from the season, including his 20th Premier League goal against Newcastle. The video showcases his long-range strike against Chelsea, a headed goal against Arsenal, and his debut goal for England. The video is titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?' and will be released before the awards ceremony on Sunday, where Kane will compete with players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez for the top prize.

Jamie Carragher believes Brendan Rodgers should remain as Liverpool's manager despite a trophyless season and possible failure to qualify for the Champions League. Carragher, who received a Beacon Award for his community work in Merseyside, stated that Rodgers' future should not be determined by one game and that he needs to identify areas of improvement within the team. The former Liverpool defender also emphasized the importance of making the right signings to strengthen the squad.

A four-year-old boy named James Hayward had his toy gun taken away at East Midlands Airport because it was seen as a security risk. His parents were going on vacation to Lanzarote and had packed the toy in their hand luggage. The airport staff thought it looked like a real gun, so they took it away from James and checked him thoroughly. His dad thought this was silly and said they should have let the little boy keep his toy. After their trip, James got a new toy gun to replace the one that was taken away.

A lonely man in Humpty Doo, Northern Territory has posted a Gumtree advertisement seeking a girlfriend or wife. He lists his requirements for the 'successful candidate', including being a non-drinker and smoker, fit and attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, good around the house, good with their hands, a good cook, great in bed, enjoying the outdoors but also able to be a 'princess when need to be'. The 31-year-old man describes himself as athletic, heavily tattooed, and successful. He promises to spend money on his partner and consider all reasonable offers.

Football Association chairman Greg Dyke has received support from five former England managers in his push for radical changes to increase the number of home-grown players in club squads. The proposed changes include increasing the minimum number of home-grown players from eight to 12 and changing the rules so that 'home-grown' means having trained in England for three years before the age of 18 rather than before 21. The former England managers warn that failure to implement these changes could risk England falling further behind leading football nations and make it harder to win the World Cup. They also highlight the shrinking pool of English talent playing at the top level as a clear disadvantage for any England manager.

In the latest episode of Poldark, Demelza gives birth to a baby girl, and Ross Poldark is shown as a loving father. The timeline of Demelza's pregnancy seems rushed, as she goes from announcing her pregnancy to giving birth in less than an episode. Fans have noticed this inconsistency and expressed their thoughts on social media.

Leicester City's manager Nigel Pearson has asked his team to focus on their own performance and not be distracted by their relegation rivals. The Foxes are three points from safety in the Premier League after back-to-back wins, but remain at the bottom of the table. Pearson wants his players to concentrate on their own games and not worry about other teams' results. He believes that their future is in their own hands and they have a realistic chance if they perform well in their remaining matches.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara has set a new record for the longest mammal migration, swimming nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. The previous record was held by a humpback whale at 10,190 miles. During her journey, Varvara visited three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, which may indicate that some western gray whales are actually eastern grays. This discovery could have implications for the believed number of western gray whales in existence.

A 1,000ft stretch of seabed was pushed to the surface overnight on the Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu, Hokkaido Island, Japan due to a landslide caused by melting ice and snow. The new landmass is as high as 50ft above sea level and measures approximately 1,000-1,640ft long and 100ft wide. No tremors or sounds were reported during the event, and it is not expected to expand further.

Gregory van der Wiel denies leaving Paris Saint-Germain rumors and expresses his love for the club. Despite a recent falling out with manager Laurent Blanc, Van der Wiel states he is happy in Paris and has no plans to leave. He wants to sign a new contract and is ready to play whenever called upon. However, with PSG being linked to Barcelona's Dani Alves, Van der Wiel's future at the club remains uncertain.

Carlos Tevez wants to terminate his contract with Juventus and return to his former club Boca Juniors in Argentina. Although his deal with the Serie A champions runs until the end of next season, he has reportedly expressed his desire to leave this summer. Boca Juniors are close to completing a deal for the 31-year-old striker, but Tevez must first terminate his contract with Juventus. Despite being reluctant to lose their top scorer, Juventus have accepted that Tevez wants to leave and are already identifying potential replacements.

During an exciting Champions League match between Bayern Munich and Porto, Bayern's manager Pep Guardiola ripped a hole in his trousers, revealing his underwear. The incident occurred during the first half when Bayern was leading 5-0. Despite the wardrobe malfunction, Bayern went on to win the match 6-1, with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and Robert Lewandowski. This victory allowed Bayern to book their place in the Champions League semi-finals.

A multi-vehicle crash involving ten people, including four children, occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale. Three vehicles collided, resulting in various injuries. Two patients were flown to the Princess Alexandra Hospital by rescue helicopter, while six others were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for further assessment. The highway was closed off and diversions were put in place. One person was trapped in their vehicle and had to be freed by Queensland Fire and Rescue crews using hydraulic cutting gear.

Arsenal's Mesut Ozil received a new Apple Watch and shared his excitement on Instagram. The midfielder is expected to play in the upcoming match against Chelsea, as Arsenal trails by 10 points with six games remaining. Meanwhile, Jack Wilshere's fitness is seen as a key factor for the team's success, according to club legend Ray Parlour.

Referee Mark Clattenburg will officiate the Manchester derby between United and City at Old Trafford on Sunday, despite having sent off three players from both teams this season. He has only shown two red cards this season, both to United players. City captain Vincent Kompany is suspended for the match due to his dismissal in a Euro 2016 qualifier. The match could ultimately decide who finishes second behind expected winners Chelsea.

Bob Katter, an MP of Lebanese descent, accused the Queensland Government of assuming that embattled MP Billy Gordon would quit after being accused of domestic violence and admitting to his criminal past. Katter sympathizes with Gordon's position and questions why the government assumed he would resign when similar cases in the federal parliament did not lead to resignations. The statement has sparked criticism on social media for its terminology, but Katter defends it by saying he used the term "black puppet" based on his personal experiences and to call out racial overtones.

Dayna Dobias, a teenager from Illinois with cerebral palsy, is using dance to challenge stereotypes and inspire others with disabilities. She creates enthusiastic videos to counteract the negative perceptions people have about her condition and show that she is just like everyone else. Dayna hopes her videos will encourage people to think before judging those with disabilities. In addition to dancing, she has started motivational speaking at local schools in the Chicago area.

Orlando City, an MLS side with a large Latin-American fanbase, is interested in signing Manchester United's Javier Hernandez. The Mexican international could be a significant commercial asset for the Florida-based team coached by Adrian Heath. Orlando made enquiries about a potential deal last week. However, they face competition from eight European clubs and other Premier League teams such as Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, and Everton. Hernandez has one year left on his contract, and Manchester United is willing to sell him for around Â£8 million. Meanwhile, Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to teenage prospect Andreas Pereira, who has attracted interest from Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord if he doesn't agree to terms at United.

A group of at least three people set a car on fire at a California gas station after pouring gasoline on it and attempting to carjack the driver. The incident occurred at a 76 Station in South Los Angeles around 12:15am on Saturday. The driver, who has not been identified, got into an argument with the suspects while pumping gas. The passengers and driver were unharmed, but the car was completely destroyed. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as an arson, and the suspects are still at large. Surveillance video is being used in the investigation.

A southern Iowa chiropractor, Charles Manuel, has surrendered his state license after being accused of accepting sex as payment for his services and performing exorcisms on patients. Manuel admitted to his misdeeds and agreed not to apply for reinstatement for at least 10 years. Despite these accusations, he received outstanding evaluations for patient satisfaction on HealthGrades.com. The agreement requires Manuel to prove that the circumstances surrounding the revocation of his license no longer exist before he can resume practicing chiropractic in the state.

A Russian fighter jet intercepted a U.S. reconnaissance plane in an "unsafe and unprofessional manner" over the Baltic Sea, prompting the U.S. to complain to Moscow. The Pentagon stated that the Russian SU-27 Flanker performed aggressive maneuvers close to the U.S. RC-135U aircraft and had a high rate of speed. Russian state news claimed the U.S. plane was flying toward the Russian border with its transponder off, but this was denied by a U.S. official. This is not the first time such an incident has occurred between a RC-135U and a SU-27; a similar event happened over the Sea of Okhotsk last year.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from a Salt Lake City hotel parking lot just days before President Obama's visit to Utah. The gun, secured in a hard case and attached to a truck safe with padlocks and chains, was taken by breaking the rear right passenger-side window and using another vehicle's momentum to break the case's handle free from the lock. The thief also stole the agent's gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools. The hotel does not have surveillance cameras, and the sniper rifle has not been recovered.

In July 2012, Luigi Costa, 71, allegedly killed his elderly neighbor Terrence Freebody in Red Hill, Canberra. Costa is accused of stomping on Freebody's head, cutting his throat, and stabbing him multiple times. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen examined Costa and found evidence of a decline in his mental state leading up to the incident. He believes that dementia and alcohol abuse compromised Costa's brain at the time of the murder. The jury can return a not guilty verdict if Costa's unstable mindset during the attack can be proven.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley's decision to take a penalty kick during their 1-0 win against Burnley, despite Leighton Baines having a better success rate in the Premier League. Barkley's effort was saved by Burnley goalkeeper Tom Heaton, but fortunately for Everton, Kevin Mirallas scored the only goal of the game later on. Martinez stated that Barkley was within his rights to request penalty-taking duties and that he loves seeing players take control of big moments.

Two passengers were found dead in a suspected murder-suicide on a cruise ship in Puerto Rico. The incident occurred on the ms Ryndam, and the cabin was immediately secured with authorities notified, including the FBI. The ship had departed from Tampa, Florida on March 29 for a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise and is currently in San Juan, Puerto Rico. The cleaning staff discovered the deceased passengers after knocking on the cabin's door.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, has led Curacao to the second qualifying round in CONCACAF for the 2018 World Cup. They advanced after a 2-2 draw in the second-leg match against Montserrat, winning 4-3 on aggregate. Curacao won the first match 2-1 in Willemstad. Kluivert's team will face Cuba in the next round on June 8 and 16.

Esteban Cambiasso, a highly decorated footballer, has stated that keeping Leicester City in the Premier League would be one of his greatest achievements. Despite the team being at the bottom of the table and facing a difficult challenge to avoid relegation, Cambiasso remains optimistic and believes that saving Leicester will feel like winning a trophy. He joined Leicester in 2014 after a successful career in Italy and Spain, where he won numerous titles including the Champions League and La Liga.

A 23-year-old mother with two children under five is at risk of being banned from seeing her kids due to her excessive drinking and partying. She handed over the care of her infants to her 52-year-old mother when they were four months old. The grandmother, Debbie, threatens to ban the young mother from seeing the children after discovering her daughter's habit of using legal high MKat and suspicion of stealing. Debbie stepped in to care for the children when social services considered taking them away. She claims that Gemma's constant drinking and partying is getting out of hand and she stole an iPad from one of the children to fund her lifestyle. Although Gemma denies stealing the iPad, she admits to stealing money and other items from her mother in the past. Debbie plans to ban Gemma from her home and prevent her from seeing the children as she cannot trust her not to steal their possessions.

During a match between Chelsea and Manchester United, Eden Hazard scored a goal for Chelsea after receiving the ball from Oscar. The goal was set up by John Terry's strong challenge on Radamel Falcao, which led to a loose ball that Cesc Fabregas picked up to start the scoring move. Sky Sports pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness agreed during half-time analysis that play should have been stopped for Terry's rough tackle on Falcao, as it was considered a foul.

A tour bus belonging to Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott caught fire on a Texas freeway, but all passengers were safely evacuated. The cause of the fire was a blown-out rear tire. Scott and other passengers, including her husband, the tour manager, and the driver, were able to escape unharmed. The band's two other members were not on the bus at the time.

Dr Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University is working on a space laser that can convert sunlight into energy using satellites covered in mirrors. The laser will be used to power homes and could make solar power viable in Scotland or restore power instantly to disaster-hit areas. Unlike in movies, the lasers will not be powerful enough to harm people or planets. However, Dr Quarterman acknowledges concerns about who controls the satellites.

A man named Stephen Munden, who is not well in his mind and likes little girls a lot, has escaped from a place where he was being kept safe. He was last seen leaving a hospital near a place called Hook in Hampshire. The police are looking for him because he did something very bad to a little girl on a bus. They have pictures of him with and without a beard, and they think he might have removed his beard before leaving the hospital. They also believe he may have some trouble learning and understanding things. The police want to find him quickly because he needs to be watched carefully.

A Los Angeles judge has ordered V. Stiviano to repay over $2.6 million in gifts received from Donald Sterling, after his wife sued her for targeting wealthy older men. The court ruled in favor of the Sterling family, setting a precedent that the injured spouse can recover damages from the recipient of ill-gotten gifts. This comes after Donald Sterling's racist remarks led to him losing ownership of the NBA team Los Angeles Clippers.

Thierry Henry has criticized Arsenal's recent transfer dealings and urged the club to sign four top players in the summer. He believes that Arsenal need a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder, and striker to have any chance of winning the Premier League title. Henry also questioned whether Arsenal can win the title with Olivier Giroud as their first-choice striker. He suggested that the team needs to sign players of similar caliber to Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas, and Diego Costa to compete for the title.

A young woman who was abused by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn for years has shared the severe impact it had on her life. Van Ryn pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim is scared for her future relationships and didn't understand why she was targeted. She didn't know the abuse was wrong until she heard he had been caught and attempted to take her own life since then. The hearing continues.

The passage discusses the recovery of Arsenal teenager Serge Gnabry, who has been out for over a year due to a serious knee injury. The 19-year-old midfielder impressed last season but was sidelined after the Champions League match against Bayern Munich in March 2014. Gnabry recently played 90 minutes for Arsenal Under 21s against Reading and is now over his injury concerns, feeling better and looking forward to future games.

A 23-year-old accountant, Jacob Phillips, fell to his death after running from a taxi to avoid paying the fare. He had been out with friends in Penarth, South Wales and didn't have enough cash to pay for the cab. After jumping out of the taxi and over a fence in the dark, he plunged down a 70ft cliff. The taxi driver chased him but was unaware of the danger Phillips faced. His body was found by a dog walker the next day on a rocky beach at the base of the cliff. The coroner recorded a verdict of accidental death, stating that Phillips likely became disoriented and couldn't have known the danger ahead.

Last summer, thousands of holidaymakers faced passport delays and many had to pay extra to get their travel documents rushed through. Despite the passport agency making a Â£42 million profit during the chaos, only 2,191 compensation applications were approved, with an average payout of Â£92.68. Ministers rejected a demand for blanket refunds, and managers at the passport agency received bonuses up to Â£3,500.

A 1930s timewarp home in Horfield, Bristol, with original features such as stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, and retro food jars, is up for sale. The semi-detached property has a guide price of Â£200,000-Â£250,000 and includes the original bathroom, kitchen, and vintage cupboards. Despite some upgraded features like double glazing, potential renovation costs may deter developers. The house will be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick started as a backup to Alex Smith but became the 49ers' starter in 2012 after Smith's concussion. He led the team to their first Super Bowl since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice is an author who was born in New Orleans and lived there as a child before moving to Texas and then San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey that connects the New Jersey Turnpike to New York State Route 495 inside the Lincoln Tunnel, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language television network owned by Comcast through NBCUniversal division NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in East London and Essex, attended Stanway School where he met Graham Coxon and formed Blur. Their debut album Leisure was released in 1991 with mixed reviews. The band's self-titled album in 2001 was a worldwide success. Albarn's solo studio album Everyday Robots, co-produced by Richard Russell, was released in 2014 featuring collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir.

Mogadishu, also known as Hamar, is the capital and largest city of Somalia. It is locally pronounced [ËmÉËÉ¡ÉËdiËÊuË] in English, [mÊqdÉªÊÉ] in Latin script, and [ÙÙØ¯ÙØ´Ù] in Arabic script. The city is home to many important national institutions due to its status as Somalia's capital.
The song "Happiness in Slavery" is by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails and is featured on their debut EP, Broken, released in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker is an American screenwriter born on August 14, 1964, who has been nominated for a BAFTA award.

The passage describes two different works: a 2007 film called "Shooter" and a TV series with the same name. Both feature a character named Bob Lee Swagger, who is an expert marksman. Cuadrilla, a firm conducting shale gas drilling or "fracking" tests, has suspended operations as a precaution after a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months. The British Geological Survey (BGS) will examine data before the company decides whether to resume. A similar tremor occurred on 1 April. Fracking involves shattering hard shale rocks underground to release gas using hydraulic pressure or tiny explosions. The process has been controversial due to environmental concerns, but the Commons energy select committee supports it with proper regulation and good industry practice. The BGS is monitoring fracking as a precaution and has recorded two small earthquakes in Lancashire since fracking began there in March.

Angus Carpenter, a bagpiper who has played in Liverpool for over 30 years, was found guilty of one count of fraud. He was accused of collecting money for the Hillsborough Justice Campaign while performing with a banner featuring the charity's name and logo. Carpenter claimed he was simply busking and had permission to display the banner as a tribute to the victims. The jury cleared him of two other fraud charges. He will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3-0, with goals from Grant Ward, Luke Varney, and Tom Lawrence. QPR had few attacking opportunities and failed to score, while Ipswich could have scored more goals. The win moved Ipswich up four places to 14th, while QPR slipped to 15th. QPR manager Ian Holloway criticized his team's defending and mental toughness, while Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy praised his players' performances.

Summary:
The passage discusses the impressive performance of Wells, aged 23, in the T20 Blast last season where he scored 373 runs at a strike rate of 138.66. He expresses excitement about the club's direction and praises the elite performance environment created by the coaches.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured a second consecutive win by defeating third-placed Chinnor 29-12. Key players Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams played a crucial role in the victory. Churcher praised their performance and highlighted the importance of the front row and front five's contribution in making over 70 tackles during the match. The Reds have seven games against lower-ranked teams and league leaders Old Elthamians coming up. Although they won, Churcher believes there is still room for improvement and emphasizes the need to build on their recent success to avoid wasting the progress made last weekend.

A 28-year-old man named Nazrul, also known as Nazu, has been accused of raping a 74-year-old nun in Ranaghat town, India. He was arrested at a railway station in Kolkata and is the sixth person to be arrested in connection with the crime. Police have identified eight suspects, with two still untraced. The incident led to widespread protests across India. Money was stolen from the convent school during the attack, and the building was ransacked before the nun was raped in the convent itself.

The passage discusses an interactive video featuring Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London. He explains the reasons behind changes in consumer purchases, such as the introduction of domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports. The video also explores shifts in brand ownership and rankings among the top 20 consumer brands in the UK. A non-interactive version is available for users with older browsers.

The passage describes two incidents where individuals were scammed by callers claiming to be from BT technical support. In the first incident, a 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills was tricked on September 15th, and in the second incident, a woman in Stranraer lost money on September 22nd. Both incidents involved the scammers gaining remote access to the victims' computers and stealing substantial amounts of money. PC Siobhan Pellett warns people to be cautious when receiving cold calls asking for remote access to their computer and never to give out banking details or account numbers over the phone.

Duffy, a 37-year-old former professional rugby player, has signed a one-year contract with third-placed Championship team Featherstone after leaving Swinton Lions. He will lead the team in their final league game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers. The chairman of Featherstone praised Duffy as a fantastic coach and expressed excitement about his future with the team. Duffy had previously played for Leigh, Widnes, and Salford during his 16-year playing career and was replaced by Stuart Littler at Swinton.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, along with a medic and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter, were dispatched to Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve on Sunday at 12:50 GMT. The rider had sustained head injuries and was suffering from hypothermia after being unconscious on the wet sand. After receiving treatment, she was airlifted to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales for further care.

The UN conference in Geneva decided to dedicate part of the radio spectrum for a global flight tracking system, aiming to improve the current tracking system that relies on ground-based radars. MH370's disappearance in 2014 revealed weaknesses in worldwide air navigation systems, prompting Malaysia's communication minister to urge the ITU for real-time flight data transmission solutions. The new system will enable satellites to receive transmissions from aircraft, allowing "real-time tracking of aircraft anywhere in the world." The UN's aviation arm, ICAO, has set a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines, including aircraft sending their position every 15 minutes or more during emergencies.

A long-missing child, Julian Hernandez, has been found at the age of 18 living with his father in Cleveland. The FBI received a tip about his possible identity after he faced issues applying for college. The agency worked with local police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children to confirm his identity. His mother has been notified of his recovery. Julian's father, Bobby Hernandez, is charged with tampering with records to obtain a driver's license in 2012 and is being held at Cuyahoga County Jail with a $250,000 bail. Authorities had suspected him as the culprit since the time of the boy's disappearance.

A fire at Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited's site in Duncan Street on 2 March led to train service disruptions and travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended the company from accepting waste, as they were "broadly compliant" with fire safety law. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) had visited the premises nine times in the last year and found the site operators, Asset and Land Group, to be broadly compliant with fire safety legislation. The EA decided to revoke the environmental permit after concerns raised by GMFRS about the impact of a fire on nearby residents, transport, and the environment. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia proposed two bills related to Ukraine's Crimea region, where pro-Russian feelings are strong. One bill suggests new provisions that could be triggered by a referendum or a plea from territory leaders, allowing part of a neighboring state's territory to become a new "subject" of the Russian Federation. The other bill aims to speed up the process for issuing Russian passports to Ukrainians, removing requirements such as paying a state tax and having previous residence in Russia. The fast-track procedure for passport issuance was announced in Sevastopol, with several Russian MPs, including celebrities, supporting the move.

The passage discusses the history of McLaren in Formula 1, highlighting their past successes and current struggles. Despite having won 182 grands prix and 12 drivers' world championships, McLaren is currently experiencing a slump due to issues with their Honda power-unit. The team's last constructors' title was in 1998-99, and they have not had a win since 2012. The passage also mentions scandals involving illegally possessing Ferrari technical information and misleading stewards. Ron Dennis, who has held various roles within the team, believes that McLaren will break Mercedes' hegemony in F1 and return to winning ways.

Thomas Baker, a 44-year-old man from Everton, was found badly injured at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on January 27th after being shot in the head and chest. He later died in the hospital. Three men from Liverpool, aged 29 and 32, have been arrested and remain in police custody for questioning. Detectives believe the suspects had been waiting outside Phoenix Gym for about an hour before the shooting occurred. A silver VW polo, which "left the scene at speed," is still being sought by officers. Merseyside Police are urging anyone with information, especially those who were captured on CCTV near the meat market, to come forward as they may have key information for the investigation.

The passage discusses various ways to enjoy Christmas online, including virtual church services, a Bible-themed fantasy game for children, and nativity videos. It highlights the success of a German marketing company's digital story of the nativity and the use of Manga as a medium to share biblical stories. Additionally, it mentions how social media platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram are being utilized by various groups to connect with their communities during the holiday season.

The eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is discussing a proposal to take over 250 hectares of common land, with backers offering 320 hectares of replacement land. Experts have given conflicting opinions on the potential damage to habitats and plant life. Natural Resources Wales finds it difficult to conclude if the replacement land is of equal value but does not oppose the development overall. An ecology report from developers claims a "net gain" in biodiversity due to enhancement work on nearby habitats, which the Gwent wildlife trust disagrees with. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation after the inquiry, with Welsh government ministers having the final say on whether the plans can proceed.

Chechen Muslim clerics have called for retribution against journalists after a report by Novaya Gazeta revealed the detention and torture of over 100 people on suspicion of being homosexual. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report, but Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations. The paper's editor urged dialogue and said journalists would continue investigating human rights abuses in Chechnya. The LGBT Network is helping people flee persecution and may file a case at the International Criminal Court if Russia fails to prosecute anyone.

Investing Solutions, a letting agency, has been receiving housing benefit payments for the past two years by housing single homeless men in properties sourced by Fresh Start Housing, a charity. The company and charity are not acting illegally, but a homeless group claims their relationship is unethical. Investing Solutions makes a profit by housing several unrelated people in one house and charging housing benefit for each person, resulting in higher payouts than rent fees passed to landlords. Both organizations are based in the same storage unit in south London. Investing Solutions is one of the largest recipients of housing benefit in the UK and focuses on providing housing to single homeless men over 35. However, they have been criticized for poor living conditions in their properties. Wandsworth Council has paid Investing Solutions over Â£2.1m in the past two years, while other councils have dedicated teams to ensure private sector housing is safe and affordable.

In a closely contested game, the Netherlands defeated Great Britain 79-75. Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and NBA player Ben Gordon added 13 for GB. Coach Joe Prunty's team led for most of the first three quarters but lost momentum in the last 10 minutes. GB begins their Eurobasket qualifying campaign with a midweek game in Hungary. Prunty emphasized the importance of giving their best on every play and maintaining intensity on both ends of the floor. Despite a late comeback attempt, the hosts couldn't overcome the Dutch lead, who were led by 18 points from Worthy De Jong. Prunty praised Gordon's performance, stating that he had a good showing and contributed well to the team.

A former five-weight world champion submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) for a bout at 154 lbs, which requires 10oz gloves. The NAC will debate the matter on 16 August and decide whether to allow lighter gloves. Lighter gloves offer less cushioning but can lead to more punishing punches. The fighters' health and safety is the top priority. McGregor, who has used 4oz gloves in his UFC career, welcomed Mayweather's Instagram post about using 8oz Grant gloves. The NAC will publicly debate the issue before announcing its decision.

The last two journalists have left Fleet Street, once the hub of British journalism with nearly every national paper and several provincial newspapers having offices within a half-mile radius. The first British daily newspaper was published here in 1702. At its peak, it was known as "the Street of Shame" and was synonymous with the nation's biggest newspapers. However, media tycoon Rupert Murdoch moved his papers to Wapping in east London in 1986, leading to a bitter dispute which ended in defeat for the unions and most national newspapers moving away from Fleet Street by 1988. The buildings they left behind gradually morphed into other uses.

The Harry Potter author, J.K. Rowling, faced criticism on Twitter for her political views and donations to the campaign for a No vote in the Scottish independence referendum. She revealed that she had been called "a traitor" and blocked some abusive users who she believed were supporters of the Scottish National Party (SNP). Rowling also mentioned that she had discussed common political ground with other SNP supporters.

A study by the University of Edinburgh found that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action for the same crime as better-off children. Poverty also increases the likelihood of violence among both boys and girls. The study tracked 4,300 young people in Edinburgh since 1998 and found that household poverty is an exacerbating factor for young people offending. Additionally, the recent fall in crime rates in Scotland has not benefited areas with the most chronic rates of crime, and crime tends to be highly concentrated amongst poor people and within poor neighborhoods.

Mr. Haugh, 25, was stabbed in a laneway in the Marian estate early Sunday morning. Robbie Walsh has been charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr. Haugh and is remanded in custody until next week's court appearance. Two other men were arrested and released without charge, with files being prepared for the Director of Public Prosecutions. It is alleged that Mr. Walsh and two other males entered the Marian Estate looking for Mr. Haugh, resulting in a fight where weapons were used, leading to Mr. Haugh's death. A knife handle and blade with blood were recovered at the scene. The judge remanded Mr. Walsh in custody due to tension in the area following the killing.

In May 2014, Fermanagh MLA Phil Flanagan tweeted about Tom Elliott's appearance on a BBC radio program, questioning his involvement in the UDR and suggesting he harassed and shot people. Mr. Elliott served in the UDR between 1982 and 1992 and is now the MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone. The High Court heard that he has a clear MoD record. Flanagan deleted the tweet within an hour of posting it. He later apologized for the untrue and baseless comment. Mr. Justice Stevens reserved judgement on compensation. The insurance firm covering MLAs at Stormont refused to cover Flanagan for this case, leading him to challenge their decision in a separate court action. Mr. Elliott expressed disappointment in the time it took to resolve the issue but was ultimately vindicated by Flanagan's admission of falsehood.

Hawick Knitwear, a company with a history dating back to 1874 and currently employing over 230 staff, has increased its production of sweaters in response to higher demand. The company, bought by managing director Benny Hartop in November last year, has seen growth in both its private label business and the newly launched Hawick Knitwear-branded range. Production has risen from approximately 7,500 sweaters per week last year to 9,500 sweaters each week to meet demand. The company sells its products in Europe and other markets including the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being hit by Brian Wright's car outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright, 55, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see Mrs. Blackburn, who was escorting a woman and her daughter across the road. He denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving but has expressed remorse for his actions. The trial is ongoing.

The passage discusses a Nato exercise named "Dynamic Mongoose," which focuses on anti-submarine warfare and is aimed at countering the growing threat from Russian submarines. The exercise involves 10 Nato warships, including the Royal Navy Frigate HMS Portland, searching for a German U-boat acting as an unseen enemy. The exercise highlights a gap in Britain's defences, particularly the lack of maritime patrol aircraft, which used to be provided by the Nimrod. This vulnerability could allow Russian submarines to track the UK's nuclear deterrent as it leaves Faslane naval base in Scotland. The passage also mentions Russia's increasing military strength, with a fleet of around 60 submarines, and their advancements in submarine development.

The United Nations has warned that the violence in South Sudan could lead to genocide and ethnic cleansing. Since July, 340,000 people have fled to Uganda due to the escalating violence, making it the largest refugee crisis in the world this year. Ethnic violence has been a major factor in the conflict, with Dinka, Nuer, and Equatorians being targeted. Uganda is coping well with the influx of refugees but is beginning to struggle as nearly a million refugees have arrived. The UN is urging the international community to pressure South Sudanese leaders to stop the violence against civilians.

McKenzie, a former footballer turned professional boxer with a record of eight wins and one draw, will fight Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight championship at York Hall on 12 November. He is the son of former British and European champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The coalition is investing Â£330m in new NHS facilities across England, including a new Bridgwater Community Hospital with 30 inpatient beds, a maternity unit, minor injury unit, X-ray facilities, and space for mobile scanners. The current hospital, built in 1813, is cramped and outdated. The project costs Â£33m, with the remaining balance covered by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The new hospital aims to provide a more modern and comfortable environment for patients and staff. Planning permission is required for the construction on land at Bowers Lane, with a target completion date of autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe. He was found with a gunshot wound to his chest and later died at the Northern General hospital. The victim was in or near his black Mercedes when the shooting occurred. Local residents said the man was part of a family who were having a celebration nearby when the attack happened. There have been several shootings in Sheffield recently, but this is the first one in the Upperthorpe area.

The passage discusses the activities of various virtual warriors, including the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International. These groups engage in hacking and cyber warfare to gather information, disrupt their opponents' activities, and spread their message. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops focus on disrupting separatist funding and monitoring rebel movements in eastern Ukraine. Cyber Berkut is anti-Western and aims to thwart Ukraine's military plans. Anonymous International publishes leaked documents from the Kremlin and focuses on Russia's domestic affairs but also covers Ukraine.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick shed tears during farewell speeches by veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former first minister Alex Salmond, who are among those standing down as MSPs ahead of the May 5th election. Salmond used his valedictory address to emphasize that Scotland is diverse but not divided, and welcomed the transfer of powers to Holyrood under the Scotland Bill. He also joked about competing with a major attraction down south and wished everyone in the upcoming election good luck. McNeil warned that Holyrood could learn from Westminster's committee system and stressed the importance of accountability and scrutiny.

Older People's Commissioner for Wales Sarah Rochira is gathering experiences of residential care from pensioners and their families to create recommendations for care providers and public bodies. This is part of her review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She will highlight good care but also show the impact of poor care on older people. The review will consider factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Care providers, social care staff, and public bodies will also be consulted. The chair of Care Forum Wales, Mario Kreft, supports the review but feels that the advisory panel lacks representation from those with direct experience in managing or owning a care home.

Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, experienced an increase in pre-tax profit by Â£800,000 to Â£3.5m for the year ending June 2016, despite a decrease in turnover by Â£1m to Â£100m. The company's international sales grew in Europe and new markets. Harbro manufactures and supplies feeds for various sectors and operates 19 shops under the Country Store brand in Scotland. The outlook for agriculture is uncertain, but the company remains confident in its ability to face challenges such as Brexit.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, and another man in his 80s was taken to the hospital. Police are searching for 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, in connection with the death and warn people not to approach him. The investigation is ongoing, and anyone with information is urged to contact the police or Crimestoppers. Additional patrols have been conducted in the area to provide reassurance to residents.

David Lipton, the second in command at the IMF, spoke about global economic risks at a speech in Washington. He mentioned that the latest reading of the global economy shows a weakening baseline and that we are at a delicate juncture. This comes after weaker-than-expected trade figures from China showed exports plunging by a quarter from a year ago. The IMF is likely to downgrade its current forecast of 3.4% for global growth when it releases its economic predictions in April. This dismal picture has ongoing ramifications for businesses and industries that bet on China's growth story.

The council discussed problems with a new ferry, including breakdowns, groundings, and suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency. Council leader Dave Stewart announced that the crossing at Cowes would be free until 2 July for feedback and to address issues. A review of the project by auditors has been ordered. Local businesses are affected by the problems, and compensation is being considered. Councillor Ian Ward acknowledged teething problems but said they have been rectified.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday, resulting in a 32-year-old man's death. A 33-year-old man was arrested for causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook for investigation until early evening.

Matching Models, an international temp agency based in London, has been criticized for its advertisement of a personal assistant position requiring a "classic look" and specific cup size. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) called the ad "appalling, unlawful, and demeaning to women," while women's equality campaigners likened it to outdated 1970s practices. The EHRC plans to ask Matching Models for clarification on their hiring practices. Employment lawyer James Lynas stated that the ad is clearly unlawful and could lead to sex discrimination claims. Under the 2010 Equality Act, employers cannot discriminate based on factors such as age, sexual orientation, or disability. Matching Models founder Nathalie Jansen defended the ad by stating that clients have specific requirements related to appearance.

A shooting occurred at a hostel attached to the Pragati Residential School in Bangalore city, involving an office assistant named Mahesh. It is unclear what prompted the shooting, but Mahesh allegedly shot two students, one in the head and another who suffered severe injuries. He was arrested after a manhunt. Gun crime at schools and colleges in India is rare.

The advocacy group Glaad analyzed shows between June 2016 and May 2017, finding 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters. The number of transgender characters increased from seven to 16, but over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off. There is a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television due to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. Glaad's study is based on scripted broadcast, cable, and streaming series already being shown or for which casting has been confirmed.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced his decision to not seek re-election ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be opposed. This comes after criticism of his involvement in a loan to Northampton Town FC when he was leader of the borough council. About Â£10.25m of the public money loaned is missing and subject to a police investigation into alleged financial irregularities. The football stand remains half built. A majority of his party's local executive council said they would vote to deselect him.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old former police officer, fired a rifle into a car killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards in Balch Springs, Texas in April. The incident occurred during a response to reports of underage drinking at a house party. Initially, police claimed the vehicle reversed "aggressively" towards the officer, but footage discredited this claim. Oliver was fired for policy violations and charged with four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon by a public official. He faces five to 99 years in prison if convicted of murder. This would be the first police officer convicted of murder in Dallas County since 1973.

The president-elect's wife, Melania Trump, and their son Barron will move to Washington after the school year ends. Some people criticized this decision on social media, but others defended it. There have been other First Ladies in history who did not live in the White House during their husbands' presidencies, such as Martha Washington and Anna Harrison. Families have coped with moving to the White House in different ways in the past, and Melania has said that Barron is her top priority. The role of the First Lady is mainly ceremonial, but some have also taken on public roles and supported causes like education and anti-drug campaigns.

The man died in Inverness on 27 October. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc) is scrutinizing the initial police response to the man's call. Police Scotland is cooperating with the investigation, and a report on the commissioner's findings will be submitted to the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS).

The passage describes a yellow wind warning issued for several counties in the west of the mountains, with gusts up to 75mph possible due to an unusual easterly direction. This may cause disruption to travel on roads and at sea. A tree has already fallen due to the winds, closing a main route into Menai Bridge on Anglesey. Clean-up work is expected to keep the road closed for most of Monday.

The Giants won their opening game against the Panthers with a short-handed goal by Derrick Walser. Jeff Dimmen equalized for the Panthers in the first period. In the second period, Mike Forney scored a powerplay breakaway goal making it 2-1, but Andy Bohmback equalized soon after. Mike Radja and James Desmarais then scored for the Giants, making it 4-2. David Ling of Nottingham got one back before the end of the match. The two teams will face each other again on Saturday night in their second match of the double-header. Currently, Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 points and Belfast with 25 points.

World champion Lewis Hamilton started from the back of the grid, suffered a broken front wing on lap one, and did five pit stops in the Chinese Grand Prix. Despite his efforts, he faces a 36-point deficit in the remaining 18 races of the season. Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel came second after colliding with teammate Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap, while Raikkonen fought back to fifth place. The race was shaped by an incident-packed opening, leading to a safety car being introduced on lap four. Mercedes F1 boss Toto Wolff said Hamilton's car had lost a lot of aerodynamic performance due to damage from his collision with Sauber's Felipe Nasr.

In an interview, former German footballer Thomas Hitzlsperger publicly revealed his homosexuality to advance discussion on the topic in German football. He received support from fellow players and figures in German football administration, with some calling it a courageous step towards fighting homophobia. The announcement is seen as a significant moment in Germany's struggle with homophobia in football.

The passage discusses the achievements of Steve Sidwell, a 34-year-old midfielder who has played a significant role in helping Brighton & Hove Albion achieve promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years. With his contract set to expire, Sidwell expresses his desire to sign a new deal and continue playing for the team. He believes that with their recent success, they can stay in the top flight. Sidwell has previously played in the Premier League for various clubs such as Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham, and Stoke.

In a closely contested match, Blackpool and Colchester United ended with a 1-1 draw. The Seasiders took the lead in the first half with a goal from Jamille Matt, but Colchester equalized soon after. Both teams had chances to score a winning goal, but were denied by impressive saves from the respective goalkeepers. In injury time, Colchester's Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle, leaving the team to finish the game with 10 men.

The 29-year-old player previously made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season during their relegation from League One. He has played for other teams such as Charlton, Bradford, and Preston. He may make his debut for the U's in an upcoming EFL Cup first-round match against Aston Villa. Colchester recently suffered a 3-1 defeat against Accrington in their season opener. For football transfer updates, visit our dedicated page.

The murder of PC Keith Palmer in an attack outside the Houses of Parliament in March has led to a greater emphasis on the need for a permanent memorial. The UK Police Memorial Trust is appealing for Â£1.5m towards its construction at the National Memorial Arboretum, which will bear the names of over 1,400 officers and staff. The memorial, dedicated to the courage and sacrifice of fallen officers over the past 250 years, is expected to be completed by 2019. The government has committed Â£1m towards the Â£4m needed for its construction.

Manchester United won 1-0 against Sunderland, maintaining a 15-point lead at the top of the table with eight games left. Manager Ferguson focuses on upcoming matches and praises the team's record. Injuries occurred during the match, and changes are expected for the FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea.

The passage discusses Google's tax payments in the UK and its stance on taxation. Mr Schmidt, Google's chairman, states that the company follows the law and pays the legally required amount of taxes. He believes it is up to the government to change the tax system if they want companies to pay more. Google paid Â£10m in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011. Margaret Hodge, head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, suggests a new committee to oversee major firms' tax arrangements. Google has been criticized for organizing its tax affairs to minimize UK payments. EU leaders agreed to tackle tax avoidance through an "automatic information exchange between tax authorities." Mr Schmidt argues that corporate taxes should be levied where economic activity and risks occur, rather than where products are consumed, and calls for international tax reform.

NHS Improvement wants to reduce the agency bill by Â£1bn by the end of this financial year, as last year Â£3.6bn was spent on agency staff. A cap introduced in October has saved Â£600m so far, but hospitals are still 10% behind where they want to be. The aim is to reduce overall costs and reliance on agency staff, who are more expensive due to fees and employer costs. NHS Improvement plans to publish league tables of best and worst-performing trusts and collect information on the 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust.

The Longford Town Centre, once a symbol of the Celtic Tiger's economic growth in the Republic of Ireland, now stands as a reminder of the country's economic crash. Local traders, however, see signs of improvement with businesses like Matt O'Brien's men's clothing shop experiencing an increase in sales after a difficult period. Despite this, Fianna FÃ¡il criticizes the government's handling of the midlands region and calls for improvements in areas such as broadband. The government points to investments like the planned Center Parcs tourism development in Ballymahon as evidence of support for County Longford. However, local traders argue that more could be done to boost business, such as providing free parking in the town centre. Overall, while there are signs of economic recovery in the midlands, more efforts are needed to support local businesses and encourage growth.

The competition ends on May 29th and has eight teams competing in a round-robin format, with the top four advancing to the playoffs. BBC Sport provides coverage of scores, fixtures, and results. Four England players are participating: Eoin Morgan, Jos Buttler, Sam Billings, and Kevin Pietersen. Fixtures and results are provided with all times listed in BST.

The number of plastic carrier bags has increased by 200 million since 2013, causing environmental issues such as pollution in landfills and rivers. To address this problem, England will implement a 5p charge for plastic bags starting in October, following the example of supermarkets in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland that have already seen a decrease in bag usage due to similar charges. The goal is to encourage reuse and reduce the number of bags being thrown away, ultimately benefiting the environment.

A school roof was damaged and hundreds of homes experienced power cuts in Wales due to strong winds. Train delays, speed restrictions, and lane closures also occurred on major bridges. The winds were part of a yellow 'be aware' warning that lasted until midnight on Friday. Irish Ferries cancelled six fast sailings between Holyhead and Dublin, while Arriva Trains Wales warned of possible delays and speed restrictions. Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle were closed by the National Trust due to expected high winds. Winds eased in the evening, but a blustery forecast for the Christmas weekend led to the postponement of Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip.

Michael B. Jordan is excited to work with director Ryan Coogler again in the upcoming Black Panther film, and looks forward to working with co-stars Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman. Jordan previously played the Human Torch in Fantastic Four, while Nyong'o won a best supporting actress Oscar for 12 Years a Slave and played Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens. Black Panther is set to release in February 2018.

The theatre, founded in 1875, is set to be restored and used for various events such as theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music. The BBC studios will also be repaired and refurbished. If fundraising efforts are successful, the theatre aims to reopen in 2018 as part of a larger east wing restoration project to transform Alexandra Palace into a new cultural destination. The Heritage Lottery Fund (HLF) and Haringey Council are contributing Â£18.8m and Â£6.8m respectively towards the Â£26.6m project cost. The Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust have committed to raising the final Â£1m by summer 2017.

The passage discusses a former Manchester City player, aged 30, who won 61 caps for England between 2009 and 2016. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships but only played three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps since 2004. He scored his first and only international goal during the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers in a match against Moldova.

A house in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador caught fire, engulfing the entire building. Marcy Smith and her family were able to escape but their dog and cats did not survive. The fire was started by rubbish burned in a wood stove and the alarm did not go off. The community has since supported the family with donations. Marcy Smith is proud of her son David for waking them up and saving their lives.

The energy drinks company is considering a Â£200m offer for the Premier League club, which was valued at Â£105m when Sullivan and Gold bought a majority stake in 2010. They now own over 85% of the club and have been linked with takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups since moving to London Stadium in August. Last year, Sullivan mentioned the possibility of selling a minority shareholding to clear debts but intended for the ownership to eventually pass on to their children.

The passage describes a ceremony where fan-voted awards were given out, including best kiss and best shirtless performance. The Fault in Our Stars won best movie, with Shailene Woodley also winning best female performance and other awards. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for American Sniper, while Channing Tatum and Meryl Streep won awards for their comedic and villainous roles respectively. Other winners included Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, and Rose Byrne. Kevin Hart was honored with the comedic genius award, and Robert Downey Jr received the Generation Award with fellow Avengers stars presenting. Clips from upcoming movies were also shown during the event.

The passage discusses the loaning of a young football player named Smith, aged 21, from Dons to United in July. He has scored five goals this season and previously made his Aberdeen debut in 2012, scoring four times in 89 appearances for the Pittodrie side. St Mirren's boss Jack Ross praises Smith as a brilliant acquisition and believes he will be a good fit for the team, providing another option in the attacking area. St Mirren is set to host Falkirk on Saturday.

The Northumberland County Council is using Jetpatcher machines to fill 145 potholes daily for the next four months due to warm weather. Additionally, extra staff will repair damaged drainage systems and clear debris from gutters caused by heavy rain.

In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors working on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland were exposed to low levels of alpha radiation while removing pipework during shutdown activities. The workers were not wearing proper personal protective equipment and have since faced health concerns, including potential cancer risks. EnQuest claims the exposure was less than 1% of the reportable level and has taken additional precautionary steps. Wood Group maintains a commitment to employee safety and conducted medical assessments following the incident. The Health and Safety Executive was informed but did not investigate as the incident was not reportable under current regulations.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) bought a stolen bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 in 2007 from Art of the Past, which later admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities. The allegations were revealed during a 2012 court case against the firm for trafficking antiquities. The sculpture is believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India. After discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and India's Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), the ACM decided to return the sculpture. The ASI submitted an official request for its return in May. ACM will take legal action to seek compensation for the apparent fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca, Italy at a depth of 15.5km, with no immediate reports of injuries or damage. The tremor was felt in Milan and Florence, and several aftershocks were reported. Phone lines and power supplies were disrupted in the Garfagnana area, and schools were evacuated for safety checks. This earthquake serves as a reminder of Italy's vulnerability to seismic activity, as seen in the 2009 L'Aquila quake that killed nearly 300 people.

The passage describes a situation where Austin Grant from Sheffield had doubts about the suitability of South Yorkshire's climate for growing fruit. However, he has finally seen some positive results as the fruit is still attached to the plant and not yet ripe enough to eat. The 62-year-old grandfather expresses his excitement by saying he was "literally jumping for joy."

The game's release has been delayed until 24 March due to the need for extra testing and polish. Online heists will be available on consoles before the PC release date, with screenshots from the PC version showing greater detail and support for up to 4K resolution and triple monitor configurations. Minimum specifications required to run GTA V have also been published.

The 76-year-old artist, shortlisted in 1991, won the Â£25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his work Squint (19) at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. Judge Ansel Krut described the painting as "quite extraordinary" and "a little bit like a tone poem." The artwork depicts a leper squint, with Simpson explaining that it was one of a series of paintings he has been working on. The prize money will be spent on art materials. The biennial John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with previous winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig.

The daily Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit newspaper offices were attacked by four masked assailants. No casualties were reported, but the buildings' windows were shattered and spent bullet casings were found at both scenes. Both papers support President Erdogan's AK Party. Police have cordoned off the area and are searching for the attackers, but no group has claimed responsibility yet.

A 24-year-old football player, previously contracted with the Stags, is set to join Marcus Bignot's team on a free transfer. He played for Crawley on loan earlier this season, scoring three goals in 23 appearances. The former Burton player will officially become part of the Mariners on January 1st and is Bignot's first signing for the team.

The passage discusses ArsÃ¨ne Wenger's views on Gareth Southgate potentially becoming the permanent manager of the England national football team. Wenger, who is currently the manager of Arsenal, believes that Southgate has gained valuable experience and is a good observer of the national team's situation. Wenger focuses on his own job and does not directly address the rumors linking him to the role. Southgate will have a chance to prove his competency in the upcoming World Cup qualifier against Scotland and a friendly match against Spain. Additionally, Wenger mentions that Hector Bellerin and Aaron Ramsey are important players for Arsenal, with Bellerin being offered a new contract and Ramsey expected to miss one or two more games due to injury.

Summary: A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker around 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are conducting a joint inquiry, with the company's full cooperation.

The Transport Minister announced a new charter arrangement to resolve the seafarers' pay dispute on two freight boats. The RMT union claimed workers were paid less than Â£4 an hour, and the change will see contracted out services return to operator Serco Northlink. Seatruck, which operates the vessels, argued that the national minimum wage was not applicable to its non-UK resident crew members. Serco Northlink offered to bridge the pay gap but was declined by Seatruck. The new arrangements will be implemented next month, ensuring all crew members are paid at least the minimum wage.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in the hospital on May 14 after an incident at Rockley Park site in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted to intervening in an argument between Mr. Dickie and his mother. The trial revealed that Mr. Mitchell and Mrs. Mitchell had been in a relationship for years and were going through a rough patch when the incident occurred. On May 7, Mr. Mitchell accompanied his mother and Mr. Dickie to the holiday park bar and got intoxicated. A confrontation ensued between the two men, resulting in Mr. Mitchell pleading guilty to common assault. Both he and his mother also admitted to attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying about the events. They will be sentenced on February 6.

Rod Temperton, a renowned songwriter known for his work with Michael Jackson and Heatwave, has passed away at the age of 66 after a brief battle with cancer. Temperton wrote several hits for Jackson including Off The Wall, Rock With You, and Thriller. He also penned songs for other artists such as Anita Baker, Donna Summer, Aretha Franklin, and The Brothers Johnson. Temperton won a Grammy Award in 1990 and was nominated for two Oscars in 1986.

A team of researchers from Swansea University, the universities of Exeter and Reading, and Brazil's SÃÂ£o Paulo and BelÃ©m discovered over 450 ancient earthworks, or "geoglyphs," in the western Brazilian Amazon. The geoglyphs are possibly 2,000 years old and were concealed for centuries by bamboo-dominated rainforest until modern deforestation revealed them. The purpose of these sites is still unknown, but they are unlikely to be villages as few artifacts have been found during excavation. Researchers believe they may have been used sporadically as ritual gathering places. Dr. Neil Loader analyzed soil samples to reconstruct ancient vegetation and found that the geoglyphs were likely constructed amongst taller vegetation, not visible above the forest canopy. This challenges previous assumptions that the Amazonian forests were pristine ecosystems before the arrival of Europeans in the early 16th century. Instead, it appears humans transformed their environment by focusing on economically valuable trees such as palms, creating a "prehistoric supermarket" of useful

Australian tennis player Nick Kyrgios, ranked 12th in the world, won his match against Sam Querrey (world number 29) with a score of 6-4 6-4 in just 53 minutes. Despite his victory, Kyrgios admitted to being bored and tired during the match, attributing it to fatigue from winning the Japan Open and the travel involved in reaching the Qi Zhong Stadium in Shanghai. Last year, Kyrgios was fined $1,500 for an outburst at the same tournament.

The passage discusses the push for the human papilloma virus (HPV) vaccine to be extended to boys in Wales, as it is currently only given to girls aged 12 and 13 to protect against cervical cancer. Scientists and charities argue that the vaccine can also protect against head and neck cancers, which are increasingly affecting younger people, particularly men. The Welsh government is waiting for advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making a decision on whether to extend the vaccination program.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old suffering from a rare form of blood cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, passed away. He had been documenting his life and treatment on social media under the page "Jak's Journey" and gained support from thousands of people in West Lothian and beyond. Jak briefly attended his school prom but left due to feeling unwell. His family collected awards on his behalf at the event. Despite receiving news that his cancer had spread throughout his body and doctors deciding not to pursue further treatment, Jak remained positive and continued to share his experiences with others. In honor of Jak, a special football match will be held to raise money for charity.

In a closely contested match, Egypt managed to secure a 1-0 victory over Uganda with a late goal from Abdallah El Said, assisted by Mohamed Salah. The win means Egypt will face Ghana in their next match, while Uganda is out of the tournament.

Lancashire County Council has identified land at the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for potential development. The council, in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, plans to establish a railway station in Skelmersdale, which could provide two direct trains per hour to Liverpool. The decision follows a comparative study of sites near the Concourse shopping center. The selected location is large enough for future expansion and offers good highway access and connectivity. The authority will now begin acquiring the necessary land.

Summary:
Plants were discovered in an elaborate grow house during a warehouse search near Ashbourne on Saturday. A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

A 28-year-old woman in Hamelin, Lower Saxony was found with serious injuries after being dragged by the neck through several streets.
