If the lease is extended, the property could be worth over Â£6 million. The flat is being sold by Russell Simpson and is one of two maisonettes being sold with short leases. Both properties require modernization and are offered at prices comparable to renting a three-bedroom flat in the area. The current freeholder is thought to be the Welcome Trust, and any buyer would need to negotiate a lease extension with them.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage affecting 8,000 stores in the US and Canada, causing baristas to give away free drinks. The outage lasted from the early evening on the East Coast to the late afternoon on the West Coast. The company resolved the issue and expects stores to open for business as usual on Saturday. The cause of the outage was not explained, but it disrupted sales at company-operated stores. Some customers took advantage of the situation by getting free drinks and baked goods.

Terrorists are training in rural areas of West Wales, including Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, to radicalize Muslims. The area is also used by the British military for training due to its rugged terrain. Incidents of Islamic extremist activity in Wales can be traced back to 1998 when Abu Hamza sent a group of extremists to train in the Brecon Beacons. Community intelligence is vital for authorities to prevent such activities.

A rare Omura's whale, previously feared to be extinct, was found on a remote beach in Western Australia after tropical cyclone Olwyn. This is the first sighting of the species in WA and only the second in Australia. The juvenile female was initially difficult to identify, but was confirmed with DNA profiling. The find is significant for scientists as little is known about the species, which was only described in scientific journals in 2003. Omura's whales are usually found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan.

The passage discusses the role of hormones in presidential candidates, focusing on the belief that female hormones may make a woman unfit for presidency. Cheryl Rios, CEO of Go Ape Marketing, argues that women should not be president due to their hormones potentially causing irrational decisions and starting unnecessary wars. The article also highlights studies showing that women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks than male counterparts, and points out the historical impairment of some male leaders' decision-making due to male hormones. However, it emphasizes that the bias against women in the workplace is a more significant concern, as it limits their potential regardless of biochemistry or ability. The article calls for an end to gender bias and promotes equality in leadership roles for both men and women, citing benefits such as better company performance and stronger families.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy is selling his collection of over 200 antiques in a Â£100,000 auction due to downsizing his home. The star, known for his roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and as Winston Churchill in several productions, has collected items throughout his career. Hardy, 89, is an expert on the medieval longbow and studied English with J.R.R. Tolkien. Among the items being auctioned are a diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, paintings, furniture, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, and crystal chandeliers. The auction will take place at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire on Saturday.

Michael Scott Shemansky is a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, and has been on the run from police since Saturday. He failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother's body was found at their shared home in Winter Garden, Florida. An initial investigation determined there was foul play. Shemansky is already on parole for battery on law enforcement, has a history of bipolar mental illness, and was involuntarily committed to a psychiatric ward for an attempted suicide. His wife filed a domestic violence injunction against him two years ago. Neighbors believe the stress of divorce proceedings may have pushed him over the edge. Authorities have the murder weapon but have not yet confirmed how Sandra Shemansky was killed. Anyone with information about his whereabouts is urged to contact authorities.

The city of Eugene in the United States has been chosen to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships without a bidding process due to a unique strategic opportunity for the first-time hosting in the USA. Eugene previously failed to secure the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha. IAAF President Lamine Diack stated that this decision allows for taking advantage of a rare opportunity with support from public authorities, private sector, national Olympic committee, NBC, and an enthusiastic public.

Aspiring model Leonie Granger was jailed for 16 years for luring professional gambler Mehmet Hassan to his death in order to steal his winnings. Granger befriended Hassan after spotting him with a roll of Â£50 notes at a casino in London's West End. She used her good looks to gain his trust and he showered her with gifts, cash, and trips to fancy restaurants. After going back to Hassan's flat one night, Granger left the door unlocked so her boyfriend and an accomplice could enter and rob him. They tied up Hassan, kicked him to death, and ransacked his home looking for his hidden winnings. Granger was found guilty of manslaughter by a majority verdict, while her co-defendants were found guilty of murder and given life sentences with a minimum term of 36 years.

The passage discusses the declining performance of Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas, particularly in the second half of the season. Fabregas has been struggling in recent games, including a poor performance in Spain's 2-0 defeat by Holland. Despite his initial success with Chelsea and being on track to break the Barclays Premier League record for assists around Christmas, his form has significantly dipped. With nine games left in the season, Chelsea is still set to face six opponents that Fabregas has previously provided goals against. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho will be demanding more from him in the remaining games as his role in the team's title charge seems to have declined lately.

West Ham is in talks to sign 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, who impressed during a trial with the club. Beckford, who has also received offers from Belgian clubs, is considered one of the top prospects from the Caribbean. West Ham plans to have the cheapest season tickets at their new Olympic Stadium, priced as low as Â£289, to attract fans for their 2016-17 season.

The police have dropped an investigation into a vicious assault on a huntsman, Mike Lane, despite having a wealth of evidence pointing to the identity of the suspected attacker. The incident occurred during a hunt when balaclava-clad protesters attacked Lane with iron bars on ropes. A video of the incident and a dossier of evidence were given to Wiltshire Police, but they have stopped the investigation due to insufficient evidence. Hunt supporters across the country are dismayed by the failure to identify, charge or prosecute anyone involved in the attack.

Adam Gadahn, an American citizen and prominent member of al Qaeda, was killed in a U.S. government counterterrorism operation in January. He was known as the "American mouthpiece" for the terrorist organization and had risen to become its chief official English-language propagandist. Gadahn converted to Islam in 1995 and left the United States for Pakistan three years later. He appeared in numerous al Qaeda videos threatening attacks on Western targets and urging Muslims to target American, Western, and Jewish interests. In 2006, he was indicted for treason and material support to al Qaeda.

A five-year-old Chinese boy named Mai Zizhuo has become an internet sensation due to his impressive basketball skills. Mai started shooting hoops at the age of two and a half and is now able to dribble two basketballs simultaneously while maintaining perfect rhythm. His talent has gained him many fans in China, where basketball is very popular. Some viewers have expressed disbelief and even shame over their own basketball abilities compared to Mai's.

Tom O'Carroll, a former member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), has joined the media pressure group Hacked Off. PIE campaigned to legalize child sex in the 1970s and 80s. O'Carroll attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off was set up after the phone-hacking scandal and is campaigning against what it sees as the "biased and unfair" Independent Press Standards Organisation. It wants MPs to establish a statutory body to regulate the press, as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry.

Bondi's Icebergs Club pool was emptied and used as a catwalk for the Ten Pieces presentation during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The unisex collection, designed by Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss, consists of ten pieces that can be worn in 20 different ways and is suitable for day to night wear. The event took place on an unusually warm day with guests enjoying views of the ocean and treats from Icebergs and Santa Vittoria.

Amir Khan, a boxer from Bolton, spent his Friday at a safari park in Northern California with his family. He posed with and fed a rare white tiger, as well as giraffes and sea lions at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom. Khan announced earlier this week that he will fight former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation about a potential match with British rival Kell Brook.

A Palestinian teenager's name, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, was removed from an Israeli memorial commemorating fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism after his family and others complained. Abu Khdeir, 16, was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July. His family objected to his inclusion on the memorial wall, stating that they did not give permission for his name to be listed among "soldiers of the occupation." Almagor, an organization working on behalf of victims of terror in Israel, also opposed Abu Khdeir's inclusion and demanded his name be removed from the memorial. Following complaints from the teen's father, the National Insurance Institute of Israel agreed to remove his name from the memorial.

A young boy chases his cat around the garden, using its belly as a pillow to rest his head. The cat eventually gets up and moves away, with the boy following and repeating the action. The cat finally has enough and goes indoors. Later, the boy is seen feeding the cat treats as they make up.

A police corruption trial in Philadelphia involves over a dozen former drug dealers, including witness Robert Kushner, testifying about alleged police wrongdoing. Kushner lost his coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after revealing his marijuana-selling past during his testimony. Despite passing a background check when hired in 2010, the school terminated his employment after learning of his history. Kushner believes he is innocent of the 2011 charges and regrets his past actions. The trial includes six former drug squad officers accused of racketeering, with lawyers claiming the government's case relies on lies from 19 drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

An explosion at a chemical plant in China's Fujian province injured six people and caused a large fire. The plant, which produces paraxylene (PX), a potentially carcinogenic chemical used in polyester production, had previously been relocated due to pollution concerns. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility after an oil leak, but no toxic chemical spill has been reported. More than 600 firefighters were sent to control the blaze, which is now under control.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa teenager, is known for wearing his socks low during games due to superstition and has no plans to change. Despite some referees advising him to pull his socks up, he continues the practice after making his first Premier League start. Grealish wears children's shinpads and believes this superstition has helped him avoid injuries. He made his first league start in a 3-3 draw against QPR and is glad to have gotten it out of the way. The Republic of Ireland Under 21 international is hoping for more starts before the end of the season and appreciates the trust his manager has placed in him.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has global and irreversible brain damage according to her grandmother Cissy Houston. Despite no longer being in a medically induced coma, she remains unresponsive with no signs of improvement. The family is hoping for a miracle and trusting in God. Bobby Brown recently announced that his daughter had improved and was awake, but the attorney for the Brown family later clarified that while she has made progress, the quality of her life remains uncertain as she embarks on a long rehabilitation process.

Russia is close to making the Fed Cup final with a 2-0 lead after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to beat Germany's Sabine Lisicki. Svetlana Kuznetsova also beat Julia Goerges in straight sets. Both players struggled with their serves, but Lisicki's 63 unforced errors were crucial. Russia needs one win from Sunday's three matches to reach the final and secure their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales are warned to prepare for more floods and damage as another storm is predicted to hit the region later this week. Meteorologists suggest an east coast low, similar to the weather system that caused wild weather last week, could bring heavy rain from Thursday through to Saturday. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned that more storms will hamper clean-up efforts, with over 4,000 jobs from the 24,196 requests still to be completed. The SES is particularly worried about the effect of more wild weather on the hard-hit Hunter region.

Nina Moric, a model who appeared in Ricky Martin's music video for "La Vida Loco," denied Italian media reports that she attempted suicide and clarified that she collapsed due to low blood pressure. She posted photos of her injuries on Instagram and explained that she was treated in the hospital after a domestic accident. Moric expressed shock at the suicide claims and assured her followers that she is recovering well. In 2009, Italian media also reported that Moric had tried to take her own life after overdosing.

The British public hopes Kate and William will choose a traditional name for their second child, with Diana being the favorite if it's a girl. Alice and Charlotte were the next preferred names. If it's a boy, 13% prefer James and 25% hope for a female baby. Most people support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave.

A suicide bomber killed 17 people and wounded dozens more in eastern Afghanistan on Thursday. The attack occurred near a group of protesters, including an Afghan lawmaker, who were on their way to join a larger rally against the provincial governor. The Taliban denied responsibility for the attack, and no other organization has claimed responsibility so far.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. The Brazilian right-back has spent seven successful years at the club, winning four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice. However, he has been unable to agree on a new deal with the Catalan club and will depart from the Nou Camp. Alves' agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that her client rejected a three-year contract extension dependent on participating in 60% of matches for the club. Negotiations are now over, and it seems unlikely that Barcelona will renew Dani's contract.

Pablo Osvaldo, a player for Boca Juniors, wants Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentinian club. He believes they would be a good fit and that the fans would love them. Osvaldo has played with many great players and considers Pirlo and Totti his friends. He thinks their style of play is well-suited for Boca Juniors and that the fans would be very excited to have them on the team.

The passage describes an 18-year-old amateur jockey named Lewis Ferguson who experienced a spectacular fall from his horse, Merrion Square, during a race at Wincanton. Despite the dramatic incident, which has gained significant attention online, Ferguson only suffered a cut on his nose and is undeterred from riding again. He recounts the experience and the reactions of fellow jockeys, and jokes about possibly pursuing a gymnastics career after racing.

The new Avengers movie, Age of Ultron, premiered at Westfield London shopping center with fans excited to see the A-list cast including Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth, and Scarlett Johansson. London Wasps rugby captain James Haskell joined in on the hype by dressing up as Iron Man and posting a photo on Instagram. He played for Wasps from 2002 to 2009 before moving to Stade Francais in France, Ricoh Black Rams in Japan, and Highlanders in New Zealand. After returning to England in 2012, Haskell has surpassed 100 appearances for Wasps and became an important part of the England squad with 57 caps so far.

The wide leg trouser is a growing trend for SS15, offering an alternative to the skinny jean. It can be styled with high heels and a simple top to elongate the legs and create a flattering look. Denim is an easy way to achieve this trend, with Gucci and Topshop offering their versions of flared jeans. Celine and Stella McCartney showcased dressier styles perfect for evening wear. Finery London offers a similar style at a lower price point. This trend can update your wardrobe and doesn't require nice weather.

The University of Michigan will screen "American Sniper" despite objections from some students. Over 200 students signed a petition against the movie, but there was also a counter-petition asking for reconsideration. The university's vice president for student life stated that canceling the movie was a mistake and that it goes against their values of freedom of expression and respect for students' choices. A family-friendly alternative, "Paddington," will be offered for those who do not want to attend "American Sniper."

Two French tourists, aged 18 and 24, were evicted from Rottnest Island in Western Australia after allegedly setting a quokka alight with an aerosol spray and lighter. The incident occurred on April 3, and the quokka survived but was singed by the flame. The men have been charged with animal cruelty and will appear in court on April 17. Quokkas are small Australian animals, similar in size to domestic cats, and can be found on some islands off the west coast of Australia, including Rottnest Island and Bald Island near Albany.

A 102-year-old former dancer, Alice Barker, who performed at famous New York nightspots in the 1930s and 1940s, was shown her own performances for the first time with the help of filmmakers and volunteers.

A new study by vehicle leasing firm OSV reveals that the tradition of washing one's own car on Sundays is dying out in Britain, with a third of men admitting they have never done it. Factors contributing to this decline include shops opening on Sundays, more live football on TV, and the rise of hand car washes. Only 12% of those who do wash their cars regularly do it themselves. Brits are more likely to wash their cars during holidays, with an estimated 15 million cars cleaned by their owners over Easter.

Martin Skrtel praises Steven Gerrard's impact on him and Liverpool since joining in 2008, but believes the team can overcome his departure. Gerrard is set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, aiming to lead Liverpool to the final against Arsenal. If successful, Gerrard will sign off his Anfield career before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel considers Gerrard one of the best players in the world and acknowledges that it will be different without him at Liverpool. However, he believes potential replacements exist within the team and with proper support, they can fill Gerrard's void. Both Gerrard and Skrtel may return for the match against Aston Villa after serving three-match bans for violent conduct.

Jack Nicklaus, at 75 years old, hit a hole-in-one during the par-3 contest at Augusta National. This was his first ace on that course and it happened while playing with Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. The crowd cheered as Nicklaus held up his ball in celebration. Although Camilo Villegas also made two aces that day, he lost in a play-off to Kevin Streelman. Nicklaus is one of five men to complete the career grand slam and won his sixth green jacket in 1986.

On Wednesday night, tornado sirens sounded in Kansas as multiple storms brought reports of twisters. Spotters reported a tornado about 6 miles northwest of Goddard, which is less than 17 miles west of Wichita. The storm moved northeast, missing the city but posing potential risks to other communities. Severe weather expert Chad Myers warned that nighttime tornadoes are the most deadly and dangerous. Other reports of tornadoes came from southwestern Kansas, and a possible tornado touched down in Potosi, Missouri. Storms are expected to continue in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

An Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, Robert Bates, accused of fatally shooting a man he intended to subdue with a taser has pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter. The judge granted Bates permission to go on a family vacation to the Bahamas, which prompted a response from the victim's family expressing their surprise and disappointment. Bates' preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2. He claims the shooting was accidental and has apologized to the victim's family. The victim's family lawyer alleges that Bates received preferential treatment due to donations and friendship with the sheriff, while the Tulsa County Sheriff's Office denies these allegations.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo on July 11. He has revealed a new tiger tattoo on his stomach and claims to have greater motivation to win the title than Aldo, who he says lacks the same drive. The two fighters have a contentious relationship, as evidenced by an incident in Dublin where McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt during a promotional tour.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott skolled a beer at an Australian rules function, drawing criticism from anti-drinking campaigners who argue that he is glorifying binge drinking and associating masculinity with alcohol consumption. Cultural studies professor Julie Robert claims that the Prime Minister should advocate against binge drinking instead of showcasing his masculinity by skolling a beer. Critics say that this performance perpetuates the stereotype that heavy drinking is necessary to be a true blue Aussie bloke. Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott's actions, stating there was nothing wrong with his behavior.

Indiana has seen a significant increase in HIV cases, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary positive cases tied to Scott County. The cases have risen from 106 last week, and health officials expect the number to continue increasing as more people are tested. The outbreak has occurred among intravenous drug users and primarily involves the use of the high-powered painkiller Opana. Governor Mike Pence approved a short-term needle exchange program on March 26, which has provided 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants so far. The future of the Scott County program and needle exchange programs in other counties remains uncertain, as legislation is still being debated.

A girlfriend took a test about her boyfriend's favorite football club, Arsenal, and scored 43.5 out of 50. He was impressed and decided not to dump her because of her good grade. The test had multiple choice questions, tables to complete, and sections where she had to answer in her own words. She got some answers wrong but still received an 'A' grade from her boyfriend. Some people thought the boyfriend went too far with the test, while others found it funny and inspiring.

Carlos Toro, a former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel, worked as an undercover informant for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for US citizenship. After fleeing Colombia and providing information on his former bosses and associates, he became one of the DEA's strongest assets, helping with undercover stings worldwide. Despite his contributions, Toro was never granted citizenship and now faces deportation back to Colombia due to declining health forcing him into retirement. He fears for his life if returned to Colombia and has not received help from the DEA regarding his citizenship.

A 14-year-old girl in India was allegedly gang-raped by five men from her village and then set herself on fire, resulting in 70% burns. The incident occurred when she went outside to relieve herself. Her family reportedly told her to keep quiet about the attack. The accused men have been arrested. This case highlights the heightened sensitivity to the issue of sexual assault in India, following recent protests and incidents of vigilante justice.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal has ruled out Robin van Persie for the upcoming derby against Manchester City due to fitness concerns. Van Gaal expressed his desire to finish as high as second or third in the league, which would help the team avoid a Champions League qualifying fixture. He emphasized the importance of controlling aggression during the match and acknowledged that City will provide a tough challenge. Additionally, he does not consider Luke Shaw fit enough to play. Despite these setbacks, Van Gaal is looking forward to experiencing the atmosphere at Old Trafford during his first Manchester derby as manager.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested against high ticket prices by leaving their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of a Premier League match. The protest was organized by fan groups from both clubs, who are disgusted with the continuous rise of ticket prices. Banners were displayed inside and outside the stadium, with one reading "Â£5bn and what do we get? Â£64 a ticket." The cheapest tickets for the match started at Â£64, which is considered one of the highest prices in the Premier League. Fans hope to raise awareness of the struggles they face in meeting the rising costs of following their clubs.

A newborn baby with a life-threatening liver condition called biliary atresia was saved after receiving a transplant from her mother's twin sister. The baby, named Star, was diagnosed shortly after birth and underwent an operation to unblock her bile ducts. However, doctors determined that she needed a liver transplant to survive. Her maternal aunt, Shanell, offered part of her liver and successfully saved her niece's life. Biliary atresia affects about 1 in 16,000 babies and can lead to liver failure and death if left untreated. Star has since made a good recovery and will continue to receive anti-rejection medication for the rest of her life.

Chelsea footballers Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian participated in Audi's football challenge. They competed in various tasks such as shooting balls into a car boot, playing "tennis" with an Audi R8 as the net, and aiming for convertible Audis from long range. Hazard and Ake won most of the challenges, but Remy and Willian had a surprise win in the final game. However, Willian accidentally smashed the wing mirror off one of the cars during their victory.

A former Fortune 500 executive, Robert Dellinger, caused a highway crash in 2013 that killed a Vermont couple and their unborn baby. He claimed during his sentencing that he was not suicidal at the time of the accident. Prosecutors alleged that Dellinger, who held high-level positions at various companies, told investigators he was trying to kill himself when he drove his pickup truck across a median at over 100mph and collided with an oncoming SUV. The crash instantly killed 24-year-old Amanda Murphy, who was eight months pregnant, and her fiancÃ©, 29-year-old Jason Timmons. Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault for the fetus' death and now faces 12 to 24 years in prison.

Lacey Spears, convicted of second-degree murder for poisoning her five-year-old son with salt, received a 20-year sentence instead of the maximum 25 years to life. The boy's father, Chris Hill, expressed his anger on Facebook and requested that she be placed in general population. Prosecutors argued that Spears had a bizarre need for attention and loaded her son's feeding tube with a lethal amount of salt while continuing to blog. Her lawyer plans to appeal the verdict, claiming innocence and blaming the hospital for negligence.

An improved influenza vaccine arriving in Australia this month includes protection against two new strains, H3N2 and B/Phuket, which caused a spike in flu-related deaths in Europe and the US. The delayed arrival of the vaccine was due to its modification to better match the circulating strains. High-risk groups can access free government-funded flu shots from April 20, and experts recommend everyone gets vaccinated. Dr. Alan Hampson emphasizes the importance of protecting high-risk individuals and their contacts.

The caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are defending the site against an unflattering critique in National Geographic magazine and potential budget cuts that could affect its management. Illinois faces a financial crisis, and Governor Bruce Rauner has proposed eliminating the state historic preservation agency that manages the tomb. The tomb has recently undergone over $2.5 million in repairs and renovations, but its future remains uncertain due to funding cuts and a possible relocation within another department.

The passage discusses various fashion trends from the nineties and noughties that are making a comeback or should be left in the past. These trends include chokers, berry-colored lips, round sunglasses, Calvin Klein logo t-shirts, JNCO jeans, bucket hats, camouflage print, taking trends to the extreme, UGG boots, daisy dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outerwear, and harem pants. The passage also highlights celebrities who have embraced these trends then and now.

The passage covers various trending stories, including four rainbows appearing in the sky after heavy rain in the New York area, a crackdown on exotic dancers performing at wakes in rural China, and actor Ewan McGregor being cast as Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast'. Additionally, it mentions the Kardashians inspiring a new lip-plumping trend, 102-year-old Alice Barker revisiting her past with help from filmmakers, and Johnny Depp's transformation in the 'Black Mass' trailer. Lastly, there is a mention of unique ways people announced their pregnancy and a military dad photobombing his son.

The Miami Open saw Serena Williams celebrate her 700th career victory with a giant cake, following Andy Murray's similar celebration for his 500th win. Williams advanced to the semi-finals after defeating Germany's Sabine Lisicki in a closely contested match. Despite her elder sister Venus's defeat to Spain's Carla Suarez Navarro, Serena remained focused on staying alive in the tournament. She is set to face Romania's Simona Halep in the semi-finals after Halep beat Sloane Stephens.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani human rights activist and founder of a cafe in Karachi known for promoting free speech and progressive values, was killed by two gunmen. She had just finished leading a discussion on the topic of Balochistan, a province where separatists have fought an insurgency for years and people have been disappearing regularly. Despite receiving death threats in the past, Mahmud continued to advocate for open discussion on this issue. Her death has sparked grief and gratitude for her work on social media and via email.

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu traditional healer and refugee, has been living in Indian Kashmir for 70 years without citizenship rights. He and thousands like him hope that their refugee status will change after the Hindu nationalist party won a share of power in India's only Muslim-majority state. The West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) have been denied the right to own property or vote in state elections, leaving three generations trapped in poverty. The Bharatiya Janata Party is expected to champion their cause, but activists warn they are ready to take matters into their own hands if their hopes are dashed again.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is considering a move to Chelsea this summer, according to club president Naoki Ogane. Chelsea has reportedly made an offer of around Â£4 million for the Japanese international, with plans to loan him to partner club Vitesse Arnhem next season. Muto is looking for a team where he can play regularly and develop his potential. Real Zaragoza boss Ranko Popovic, who gave Muto his debut in 2013, believes the player could be a success at Stamford Bridge due to his intelligence and confidence. Chelsea's transfer policy is influenced by commercial interests, including a recent Â£200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese tyre manufacturer Yokohama Rubber.

Australia has changed their policy and will now select their best players regardless of where they play, while England still has a policy of not selecting overseas players. This puts England at risk of being seen as old-fashioned and may affect their performance in the World Cup. Players like Matt Giteau and Steffon Armitage have improved since moving overseas and should be considered for selection. The success of a home World Cup depends on picking the best team, and restrictive policies should not prevent this from happening.

The Firechat app allows users to chat with friends without the need for a web or mobile signal, using wireless mesh networks. Open Garden has now developed Greenstone, an egg-shaped device that acts as a beacon or booster to help messages move more easily within these networks. Greenstone is designed to extend the range of off-the-grid networks and could be useful in situations where resilient communication is needed, such as music festivals, protests, and football matches. Currently under development, Greenstone only works with Firechat at a range of around 20ft (6 meters) but can hold up to 1,000 of the most recent messages and has a one-year battery life.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer from New Jersey, gave a TED talk about body positivity and embracing the word "fat" as an honest description of her physique. She believes that society has programmed women to avoid using the word "fat" because it is often associated with negativity and ugliness. Lillian encourages exposure to body diversity, stating that it leads to tolerance, acceptance, and even preference for different body types. Her performances aim to change perceptions by showcasing a fuller figure in a positive and glamorous way. Since her TED talk in 2014, she has received mostly positive feedback, including messages of gratitude and personal stories from people who have been inspired by her message.

Theo Walcott and six Arsenal teammates, including Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, and Mesut Ozil, were photographed for an official portrait with model Olga Sherer for Lanvin, Paris' oldest fashion house and Arsenal's official tailor since 2013. Walcott has spent much of the season on the bench and hopes to make his first start since March 14 in Arsenal's upcoming match against Hull.

A collection of props and puppets created by make-up effects artist Rick Baker will be auctioned off on May 29th, with an estimated value of $746,100. The collection includes items from popular films such as Men in Black, Batman Forever, How the Grinch Stole Christmas, An American Werewolf in London, Planet of the Apes, and more. Some individual items are expected to fetch over $40,000, including the Alien Edgar Bug from Men in Black and the Two Face mask from Batman Forever.

A seven-year-old British boy, Carwyn Scott-Howell, was killed in a skiing accident in the French Alps. He had become separated from his family and ventured into dense woodland where he fell over a 164ft drop. His body was found by police following footprints in the snow. Carwyn was described as a daring, outgoing, and determined youngster who loved skiing and snowboarding. His family expressed their devastation and the vast void left in their hearts by his passing. The community is rallying behind the family, who are well known for their award-winning farm shop.

A 15-year-old girl named Laura Scurr from Whitley Bay became obsessed with having the perfect figure and developed anorexia. She survived on just one piece of fruit a day, hid food, and lied to her mother about eating. Her dramatic weight loss led to her collapsing at home and being rushed to intensive care. After spending a week on a heart monitor, Laura received support from eating disorder organizations and began her recovery. She spoke about the pressures she felt to be thin and the idea that girls should be a size zero. Today, Laura's body image is better than ever, and her confidence has allowed her to make it to the semi-final of Miss Teen GB, a competition that promotes positive and confidence-building experiences for young girls away from size zero stereotypes.

Liverpool supporters told Raheem Sterling that they expect him to remain at the club during a kit launch event. The new home kit, designed by New Balance, is the first offering from the US sports brand who signed a record-breaking Â£300 million four-year deal with Liverpool. Despite rejecting a new contract and expressing interest in Arsenal, Liverpool insists Sterling will not be leaving this summer. Fans showed their support for Sterling during the event, and he expressed his appreciation for their backing.

The University of Manchester has produced the largest single high-definition map of dark matter, covering 0.4% of the sky. The map was created using data from the Dark Energy Camera and will eventually allow a 3D view of dark matter across one eighth of the night sky. The goal is to map 12.5% over five years, with red showing more dark matter and blue showing less. The map should help astronomers study how galaxies formed in the universe.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven's 21-year-old star Memphis Depay. The Dutch international is a target for United manager Louis van Gaal, who has previously worked with Depay in the Holland national team during the 2014 World Cup. Premier League rivals Tottenham were interested in signing Depay last summer but their Â£15 million offer was rejected by PSV. Now, it appears that United are in pole position to land the player, despite competition from other European clubs like Paris Saint-Germain. Depay has scored an impressive 20 goals in 26 league games this season and is considered a promising talent, with some comparing him to Dutch star Arjen Robben.

Chelsea took a 3-1 lead in the first half with goals from Tammy Abraham and Dominic Solanke, securing their victory against Manchester City's young side. The youngsters put up a strong fight, with performances from Kjetil Haug, Pablo Maffeo, and Toisin Adarabioyo. Despite efforts from Aaron Nemane and Bersant Celina, they were unable to find the back of the net. Chelsea's defense, led by Jake Clarke-Salter and Fikayo Tomori, effectively nullified City's attack.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate, believes people are born with a sexual preference but thinks the definition of marriage should be between a man and a woman. He doesn't believe same-sex marriage is a constitutional right and states should decide on the matter through political debate. Rubio would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer even if he didn't agree with their decision. As a Catholic, he believes divorce is wrong but wouldn't stop loving someone who is divorced.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a Spanish-Latvian couple, are cycling around the world with no plans or agenda. They have covered 7,000 miles across 16 countries in their first year of travel, living on less than three euros each per day. The couple relies on free accommodation, using hosting websites like Couchsurfing and Warmshowers, and occasionally camping under the stars. Food is their only major expense, costing just 2.74 euros each per day. Their journey began in London and has taken them through Europe and into Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia. They plan to continue into Asia and cycle the length of the American continent.

A couple from Texas hired a photo booth for their 2012 wedding, which allegedly printed a racial slur on the bottom of some photographs. The couple's attorney, Cathy Hale, is suing James Evans, owner of Premiere Photos, under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act for negligence and breach of contract. The couple did not wish to be identified and was not alerted of the photos until months after the celebration. Evans denies all allegations and claims there is no evidence linking his company to the offensive caption. Mediation is scheduled for tomorrow morning, with a trial set for July if an agreement is not reached.

England full-back Mike Brown is taking a cautious approach to his recovery from a concussion setback, uncertain about when he will return to play for Harlequins. Northampton wing George North has been advised by medics not to play again this season after suffering four quick-fire concussions, while Ireland's Johnny Sexton was stood down for 12 weeks earlier this term. Brown hopes to avoid an extended break and is being cautious not to rush back to action. He credits increased awareness of concussion symptoms, gained through online modules, for helping him make the decision to pull out of the Ireland game.

The passage discusses the possible link between smartphone use and a decline in sexual activity among couples. Research has shown that the frequency of sex among Britons has decreased since the emergence of the internet, with a typical heterosexual couple now having sex three times a month, compared to four times a month in 2000 and five times a month in 1990. Professor David Spiegelhalter suggests that the integration of public and private lives, as well as busier lives due to better technological connectivity, are contributing factors to this decline.

The passage discusses the decline in popularity of Tibetan Mastiffs in China, which were once considered status symbols and could command prices of up to Â£1.2 million each. The dramatic decline is attributed to the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several cities, and the realization that the breed is not well-suited for city living. As a result, Tibetan Mastiffs are being sent to slaughterhouses and their meat used in cheap hotpots. Unscrupulous breeders and gangs are also contributing to the problem by selling "imperfect" specimens and stolen dogs to slaughterhouses.

A survey of 600 women in the Paris area found that every woman had experienced some form of sexual harassment on public transport, with half experiencing it before they were 18 years old. The types of harassment ranged from insults and intimidating behavior to sex attacks and rape. As a result, six out of ten women were afraid of being attacked on public transport compared to three out of ten men. This issue limits women's freedom as they often have to change their routes, modes of transportation, schedules, attitudes, and clothing to avoid confrontation. The report calls for a campaign to address sexist or threatening behavior on buses and trains to ensure women can move about and occupy public space without fear.

A company called Direct Line ran a competition called #everydayfix, where groups designed products to solve common problems. They asked people to pick their top ten "everyday emergencies" and then asked London-based design company Makerversity to create products to alleviate certain emergencies. The top three products were Snooze, an alarm clock that connects with your phone to silence notifications for a good night's sleep; Forget Me Lock, a device that shows whether your door is locked or not by swiveling green for open and red for locked; and Nipper, the world's smallest mobile phone charger that uses any household battery as its energy source. People can vote for their favorite product on Twitter, and the winner will be made into an actual product through a Kickstarter campaign.

A police crime commissioner, Vera Baird, is under investigation for awarding Â£500,000 of public money to a charity she runs with the force's chief, Sue Sim. Critics argue this is a conflict of interest and have accused them of creating a "soap opera" within the force. The Ministry of Justice will investigate whether any conflict of interest rules were broken.

Three people have been sent to prison for their involvement in a brutal assault on a 53-year-old man, who was beaten, tied to a chair, and tattooed with offensive images. The gang, known as the "tattoo terrorists," led by Corey Campbell, believed the victim had hurt Campbell's cat and attacked him in the basement of Campbell's mother's house. The assault lasted for three days, during which the victim suffered severe injuries. All three main perpetrators pleaded guilty and were sentenced to prison. Two others involved are awaiting sentencing.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven's 21-year-old star Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal keen to make him one of his first signings this summer. Van Gaal is familiar with Depay, having included him in the Dutch World Cup squad last year. PSV technical director Marcel Brands confirmed that there has been contact from Manchester United, as well as Paris Saint-Germain and another unnamed big European club, but stated that they are now discussing bigger amounts of money. Depay has scored 20 goals in 26 league games for PSV this season and is considered a promising talent, being compared to Dutch star Arjen Robben and potentially rivaling Cristiano Ronaldo in the future.

Chelsea took a 3-1 lead in the match against Manchester City's young side, with Tammy Abraham scoring twice and Dominic Solanke adding another. The young Manchester City team struggled against a strong Chelsea attack but showed promising performances from players like Kean Bryan, Isaac Buckley-Ricketts, and Brandon Barker. Despite some good moments, they were unable to overcome Chelsea's commanding lead.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate, believes people are born with a sexual preference but thinks the definition of marriage should be between a man and a woman. He doesn't believe same-sex marriage is a constitutional right and states should decide on the matter through political debate. Rubio would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer even if he didn't agree with their decision. As a Catholic, he believes divorce is wrong but wouldn't stop loving someone if they were divorced.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a Spanish-Latvian couple, are cycling around the world with no plans or agenda. They have covered 7,000 miles across 16 countries in their first year of travel, living on less than three euros each per day. The couple relies on free accommodation, using hosting websites like Couchsurfing and Warmshowers, and occasionally camping under the stars. Their only major expense is food, which costs them 2.74 euros each per day. They survive by eating pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, seasonal fruits and vegetables, and occasionally getting invited for meals or picking up wild fruits.

England full-back Mike Brown is taking a cautious approach to his recovery from a concussion setback, uncertain about when he will return to play for Harlequins. This follows the advice given to Northampton wing George North, who has been advised not to play again this season after suffering four quick-fire concussions. Brown admits that increased awareness of concussion symptoms, gained through online modules, helped him realize he would not be ready to face Ireland. He now advocates for being honest and cautious about the dangers of both short and long-term effects of concussions.

The passage suggests that smartphone use and increased internet access may be contributing to a decline in sexual activity among British couples. A study by statistician David Spiegelhalter reveals that heterosexual couples are now having sex three times a month, compared to four times a month in 2000 and five times a month in 1990. The integration of public and private lives, constant email checking, and busier lives due to better technological connectivity are possible reasons for this decline.

Tibetan Mastiffs, once popular and expensive status symbols in China, are now being sent to slaughterhouses due to their declining popularity. The Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown has reduced the gifting of these dogs between businessmen and officials, while recent bans on owning large dogs in several cities have also impacted their popularity. Unscrupulous breeders and gangs are selling poor quality and stolen dogs to slaughterhouses, where they are used for meat and leather. The breed's rapid decline began in 2005 when they were seen as a symbol of wealth and status, with one puppy even selling for Â£1.2 million just a year ago.

A company called Direct Line ran a competition called #everydayfix, where groups designed products to solve common problems. They asked people to pick their top ten "everyday emergencies" and then asked London-based design company Makerversity to create products to alleviate certain emergencies. The top three products were Snooze, an alarm clock that connects with your phone to silence notifications for a good night's sleep; Forget Me Lock, a device that shows whether your door is locked or not by swiveling green for open and red for locked; and Nipper, the world's smallest mobile phone charger using any household battery as its energy source. People can vote for their favorite product on Twitter, and the winner will be made into an actual product through a Kickstarter campaign.

The airline is headquartered in Doha, Qatar and operates a hub-and-spoke network, connecting over 160 international destinations across various regions. It uses Hamad International Airport as its base and has a fleet of more than 200 aircraft.

Summary:
The airline, headquartered in Doha's Qatar Airways Tower, operates a hub-and-spoke network connecting over 150 international destinations across various regions from its base at Hamad International Airport, using a fleet of more than 200 aircraft.

Maxthon is a popular web browser, particularly in China where it holds the second highest market share. It has garnered significant attention and usage globally, with over 400 million downloads worldwide.
