The new Beauty and the Beast film has caused controversy in Malaysia due to a "gay moment" in the movie. It was scheduled for release on Thursday but is being held for review by Disney. The Malaysian Censorship Board approved the film with a minor edit concerning the gay moment. Homosexual activity is illegal in Muslim majority Malaysia, but the country's tourism minister called banning the film "ridiculous." A new release date has not been announced yet. Local cinema chains have been offering refunds for customers who purchased tickets in advance.

Landlords in Southampton who rent properties to more than three unrelated people must obtain a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) license, but many are deterred by the cost of Â£1,000. Despite the risk of fines up to Â£20,000, an estimated 1,500 unlicensed HMOs exist in the area. Shelter helpline adviser Nadeem Khan highlights tenant concerns such as fear of eviction and living in poorly maintained properties due to the shortage of affordable homes. Nationally, mandatory licensing applies to houses with three or more storeys and occupied by five or more unrelated people. In Southampton, the licenses affect properties in specific areas introduced in 2013 and 2015. While most landlords cooperate, some have resisted applying for their license, leading to prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals.

The acting Taoiseach, Enda Kenny, and MicheÃ¡l Martin are trying to avoid a second election. Fianna FÃ¡il will facilitate a minority government but won't support a program for government. Water charges are a main issue in reaching an agreement, with Fine Gael supporting them and Fianna FÃ¡il wanting their immediate removal. A commission to consider the future of Irish Water is being proposed. No party has been able to form a majority government since the election, where Fine Gael had 50 seats, Fianna FÃ¡il 44, Sinn FÃ©in 23, and Labour Party got seven.

The Sorrento, a ship owned by Italian company Atlantica di Navigazione, caught fire while traveling to Valencia and was quickly evacuated. Passengers were rescued by other ships and taken to Palma de Mallorca. At least three people were injured and taken to the hospital. The cause of the fire is unknown. The ship may sink due to the damage it suffered.

The Electoral Commission has identified a problem with duplicate applications for voting, which is causing significant administration and financial burdens for electoral officials. There were 38 MPs who highlighted people claiming to have voted twice, including students. The watchdog suggests that individual electoral registers should be better joined up to help identify duplicate entries. Labour warns against making it harder for young people to register to vote. A record number of 46.8 million people were registered to vote in the recent election, with 68.7% actually voting on the day. However, concerns over the number of duplicate applications continue to persist. The watchdog recommends clearer information on registration sites and potentially a verification function used in other countries. It also calls for people who are registered in two seats to choose in advance which one they will vote in at future general elections.

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL player and University of Nebraska star, was found dead in his cell at the age of 40. Throughout his career, he played for the St Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers but faced numerous legal issues both on and off the field. Phillips was serving a term of over 30 years after being convicted of assaulting a former girlfriend and driving his car into a group of teenagers. He had been placed in a cell alone after being accused of killing his former cellmate. On Tuesday, a judge found enough evidence to try Phillips for the death of Damion Soward. The cause of Phillips' death remains unclear.

Lance Corporal Derby XXX is a Swaledale ram who serves as the mascot for the Mercian Regiment. He was recently promoted to his rank at an event in Chester, marking eight years of the regiment's existence. The promotion was awarded by Brigadier Andrew Williams, the colonel of the regiment, in recognition of the ram's good behavior. Lance Corporal Derby XXX is the 30th in a line of mascot rams dating back to the Indian Mutiny War in the mid-19th century. He joined the regiment in 2014 and has various duties, including having his own army number, buying his rations, and taking holidays during mating season on the Chatsworth Estate in Derbyshire. Additionally, he has participated in events such as switching on Christmas lights and meeting Prince William at a memorial unveiling.

Liverpool secured a dramatic 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund, advancing to the Europa League semi-finals. Jurgen Klopp's side came back from a 2-0 deficit and a nail-biting finish saw Dejan Lovren score the winning goal in injury time. The match was filled with emotion, drama, and brilliant football, as both teams displayed their skills on the pitch. Klopp's influence on his players and fans has been evident, as Liverpool now looks forward to the semi-finals with growing confidence.

The EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee met in London, where Mr. Davis expressed the UK government's commitment to keeping Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland informed about Brexit negotiations. He proposed monthly meetings for a "two-way information flow" with the devolved administrations. However, Mr. Russell called for more transparency from the UK government regarding its strategic intentions and emphasized the importance of single market membership for Scotland's economic prosperity. The UK government hopes the High Court judgment on Article 50 will be overruled on appeal to the Supreme Court next month, but the Scottish government plans to oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court during the appeal.

The passage discusses a study conducted on 13 cloned sheep, including Daisy, Debbie, Denise, and Diane, who were cloned from the same adult ewe as Dolly the sheep. The study aims to determine if these cloned animals age normally and are healthy. Veterinary surgeon Dr. Sandra Corr performs physical examinations on the sheep, looking for signs of disease or osteoarthritis. The study focuses on three co-morbidities associated with aging: cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. The results of this study could have significant implications for the future of cloning.

The unbeaten favorite, Shutter Speed, won a race at York and is set to compete in the French Oaks instead of the Epsom Oaks. Trainer John Gosden is concerned about the ground for his colt Cracksman in Thursday's Dante Stakes and may not run him in the Derby trial due to the short time between the two races.

The pound initially fell against the dollar and euro, but started recovering before falling again. Investors are uncertain due to data showing a potential Leave vote, causing the volatility index to reach 2008 financial crisis levels. Polls show the Leave campaign ahead, with Betfair's implied probability of a Remain vote at 68.5%. Hedge funds have been short-selling on expectations of further drops in sterling value. Asian stock markets fell due to concerns about the economic impact of leaving the EU. London's FTSE 100 ended down 1.1%, with Lloyds Banking Group as the biggest faller. Nigel Farage claims sterling has been strengthening since March and a weaker pound benefits UK exporters.

The Iron are currently in sixth place in the National League, just outside the play-off spots. Despite a challenging journey and conceding an early goal against Barrow, Cowley remained positive about his team's performance. Barrow extended their unbeaten league run to nine games with the win, while Braintree's losing streak reached three games. Cowley acknowledged the difficulty of their situation as a part-time team but expressed determination to embrace the challenge and enjoy the journey.

The passage discusses the upcoming shift in responsibility for planning decisions from the Planning Service to local councils in Northern Ireland starting in April 2015. This change means that elected politicians will be making planning decisions instead of the Planning Service. Some are optimistic about this move, believing it will democratize the planning system and give councils more control over community development plans. However, concerns have been raised about potential corruption and discrimination in planning decisions, as well as the need for transparency in political donations. Friends of the Earth has warned that a strict code of conduct must be enforced to ensure fairness and transparency in the new system.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times and had to have a leg amputated. The owner found her injured and took her to the Scottish SPCA. The incident has raised concerns about air gun licensing, as the Scottish government previously held a consultation on the matter but faced opposition from the majority of respondents.

Liverpool signed Belgian international Christian Benteke as their seventh summer signing, making him the club's second most expensive acquisition. The striker was signed from Aston Villa for a fee that triggered a release clause in his contract. Benteke scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa after joining from Genk in 2012. Liverpool hopes he will help revive their attack following the sale of Luis Suarez and injury struggles of Daniel Sturridge last season.

A study commissioned by Tablets for Schools found that there is no clear evidence of academic improvement for pupils using tablet devices. The study surveyed 671 state and independent schools, finding that tablets are now used in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools. In 9% of schools, each pupil has their own tablet device. Although it is not possible to make a definitive connection between tablet computers and improved results, head teachers reported a positive impact, and tablets have been shown to help motivate disengaged pupils and involve families in learning. Touch-screen computers have also been found useful in helping boys and poorer pupils learn to read. The use of technology in schools reflects the reality of how pupils live at home and what they will find in the workplace.

The Growing Up in the City exhibition at the Museum of Liverpool showcases 25 photographs capturing the lives of children over a period of more than 100 years. The images provide a snapshot of childhood and serve as a thought-provoking social history of life in Liverpool throughout the decades. The photographs range from 1887 to the 1990s, highlighting changes in childhood experiences and special occasions marked on the city's streets. Curator Kay Jones selected the final 25 images from hundreds in the National Museums Liverpool's collections, aiming to represent both the good and bad experiences of childhood. The exhibition will be available until September 25th.

Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back, has mutually ended his contract with Barrow to join their National League rivals. He could play against his former club on 18 February. Keating, a 21-year-old striker, has been recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams and is awaiting international clearance. Nicholson praises Anderson's leadership qualities and Keating's hunger to prove himself. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone and have won only one of their last six games.

The new Bolivian law permits 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization and sets harsher punishment for violence against children, including a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide. The law aims to balance rights and international treaties while addressing the country's poverty. Over 500,000 children already work in Bolivia, with many facing extreme conditions in mines and agriculture fields. The International Labour Organisation has concerns about the legislation potentially breaching international regulations on child labor.

The 50-year-old actress, Rosie O'Donnell, experienced a "widow maker" heart attack and was lucky to survive. She searched her symptoms online and took aspirin before visiting a cardiologist who inserted a stent into her blocked artery. O'Donnell warned others to know the symptoms and call 911.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a boy from Harrow, was at a party in Belvedere Way, Kenton on Saturday evening. A fight broke out with a group of youths who were denied entry to the party. Che was stabbed in a later scuffle in an alleyway and pronounced dead an hour later. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and is in stable condition. Police believe Che was not involved in the initial altercation but was targeted later. A 21-year-old man and two boys aged 15 and 16 have been arrested on suspicion of murder, while a 14-year-old is being held on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon. Detective Chief Inspector Chris Jones is seeking anyone with information about the incident.

The passage discusses the reorganization of cancer diagnosis in Denmark, which aimed to address poor cancer survival rates compared to other European countries. The changes include fast-track diagnosis and treatment routes for patients with specific cancer symptoms, diagnostic centers for patients with difficult-to-diagnose symptoms, and "yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms that could potentially be cancer. These changes have improved organization within the existing healthcare system without overwhelming it with more GP referrals and have led to better survival rates. Denmark's healthcare system is similar to Wales, suggesting that lessons can be shared between the two countries on improving organization to catch up with the top European performers.

The UK government has disbanded the OFT and awarded Powys council a contract worth Â£170,000 annually to handle warning and banning orders against dishonest estate agents. Complaints about estate agents will still be handled by local authority trading standards departments, which will refer cases involving breaches of the Estate Agents Act to Powys. James Munro from Powys council hopes this new role will demonstrate their ability to take on more contracts and outside work in the future.

The NHS Employers has approved a plan to reshape the workforce, allowing nurses and other healthcare staff to take on additional tasks with more training. A Nuffield Trust review found examples of nurses filling in for hospital doctors and pharmacists for GPs. However, unions warn against using this as a quick fix for problems in the NHS. The report highlights the need for more staff support for doctors to help them coordinate the best possible care for their patients. Money will need to be set aside to ensure this happens.

The Lower Bristol Road in Bath was closed by Avon and Somerset Police after a crash at 03:00 GMT near Rackfield Place outside the First depot. The A36 road closure caused disruptions and delays to commuters and bus services during rush hour, but was lifted at 14:00 GMT. Investigations are ongoing to determine the cause of the collision. First reported that some services have resumed normal schedules, but it may take a few hours for all services to return to normal. Managing director James Freeman expressed gratitude for the public's support and staff's extra efforts in managing the situation and recovery.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding the potential impact of the Swansea tidal lagoon project on fish populations. NRW estimates that 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout could die each year due to the project, while TLP claims these figures lack clear scientific basis. TLP argues that NRW's methodology for calculating these numbers has not been shared and that their own computer modeling suggests a worst-case scenario of only 2% of all fish species being killed. The Â£1.3bn project is seen as a test bed for larger versions around the UK coast, but both Welsh Government and industry representatives are seeking clarity on the UK government's position.

The Northern Ireland agri-food industry is set to have a new marketing body, similar to Scotland Food and Drink, which will be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB). This initiative was announced by Stormont's Enterprise, Trade and Investment Minister Arlene Foster, who highlighted the importance of the agri-food industry in the region with nearly 100,000 jobs. The new body will provide strategic leadership for marketing activities of both government and private sector organizations. While welcoming the announcement, Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill also mentioned potential implications for other organizations and the need for discussions with AFSB.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a four-year project to plant millions of native UK trees across four new woods, including Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley. The aim is to commemorate the millions of people who died during WW1 and to create a living tribute. In Brackfield Wood, 40,000 trees will be planted in honor of the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict. Members of the public are invited to participate in planting these trees and creating a place for wildlife to thrive and for people to reflect.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for her thriller "Someone Else's Skin," which tackles domestic violence and honor crime. The book was praised for its powerful story and tight writing. Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honor for her 23-year career writing about female private investigator VI Warshawski, who was described as a game changer in crime fiction. Both awards were presented at the annual crime writing festival in Harrogate.

The passage discusses the return of New Zealand cricketer Mitchell Santner to Worcestershire County Cricket Club after recovering from a finger injury he sustained in 2016. Director of cricket Steve Rhodes expresses his unfinished business with Santner and believes that his presence would have been an extra bonus for the team's qualifying hopes. Santner, a left-arm batsman and spinner, will rejoin the Rapids following June's ICC Trophy in England. He is excited to return and make up for lost time, hoping to make an impact with both bat and ball. In August, Worcestershire signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season across all formats of the game.

Barry Pring was killed in 2008 when he was hit by a speeding car while trying to hail a taxi on the hard shoulder of a dual carriageway in Kiev. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, had returned to a restaurant for a missing glove. The coroner at Exeter County Hall recorded a verdict of unlawful killing. Close friend Peter Clifford believed that Barry was murdered and his family suspected that his death was part of a staged hit and run accident. Ms Ziuzina tried to claim her husband's assets soon after his death and sold his Range Rover, contents from his flat, and moved funds from his bank account. She was also having an affair with a Ukrainian man. The case is still active but not actively pursued.

A boy named Charlie, who is from Merseyside, needs to go back to Seattle, America for a special treatment that isn't available in the UK. He needs more T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital because the last treatment didn't work. His mom is very happy and thankful to an amazing person who paid for his treatment. Charlie has been sick since he was three years old and there are no other options for him in the UK. His family is very grateful for the kind person who helped them and they can't wait to find out when Charlie can start his new treatment.

The passage discusses the implementation of a two-step verification system by Apple to prevent hackers from stealing intimate photos of celebrities from iCloud. This security measure requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted mobile phone number or via Apple's Find My iPhone app after typing their username and password on a new device. If the code is not entered, access to iCloud and purchases are blocked, but a 14-character recovery key can be used to regain access if needed. While this system has been offered in the past, it did not previously apply to device backups. However, recent changes now guard against the technique used by hackers in previous attacks. Despite these improvements, concerns remain about the security system, including the vulnerability of recovery keys and the need for stronger default security measures across companies like Apple, Microsoft, and Google.

A deal is being negotiated for Wright to buy 20% of Billericay Town Football Club, with some details yet to be released. Wright, a former non-league footballer and runner-up in I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011, may become a club director. The team is currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division and recently came under new ownership by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who has invested Â£10,000 a week in the club. They also signed former England international Paul Konchesky in March.

Mr. Ashley has been asked to provide evidence about the treatment of workers at his Derbyshire company following a BBC investigation into warehouse working practices. He has until March 21st to respond after receiving a letter from Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee. Mr. Ashley was invited to a meeting at the company's Shirebrook base but has not accepted any of the offered dates. The BIS Committee is committed to transparency and usually meets in public at Westminster. If Mr. Ashley fails to agree to attend, the committee may seek support from the House of Commons regarding any complaint of contempt. Sports Direct, owned by Mr. Ashley, has previously pledged to review worker rights with oversight by him.

The report, entitled Putin. War, accuses President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine for his own ends, based on facts gathered since Crimea's annexation in March 2014 and the conflict in eastern Ukraine. The report presents evidence of Russian soldiers and equipment being decisive in securing major victories for pro-Russian rebels in Donetsk and Luhansk. It also documents volunteer soldiers admitting that it was Russian generals, not separatists, who directed the main battles in eastern Ukraine. The report estimates Russian spending on the conflict at 53bn roubles ($1bn). Despite the evidence presented, many Russians are still supportive of Moscow's involvement in eastern Ukraine.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found dead at Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire on Monday at 11:00 BST. The 34-year-old from Rotherham died due to head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested by South Yorkshire Police and are currently in custody.

The passage discusses the concerns of Carwyn Jones, the First Minister of Wales, regarding the lack of involvement and consultation with the Welsh government in the drafting of a letter sent to Donald Tusk by UK Prime Minister Theresa May. The letter pertained to Article 50 and the negotiation framework for the whole of the UK. Jones expressed frustration at not being able to contribute to the letter's content and criticized the perceived lack of respect towards devolved administrations. Alun Cairns, Welsh Secretary, defended the UK government's actions and mentioned that Wales was specifically mentioned in Mrs. May's letter to Donald Tusk. The passage also raises questions about which powers will be devolved to Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland after Brexit and whether there will be accompanying funding.

Two cars were damaged in an incident in Newry on Friday night. The Assistant Chief Constable expressed his disgust at the attacks on PSNI officers and the community. Police were carrying out duties when they were attacked, and a Facebook post appealed to parents to know their children's whereabouts.

Mr. Charney, the founder of American Apparel, was removed from his position last year due to employee complaints and allegations of misusing company funds. The board stated they did not expect him to return to the company. In response to a defamation lawsuit by Mr. Charney against the company and its chair, the court filing revealed evidence of inappropriate emails and racially derogatory comments made by the former CEO. The company claimed that Mr. Charney repeatedly violated their sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policy. Due to these issues, the board believes it would be difficult for any company to hire Mr. Charney as an executive or employee. A restraining order has been granted to prevent Mr. Charney from making negative statements about the company or attempting to remove board members.

The passage discusses an upcoming basketball game between Great Britain and Greece. The match will be available for viewing on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. The two teams previously played in Patras, Greece, with Greece winning 92-64. However, three members of the Greek team will be absent from the rematch at the Copper Box, giving Great Britain a chance to seek revenge. The game is crucial for both teams as they prepare for EuroBasket 2017, which begins in September.

The passage discusses the launch of the iPhone in 2007 and its impact on various industries, particularly photography. The author initially had doubts about the iPhone's revolutionary nature but now acknowledges its transformative effect on mobile technology. The iPhone changed the way people thought about smartphones and made it easier for users to perform various activities on the move. Other companies like Amazon and Google are now advancing with innovative AI-imbued products, but the iPhone marked the beginning of the mobile connected era.

The passage reports that several cats in the Victor Avenue area of Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire have died after ingesting a toxic substance, possibly antifreeze. It is unclear whether the poisonings were accidental or intentional. The owner of seven-month-old Meereen, who died on Monday, is devastated and was informed by the vet that her cat had consumed antifreeze. RSPCA inspector Andy Bostock urges people in the area to ensure pesticides and chemicals are stored safely, especially during the time of year when antifreeze is used in cars.

The Syriza government in Greece is set to agree to more austerity and liberalization measures despite no protests on the streets of Athens. Greece's resorts are experiencing an increase in tourism, with Athens airport expecting 25 million arrivals this year. The calm may be due to the anticipation of new credit from the eurozone and possibly the IMF. Greek citizens remain curious about how much Alexis Tsipras has conceded to obtain â¬86bn for the third bailout of the country. Despite conspicuously failing to deliver an end to fiscal austerity, Tsipras remains popular. Greece is suffering from a vicious economic squeeze that will further impoverish its people. For the new bailout to hold, Tsipras must offer hope of better times ahead. Creditors may need to ease the burden of Greece's unsustainably large debts by a third to a half for genuine recovery.

Ross Kemp is returning to EastEnders for a brief period to reprise his role as Grant Mitchell for the final episodes featuring Barbara Windsor as Peggy Mitchell. The character will be killed off after revealing her cancer has returned. Kemp expressed excitement about reuniting with his on-screen brother, Steve McFadden, and being part of the emotional storyline. Executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins praised Kemp and McFadden's acting skills in bringing the Mitchell brothers together for the farewell to their mother.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked Alice Ruggles in October. Her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, knew it was Dhillon who killed her even before the police officers informed them. The trial at Newcastle Crown Court revealed that Dhillon had become obsessed with Alice and had stalked her. Alice's mother, Dr. Hills, felt guilty for trying to reassure her daughter on the phone two days prior, as she later realized the severity of the situation. The Ruggles have set up the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking and to remember their daughter's vibrant personality. Dhillon was found guilty and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison.

EDF has approved funding for the Â£18bn Hinkley Point project in Somerset, with one third of the cost provided by Chinese investors. However, the UK government is considering its support for the project, causing uncertainty and raising concerns about potential environmental damage and escalating costs. The plant is expected to provide 7% of the UK's total electricity requirement. Critics argue that more investment is needed in renewable energy sources such as offshore wind.

The new divorce application form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person with whom the spouse has committed adultery. However, family lawyers warn that naming a third party can increase conflict and complexity. There is no obligation to name the person, but the form's design may lead applicants to do so. The older version of the form had a space for "co-respondents" to be named if appropriate. Adultery was cited as the reason for 12,148 out of 100,000 divorces granted in England and Wales in 2015.

The passage discusses the concerns of Confor, an organization promoting the forestry industry, regarding the emphasis on environmental aspects at the expense of commercial forestry in Wales. Ministers are encouraging investment in woodland creation, but Confor warns that 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost since 2001 and need replanting. There is a conflict between environmental policy and the needs of the timber industry, with some forests difficult to harvest and transportation causing conflicts with local residents. The Welsh government aims for a balance between environmental, economic, and social factors in forestry development through its Glastir scheme and Woodlands for Wales strategy. Martin Bishop of Confor believes there is too much focus on environmental aspects and bureaucracy hindering new woodland areas, with a need for 20,000 hectares per year to meet long-term targets.

The boy was badly injured after being struck in Coatbridge, near Langloan Primary School. Emergency crews were called to the scene on Bank Street at 16:40 and he was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow with a serious condition.

The passage discusses the presentation of Ushakov medals to veterans of the Arctic Convoys by Russian Defence attachÃ© Capt Oleg Kornienko. Able seaman Charles Lewis, a 91-year-old survivor, expressed his honor and delight at receiving the medal. Initially, the Foreign Office did not allow Russia to honor the veterans due to rules on foreign medals. The Russian embassy emphasized the importance of the convoys in allowing Russian soldiers to defeat Germans on the Eastern Front. The Arctic Convoys were maritime campaigns during World War II that faced threats from German U-boats, aircraft, severe cold, storms, and ice floes. Over 3,000 men died during these campaigns, which Winston Churchill called the "worst journey in the world." The British Government created the Arctic Star in 2012 to recognize the convoy veterans, but campaigners believed they should also receive the Russian Ushakov medal. Last year, the Foreign Office allowed an exception to its rules, and President Vladimir Putin presented the first medals in June 201

The HM Inspectorate of Probation found delays and inefficiencies in the implementation of unpaid work or "community payback" for offenders. Offenders often did not complete their assigned hours, and some were let off if they did not attend. The report highlighted 15 recommendations for improvement, including reducing the number of times offenders are turned away from work and creating objectives for unpaid work that match the circumstances of the offender. The Ministry of Justice accepted the recommendations and is taking action to implement them, aiming for more effective rehabilitation and ensuring offenders turn up on time and face consequences if they do not.

The comedian is accused of being a hypocrite for campaigning for economic and political revolution to help the poor while living in a luxury home. He has been asked about his accommodation before and called a journalist "a snide" when questioned. The star believes that personal change, including sharing wealth, is necessary but systemic change is also required. He acknowledges his past mistakes and the criticism he faces but insists that inequality and ecological disaster are real problems that need addressing.

The passage discusses the life and work of Dr. J Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur who played a significant role in mapping the human genome and creating the world's first synthetic life form. Dr. Venter's determination and sense of urgency stem from his experiences during the Vietnam War. He made breakthroughs in gene sequencing by focusing on messenger molecules (RNA) rather than the entire DNA blueprint. His commercial ventures, such as Celera Genomics and the J Craig Venter Institute, allowed him to achieve his goals without relying on public funding. In 2006, he set out to create a synthetic life form, which led to both controversy and potential advancements in various industries.

A survey of 1,000 parents in England found that four out of five children who ate school lunches tried food at school they hadn't tried at home. Half of the parents reported their children asked for those new foods to be cooked at home. Carrots, sweetcorn, and peas were the most popular vegetables, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were less popular. The School Food Trust conducted the research after a Mumsnet survey suggested some parents gave their children packed lunches due to pickiness. School meals can help children try new foods and increase diet variety. About 40% of primary school children in England eat school lunches, slightly more than in secondary schools.

Morata, a 23-year-old Spanish footballer playing for Spain at Euro 2016, joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real Madrid. Real Madrid had an option to buy him back for up to Â£23m. Morata has scored three times for Spain in the ongoing tournament and previously attracted interest from Arsenal and Chelsea. During his two years with Juventus, he scored 27 goals, won two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. He played in consecutive Champions League finals, scoring in one of them. Morata started his career at Real Madrid and made his first team debut at the age of 18, scoring 10 goals for the La Liga side.

Wilson, a 30-year-old footballer, returned to Championship side Forest from Celtic for Â£2.5m in August 2013. He has been without a team since being released in May and previously played for Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the world's third largest retailer, is selling its loss-making US food chain Fresh & Easy to Yucaipa, a Los Angeles based private equity company. Around 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business as part of the deal. Tesco will loan the new business Â£80m and expects to spend Â£150m in total to dispose of the Fresh & Easy brand. If Yucaipa becomes profitable, Tesco has the option to buy a stake.

The passage discusses an individual who faced racial abuse but overcame it, and is now aiming to win a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. Additionally, there is a reference to a special guide on how to get into martial arts.

The French Alps have lost about 26% of their glacial coverage over the last 40 years, with the area decreasing from 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s to around 275 sq km in the late 2000s. This information was presented at the American Geophysical Union (AGU) Fall Meeting and is consistent with findings of retreat in other parts of the Alps. The new French Alps glaciers inventory was produced by Marie Gardent and colleagues, assessing approximately 600 glaciers across several massifs. The greatest losses have been observed in the southern sectors, with glacier retreat being less significant in the northern Alps due to differing climatic conditions and mountain elevations.

The Scots have won all their qualifiers and are set to face Iceland, who are also unbeaten, in a match that could secure their place in the upcoming major competition. Scotland's forward, Evans, is determined not to miss out on the opportunity this time after previous play-off losses. With the best six of the eight group runners-up automatically qualifying for the finals, Scotland is in a strong position to reach the tournament in the Netherlands without needing a play-off.

Stuart Campbell, a blogger and campaigner for Scottish independence, was arrested in the west of England following a complaint of online harassment from a woman in south London. The allegations cover a two-year period and concern some tweets that Mr. Campbell claims are not threatening. He has been released on bail and is due to return in mid-September pending further inquiries.

Peta has suggested replacing the Jolly Fisherman mascot of Skegness with a modern, animal-friendly version, such as a fish with the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice." The group believes that the current mascot represents cruelty to animals and wants the resort to rebrand itself as a progressive holiday destination. However, the mayor of Skegness feels that Jolly is well-loved and does not believe there would be much support for his removal. The original Jolly Fisherman poster was commissioned in 1908 by the Great Northern Railway to promote Skegness as a seaside destination.

Scotland dominated the match against Georgia, scoring six tries and securing a 38-11 victory. The Scots led from the start with early tries from Tommy Seymour and Stuart Hogg. Georgian scrum-half Vasil Lobzhanidze scored two tries but it wasn't enough to close the gap. Scotland's strong performance was attributed to their effective ball handling and counter-attacking play.

Widnes defeated Castleford 38-24, with tries from Leuluai, Ah Van, Bridge, and Mellor securing their victory. Despite a nervy finish with three Cas tries in four minutes, Widnes held on to move above Wakefield into seventh place, while Castleford remains in sixth place, one point above the Vikings.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old detainee at the US facility in Guantanamo Bay, was released after a review panel determined he was not a "continuing significant threat." Al-Odah had been held since 2002 on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, which he denies. He will now face at least a year at a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait. This release reduces the total number of inmates at Guantanamo to 148.

Anzac Day commemorates the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One. Thousands attended services at Hyde Park Corner and Westminster Abbey, with the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia sung as the service ended. The first time Anzac Day was commemorated in the capital was when King George V attended a Westminster Abbey service in 1916. Since then, the services have become an important moment for thousands of expatriate and visiting New Zealanders and Australians, who honor the sacrifices of their countrymen and women in all wars. Members of veterans' associations, service and ex-service personal and their families took part in the parade at the Cenotaph.

The passage discusses the return of Clarkson, a 30-year-old footballer, to Premiership Well for a second spell in July. He could potentially make his St Mirren debut against Alloa in the Championship on Saturday. Last season, he scored nine goals at Dundee and has mainly been a substitute this term. Despite this, he states that he is fit and ready for his opportunity to play. With almost 400 senior appearances at club level and two caps for Scotland in 2008, Clarkson has experience playing for various teams including Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. St Mirren currently stands eighth in the Championship, seven points above bottom side Alloa. Clarkson expresses his ambition to help the team win more games, gain confidence, and push up the table to bring the club back to its previous standing.

The turkey firm was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan, who confirmed that current pension arrangements with Bernard Matthews would continue under new ownership. Unite had productive talks and received guarantees that all current agreements will be honored. The goal is to restore Bernard Matthews to its former position as a highly profitable business through greater investment, cost savings, and utilizing spare capacity to process chicken and not just turkeys.

The council discussed problems with a new ferry, including breakdowns, groundings, and suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency. Council leader Dave Stewart announced free crossings until 2 July to gather feedback and ordered a project review by auditors. Local businesses have suffered losses, and compensation for damaged cars and businesses is under discussion. Councillor Ian Ward acknowledged teething problems but stated that electrical issues have been resolved, and ramp extensions are being manufactured to address vehicle scraping concerns.

The House of Lords European Union Committee has released a report on the risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry post-Brexit. While many in the industry see Brexit as an opportunity to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation, the report warns that the industry may be marginalized in wider Brexit negotiations. The report also highlights potential issues with shared commercial fish stocks between the UK and other EU coastal states, and the need for continued market access. However, this access may come at a price, with EU member states potentially demanding more access to UK waters in return for continued rights to sell fish to the European market with zero tariffs.

Timothy Geaney, a former teacher, admitted to taking or allowing images of young boys in erotic poses to be taken between 2004 and 2014. He was sentenced earlier this year and made subject to a community payback order, placed on the sex offenders register, and ordered to participate in a special program for sex offenders. Geaney was later removed from his profession's register following a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing, which found that his conduct was "fundamentally incompatible" with being a registered teacher. The panel determined that he had failed to uphold the standards expected of the profession and found him unfit to teach. Geaney is prohibited from applying to re-register for two years.

A fire at Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited's site in Duncan Street led to train service disruptions and travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended the company from accepting waste, as they were "broadly compliant" with fire safety law. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) had visited the premises nine times in the last year, expressing concerns about the impact of a potential fire on nearby residents, transport, and the environment. The EA decided to revoke the company's environmental permit after considering all facts related to the incident. The cause of the fire remains unknown.

The passage discusses Syria's efforts to destroy its chemical weapons stockpile, which is behind schedule. Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad states that Syria is doing its best to comply with the timetable but faces challenges due to ongoing war and attacks on weapon shipments. He also denies accusations of using barrel bombs in Aleppo and accuses the US of supporting terrorist elements in the country. Reports suggest that rebels have seized most of Aleppo's central prison, but state media denies this. The US is concerned about the delay in the UN-backed plan, and Russia urges Damascus to complete the transfer of chemical weapons by 1 March.

England won by a big margin against Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series. Joe Root was named man of the match for his outstanding performance, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second. England's captain, Alastair Cook, praised Root's responsible play at number three. Pakistan struggled in both innings, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 in the first two Tests. The series is expected to be tight, but England is in a strong position.

Older People's Commissioner for Wales Sarah Rochira is gathering experiences of residential care from pensioners and their families to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. This is part of her review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She will highlight good care but also show the impact of poor care on older people. The review will consider factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Care providers, social care staff, and public bodies will also be consulted. The chair of Care Forum Wales, Mario Kreft, supports the review but is disappointed that no provider expert is included on the main advisory panel.

Paul Sheerin, former Dons midfielder and player-manager at Arbroath since 2010, has been appointed as the new manager of Aberdeen, replacing Neil Cooper. Sheerin had a comprehensive process for selection and was chosen by boss Derek McInnes. Despite wanting to retain his services, Arbroath chairman John Christison was cooperative in allowing Sheerin to return to Aberdeen. Sheerin played for various Scottish clubs and Ãstersunds in Sweden before moving into coaching. He also won a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s. Notably, Sheerin led Arbroath to win their first national trophy in history by securing the Scottish Third Division title and promotion in 2011.

Swansea City's assistant manager, Alan Curtis, and Paul Williams will take charge of the upcoming match against Bournemouth after the sacking of Bob Bradley. The club aims to appoint a new manager as soon as possible, with former Derby manager Paul Clement being their top choice. Curtis believes that the current squad is good enough to avoid relegation but emphasizes the importance of stability in management. He also mentions the club's history and how crucial it is for them to stay in the Premier League not just for the club itself, but for the entire area.

The passage discusses the life and work of Dr. J Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur who played a significant role in mapping the human genome and creating a synthetic life form. He is known for his determination to speed up the process of genomics research, which led him to establish a private research institute and later, Celera Genomics. Despite facing criticism from the scientific community for his unconventional methods, he continued to make breakthroughs in the field. In 2006, he formed the J Craig Venter Institute to focus on creating the world's first synthetic life form, Synthia, which was published in the journal Science. Dr. Venter has also been involved in other projects such as collecting life forms from the oceans to better understand genes and proteins.

The Sutton Trust warns that many apprenticeships in Europe are low quality and too short, and calls for the creation of thousands of new apprenticeships to boost the economy and improve young people's job prospects. Currently, only 20% of employers in England offer apprenticeships compared to 51% in Germany, which has one of the best vocational education systems. The report suggests that England's vocational system is overly complicated with 18,000 different qualifications, while Germany has 330. The report recommends expanding apprenticeships with up to 300,000 new starts each year, with the majority being at level three or higher.

The passage discusses the success of British Paralympian Sarah Storey, who recently won a race in Nottwil, Switzerland. She is now targeting further success at the upcoming Paralympic Games in Rio de Janeiro. With 22 medals, Storey is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian and has won 11 gold, eight silver, and three bronze medals across six Paralympics. She has also won 21 world titles across both cycling and swimming sports. Storey began her sporting career in swimming before switching to cycling in 2005.

The financial troubles of Hereford United led to their expulsion from the Football Conference. Despite efforts by fans and other clubs, the team faced debts of around Â£225,000 and failed to meet multiple payment deadlines for football creditors. Chester has been reinstated as a Conference Premier club, while Hayes & Yeading will stay in Conference South. Hereford's fate was ultimately sealed when they were unable to meet the extended deadline set by the Conference board.

The passage discusses a former Manchester City player, aged 30, who won 61 caps for England between 2009 and 2016. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships but only played three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps since 2004. He scored his first and only international goal during the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers in a match against Moldova.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and one of the most influential exponents of the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a long illness. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directed it for 30 years across six continents. The AAM recorded over 200 CDs, including the first-ever complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Hogwood was also a tutor at Harvard University and held honorary professorships at the University of Cambridge and Cornell University.

A boy from Northern Ireland with special needs is struggling due to lack of space in local special schools. His family had to remove him from mainstream schooling and requested a place at a special school, but none were available. The boy's mother expressed concerns that other families may face the same situation as the system is over capacity. The Education Authority is reviewing special school provision in Northern Ireland to ensure availability close to children's residences.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) has made a takeover bid for Newport Gwent Dragons, with plans to turn Rodney Parade into a rugby venue. Newport County, who have a lease to use the ground until 2023, will be affected by this change. The WRU's takeover will be put to a vote on May 9th. Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey stated that both County and Newport Squash Club are protected under their current agreements. The WRU intends to install an artificial surface, which goes against Football League rules. Newport County is currently two points clear of the League Two relegation zone and could secure survival this weekend with a win and a Hartlepool loss.

The country has been declared free of the virus that killed almost 4,000 people over the past 18 months. The speaker shares his experiences during the civil war and Ebola outbreak in Sierra Leone. He was kidnapped by rebels at 15 and forced to join them, but eventually escaped and found hope through a project called Lifeline Nehemiah. During the Ebola crisis, he and others worked to educate communities, provide support, and set up an Ebola treatment unit, saving many lives. The speaker now sees his life as changed and believes in investing in young people for a better future.

A public fundraising campaign raised enough money to prevent the auction of 80,000 works of art and other items from the Wedgwood Museum. The collection will remain on display in Barlaston, Staffordshire, and will eventually be loaned to the Victoria and Albert Museum. The collection was at risk of being sold due to the museum's inherited pension debt from Waterford Wedgwood plc's collapse in 2009.

A deal is being negotiated for Wright to buy 20% of Billericay Town Football Club, with some details yet to be released. Wright may become a club director and the team is currently in eighth place in the Isthmian League Premier Division. Wright has played non-league football for various clubs, and Billericay was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin who invests Â£10,000 a week. The club also signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

In a closely contested match, Blackpool and Colchester United ended with a 1-1 draw. The Seasiders took the lead in the first half with a goal from Jamille Matt, but Colchester equalized soon after. Both teams had chances to score a winning goal, but were denied by impressive saves from the respective goalkeepers. In injury time, Sean Murray was sent off for Colchester United for a bad tackle, leaving them to finish the game with 10 men.

The disused Fawley power station chimney, standing at 198 meters tall, is set to become the centerpiece of a Â£1bn "merchant city" development. The project includes a petal-shaped glass structure, marina, housing, and restaurants. Developers Fawley Waterside plan to build fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth as part of the development. Outline planning permission is due later this year, with construction potentially starting in 2018. The oil-fired Fawley Power Station was commissioned in 1971 and could power one million homes before closing in 2013.

A 23-year-old British cyclist won a bronze medal at the Hong Kong championships, making it GB's second medal in the event. He managed to catch up with Adrian Teklinski of Poland, who won gold, and Lucass Liss of Germany, who got silver. However, in the men's team pursuit, GB was beaten to the bronze medal by Italy. The young British squad in the women's team pursuit finished fifth in the heats and failed to make the bronze-medal ride. Olympic gold medallist Chris Boardman praised the cyclist for his fantastic final charge and timing his effort well.

Ross Kemp is returning to EastEnders for a brief period to reprise his role as Grant Mitchell for the final episodes featuring Barbara Windsor as Peggy Mitchell. Kemp's return will bring the Mitchell family together as they face Peggy's death from cancer. The character of Grant Mitchell has been a significant part of the soap's history since his introduction in 1990, and his reunion with brother Phil (played by Steve McFadden) is expected to result in emotional and memorable scenes.

In the passage, it is mentioned that Sadio Mane scored two goals in a short time period during a match between Spurs and Liverpool at Anfield. The Spurs' coach, Pochettino, expressed disappointment in his team's performance, stating that starting the game with a lack of desire makes it very difficult to compete for the Premier League title. He also mentioned that if Chelsea extends their lead by beating Burnley, it would create a significant problem for his team. The Spurs have struggled on the road, winning only twice since September 24th, and have had difficulty against top-six rivals. Pochettino believes that his team must improve quickly to challenge for the Premier League title. Danny Murphy, a former Liverpool and Spurs midfielder, commented on the contrast between Spurs' home and away performances and suggested they should stick to their successful defensive strategy used against big sides.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governor posts in recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the People's Democratic Party (PDP) since military rule ended in 1999. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari will be inaugurated on May 29th after defeating President Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP lost control of key northern states and only managed to hold onto Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The APC made historic gains, relegating the once-powerful PDP to a regional party. However, the APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could be a concern for President-elect Buhari as militant groups could disrupt oil production.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival is using an app to provide online information and interactive experiences for visitors. From 19-22 July in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis, attendees can access videos, band interviews, and other content through their phones and tablets. The festival will feature acts such as The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Lucy Spraggan. The augmented reality experience allows people worldwide to interact with the festival and get a taste of its atmosphere.

Birmingham schools Park View and Nansen Primary, rated inadequate by Ofsted, will have their funding agreements terminated. The Park View Educational Trust may be removed from running the schools. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School were warned they could lose funding unless concerns were addressed. A head teacher at one of the Trojan Horse schools reported parents tried to undermine her authority during an Ofsted inspection. Birmingham City Council will work with Saltley School and the Department for Education to install a temporary governing board. Lord Nash criticized Park View and Nansen Primary for failing to promote "spiritual, moral, social and cultural development of pupils." Both schools have been invited to respond before July 4th.

Vinnie Barker died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The prosecution claims that eye specialist Honey Rose's conduct was below the expected standard and "criminal," as she failed to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs and refer him for further investigation. This alleged failure led to a build-up of fluid in his brain, increasing pressure in his skull and ultimately causing his death. The prosecution argues that Vinnie's death was preventable if Ms. Rose had done her job properly. Ms. Rose denies the charge of gross negligence manslaughter, and the trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg was found guilty of coercing a woman into engaging in sexual activity and intercourse with a man he found through an adult website, as well as sending sexually explicit material to the victim's sister on Christmas Day. He was placed on the sex offenders register and faced sentencing at the High Court in Edinburgh due to its greater sentencing powers. The judge stated that Weatherhogg, a first offender, posed a moderate risk of sexual re-offending.

Ireland scored 165-5 in a T20 match against Afghanistan, with Stuart Thompson scoring 56 and Gary Wilson adding valuable runs. However, Afghanistan reached 171-4 with two overs to spare, led by Samiullah Shenwari's 56 and Mohammad Shahzad's 47. The teams will meet again in the second T20 on Friday. Ireland lost early wickets but recovered through Thompson and captain William Porterfield before Wilson helped them reach a competitive total. Despite Amir Hamza taking two wickets for Afghanistan, their batters dominated the match. Ireland missed out on a potential higher score and fell short with the ball, according to captain Porterfield.

The Spanish champions, Barcelona, have made a complementary tax declaration of â¬13,550,830.56 in relation to the signing of Neymar. This comes after allegations that the actual cost of the player was far greater than the initially stated Â£48.6m due to other contracts involved in the transfer. Despite this payment, the club denies any wrongdoing and maintains that their original tax payment was in line with fiscal obligations. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances for Barcelona this season.

The bodies of David Miller and Hannah Witheridge were found on a beach in Koh Tao on September 15. UK detectives worked with Thai police, who are holding two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun. The UK police team completed their work and will now compile a report to update the families of the victims. The suspects are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery, facing the death penalty if found guilty. The UK Foreign Office expressed concerns about the police investigation, particularly regarding DNA sample verification and allegations of mistreatment. Post-mortem examinations showed that Miller died from drowning and a head injury, while Witheridge died from head wounds. Thai police stated that DNA found on Witheridge matched samples taken from the suspects.

The Scots have won all their qualifiers and are set to face Iceland in a match that could secure their place in the upcoming major competition. Scottish player Evans is determined not to miss out on the opportunity this time, after previous play-off losses for Euro 2013 and last year's World Cup. With both teams unbeaten, the outcome of Friday's contest and the return fixture in Reykjavik will likely decide who tops the group. Scotland is in a strong position to reach next summer's finals in the Netherlands without needing a play-off.

The passage discusses the issue of third-party software being used to steal intimate photos of celebrities from iCloud and suggests that implementing a two-step verification system could prevent this. Apple has offered the two-step verification system in the past, but it did not come into play when device owners used the firm's back-up service. This allowed cyber-thieves to download complete backups of data using Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. To address this issue, Apple plans to more aggressively encourage people to turn on two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords. However, some experts believe that two-factor authentication should be the default option for all companies, including Apple, Microsoft, and Google.

The passage provides information on the campaign expenditures of various political parties in the UK during the European election campaign period from January 23 to May 22. UKIP won the election, spending Â£2,956,737, while the Tories spent Â£2,980,815. The Lib Dems spent Â£1,580,575 and lost all but one of their MEPs. Labour, which came second, spent Â£1,027,339. The Green Party spent Â£534,249 and came fourth. Including the SNP's expenditure of Â£267,372, the six highest-spending parties spent a total of Â£9,347,087 on campaigning. All parties except Labour spent more than they did during the 2009 European election campaign.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has mutually ended his Barrow contract to join their National League rivals. Striker Keating, 21, recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams, is set to join Gulls after spells with Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps, subject to international clearance. Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson praises Anderson's leadership qualities and Keating's hunger to prove himself. The team currently sits four points above the relegation zone and has won only one of their last six games.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse named Many Clouds collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The horse suffered from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage", which is a rare occurrence in horses with no underlying health issues. Despite previous symptoms of post-race ataxia, Many Clouds had never collapsed before and showed no signs of it during the race. The British Horseracing Authority is determined to understand the causes of these incidents and explore preventive measures.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick and MSPs Duncan McNeil and Alex Salmond are stepping down ahead of the May 5th election. In his valedictory address, Salmond stated that Scotland is "not divided, but diverse" and emphasized the need for the Scottish parliament to assume greater responsibility in governing the country. He also joked about competing with a major event down south and wished everyone in the upcoming election good luck. McNeil warned that Holyrood could learn from Westminster's committee system and stressed the importance of accountability and scrutiny.

Emma Watson will play Belle, Dan Stevens will play the Beast, Kevin Kline will play Maurice, and Luke Evans will play Gaston in the upcoming live-action adaptation of Beauty and the Beast. The film is set to release on March 17, 2017, with Bill Condon directing and Josh Gad as LeFou.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will inform victims' relatives about its intentions regarding charges for 23 suspects related to the Hillsborough stadium disaster in 1989. Ninety-six fans died in the tragedy, and new inquests concluded they were unlawfully killed. The CPS will discuss decisions on 15 suspects connected to the Operation Resolve investigation into the disaster's causes and eight related to an Independent Police Complaints Commission probe into police conduct afterward.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced numerous incidents of packages being thrown over the wall, including mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice acknowledges the issue and is working to improve prevention methods, with the Justice Secretary looking into tools to tackle the problem. A local resident has witnessed packages being thrown over the wall multiple times and the prison is discussing safety measures with nearby residents. There is no evidence of drones being used at the Chelmsford site, but laws have been introduced to punish those who smuggle contraband into prisons with up to two years in jail.

A 72-year-old woman named Sylvia Blackburn was seriously injured outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December after being struck by a car. The driver, 55-year-old Brian Wright, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see Mrs. Blackburn, who was wearing appropriate clothing and acting as a lollipop lady at the time. Wright admits to hitting Mrs. Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. The case is ongoing, with Wright expressing remorse for his actions and the impact they have had on Mrs. Blackburn and her family.

The passage discusses a Scottish middle distance runner's decision to prioritize her veterinary medicine studies over participating in the upcoming Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast. The 24-year-old athlete, who finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, explains that her exams in May conflict with the timing of the Commonwealth Games in April. She expresses her disappointment but emphasizes the importance of completing her degree. The athlete also mentions potentially targeting the World Indoor Championships in March and shares her recent achievements in the 5,000m race, where she set a new outdoor personal best.

Trevor Deely, a 22-year-old man from County Kildare in the Republic of Ireland, went missing in December 2000 after attending a Christmas party. A search operation has begun in an area of Dublin called Chapelizod, which is expected to last several weeks and involve excavations. Earlier this year, a team of detectives conducted a complete review of Mr. Deely's disappearance and enhanced CCTV footage from the night he went missing. The footage shows Mr. Deely talking to a man dressed in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street, where he worked. Detectives believe this man was following Mr. Deely and have renewed their appeal for him to come forward.

Del Potro, ranked 165th, secured a victory over Wawrinka in a thrilling match, winning 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3. The Argentine is playing in his first Grand Slam since the Australian Open in 2014 after having three wrist operations due to injury problems. Del Potro will next play either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. Former US Open champion Del Potro reached the Wimbledon semi-finals in 2013 and feels "amazing" about his recent win. In the same half of the draw as Andy Murray, he may potentially face Nick Kyrgios in the last 16.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints against Caf during the 2015 Nations Cup. Morocco was only able to enter the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw after Cas overturned a ban on its participation. The North Africans were punished for refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup, citing Ebola virus fears. Cas reduced Morocco's FA fine from $1m to $50,000. Equatorial Guinea stepped in to host the 2015 finals. Tunisia and Caf reached an agreement after a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou in mid-March, allowing Tunisia to participate in the 2017 Nations Cup.

The passage discusses the decline of McLaren in Formula 1 and their history of success and challenges. Despite having won 182 grands prix, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, the team is currently struggling. The slump started in 2013 when they lost their way on chassis design but still had the best engine. The partnership with Honda has not been successful, and McLaren is looking to break Mercedes' hegemony in F1. Team principal Ron Dennis believes that it is only a matter of time before success returns, while Fernando Alonso joined the team in 2015 hoping for a chance to win an elusive third title.

Paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven for a sudden death on 6 October 2014. Police found people still at the bar and alcohol being served after licensing hours. The bar was ordered closed for three months, and Colleen O'Neill and James Thomas faced charges for allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. The defense solicitor mentioned that the licensing laws were not strictly followed, and the judge expressed concern about not having the power to impose a custodial sentence. O'Neill received an appalling record and was fined Â£3,000, while Thomas was fined Â£1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points to help the Golden State Warriors defeat the Portland Trail Blazers 116-105. Curry hit eight three-pointers, surpassing his previous record of 272 made in a single season. The Warriors avoided their first three-game losing streak this season with the help of fellow Splash Brothers star Klay Thompson, who scored 26 points. In another game, the Chicago Bulls overcame a 19-point halftime deficit to beat the Miami Heat, dealing a significant blow to Miami's playoff hopes.

Four Liverpool players, Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert and Lazar Markovic, were surprised by Dutch YouTuber Bas Van Velzen, who showcased his free-kick skills at Melwood. They initially believed he was a competition winner but he turned out to be a skilled player. Van Velzen became a YouTube sensation for his free-kick videos and impressed the Liverpool players.

The passage discusses how carriers of the BRCA1 gene, like Angelina Jolie, can reduce their risk of death from breast cancer by having their ovaries removed. A study shows that this procedure cuts the risk of dying from breast cancer by over 60%. Women with a mutated version of BRCA1 or another gene called BRCA2 face a lifetime risk of breast cancer up to 70%, and they also have a high risk of ovarian tumors. The study found a significant drop in breast cancer death in women with a BRCA1 mutation who had an oophorectomy, but not in those with a BRCA2 mutation. Oophorectomies were performed an average of six years after breast cancer diagnosis, and for the 70 BRCA1 carriers who had their ovaries removed within two years, there was a 73% reduction in death compared to women with the mutation who never underwent the procedure. The authors suggest that oophorectomy should become part of the treatment discussion at the time of diagnosis for BRCA mutation carriers with early-stage breast cancers.

A married couple, Derek and Tina Lowe, were struck and killed by an Amtrak train on Easter Sunday in Durham, North Carolina. The train was traveling from Charlotte to New York City when the accident occurred on Norfolk-Southern property. None of the 166 passengers on the train were injured, but a man who fell ill during the delay received treatment. The train was delayed for about two hours and 45 minutes before continuing its journey. It is believed that the couple may have lived in a homeless camp near the tracks.

Carlos Toro, a former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel, worked as an undercover informant for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for US citizenship. He helped take down major drug figures and was one of the DEA's strongest assets. However, he is now facing deportation to Colombia due to declining health forcing him into retirement. Toro fears for his life if he is sent back to Colombia and has not received the promised citizenship. Despite his contributions, the DEA has refused to help him with his citizenship, leaving him in limbo and unable to collect social security benefits.

The US body that regulates internet addresses, ICANN, is investigating a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., for using the new '.sucks' domain name to charge exorbitant fees from celebrities like Kevin Spacey and companies looking to protect their reputations. So far, major brand names such as YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, Yahoo, and Telus Mobility have had their '.sucks' domains purchased. Celebrities like Taylor Swift have also had to spend money defensively to remove their names from adult domains attacking them. ICANN initially approved the top-level domain name but is now backtracking after an advisory panel complained. Vox Populi began accepting registrations using '.sucks' on March 30 from trademark holders and celebrities before it is released to public applicants. The company has recommended charging $2,499 a year for the privilege, and most names have been sold by resellers for around $2,000 a year.

A baby boy's body was found in a pond 27 years ago, and his mother was recently arrested after DNA evidence led the police to her. The woman, who has not been named, was arrested on suspicion of infanticide but later released when she explained that her baby had been stillborn and she had concealed her pregnancy from family and friends. The baby was reburied with a headstone after a support group for parents of stillborn children raised money for it. Police are now satisfied that no one else was involved in the baby's death.

A taxi driver has been ordered to pay compensation to a passenger who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping from a moving car. The passenger, Kristopher Hicks, was in the taxi with his girlfriend when the driver, Michael Young, mistakenly believed he was planning to run away without paying the fare. Young drove Hicks back to the rank in an attempt to teach him a lesson, but Hicks objected and jumped from the vehicle while it was traveling at over 20mph. He now requires constant care and is entitled to damages, which are yet to be decided but expected to be around Â£250,000.

On Wednesday night, tornado sirens sounded in Kansas as multiple storms brought reports of twisters. Spotters reported a tornado about 6 miles northwest of Goddard, which is less than 15 miles west of Wichita. Although the storm missed the city, it posed potential risks to other communities. Severe weather expert Chad Myers warned that nighttime tornadoes are the most deadly and dangerous. Reports of tornadoes also came from southwestern Kansas and Missouri. The National Weather Service indicated a tornado may have touched down in Potosi, Missouri, causing wind damage, flooding, and property destruction. More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

Luke Rockhold is preparing for his fight against Lyoto Machida in New Jersey on Saturday. He aims to win his fourth consecutive victory and secure a title shot. Rockhold plans to be the "bull" and dominate Machida, who he sees as the "matador." He believes that Machida's fighting style has weaknesses that he can exploit, while also acknowledging Machida's skills. Both fighters are coming off victories and are confident in their abilities. The winner of this match may potentially earn a title shot.

A light general aviation aircraft landed on a runway without deploying its landing gear, causing it to skid along the tarmac and damage its propellers. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, managed to take off again and fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale, where he landed safely. The most common cause of such incidents is human error, when the pilot forgets to deploy the landing gear before touchdown. Another possible cause is a mechanical fault in the landing gear system. The FAA is investigating the incident.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini has expressed disappointment in midfielder Yaya Toure's performance this season but will continue to support him until the end of the season. There have been reports that City is willing to listen to offers for Toure as they look to revamp their aging squad. Despite criticism, Toure is determined to stay and Pellegrini plans to back him. Meanwhile, City faces West Ham without captain Vincent Kompany due to injury, and goalkeeper Joe Hart insists the players should take responsibility for their performances.

A man named Domenico Rancadore, who was wanted in Italy for being part of a group called the Mafia, will not be sent back to Italy. He has been living in the UK for over 20 years and was supposed to serve a prison sentence in Italy. However, because too much time has passed since his conviction, he is now allowed to stay in the UK. This decision has upset some people who think it cost a lot of money to try to send him back to Italy.

Mr. Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls and ridden by AP McCoy, is one of three 7-2 co-favorites in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. The race has a seven-runner line-up including Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson's Sprinter Sacre, ridden by Cheltenham Gold Cup winner Nico de Boinville due to Barry Geraghty's injury. This will be AP McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race, with his final day as a professional jockey not yet fully planned. Ironically, it was after winning with Mr. Mole at Newbury in February that McCoy announced his retirement from racing. Other runners in the Celebration Chase include Mick Channon's Somersby.

The mother of a girl who was murdered 40 years ago, Virginia Trimble Ritter, has recently seen crime scene photos of her daughter's body. Her daughter, Marcia, was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. Marcia's body was found 33 days after she disappeared, and Ritter's then-husband advised her against seeing the body and the crime scene photos. Ritter regrets not seeing the photos earlier and now wants revenge. In 2009, Barrett was found guilty of second-degree murder and received a 44-year sentence.

Rory McIlroy believes it is "unthinkable" that he will not win the Masters at some point to complete the career grand slam. He considers his final-round collapse at Augusta National in 2011 as the most important day of his career, from which he learned a lot about himself and his game. McIlroy has only one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances but hopes to complete his grand slam of majors with a victory at Augusta later this month.

The passage covers various trending stories from the week, including four rainbows appearing in the sky after heavy rain in the New York area, a new trend of hiring exotic dancers for wakes in rural China, and actor Ewan McGregor being cast as Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast."
