The advocacy group Glaad analyzed shows between June 2016 and May 2017, finding 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters. The number of transgender characters increased from seven to 16, but over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off. There is a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television due to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. Glaad's study is based on scripted broadcast, cable, and streaming series already being shown or for which casting has been confirmed.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced his decision to not seek re-election ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be opposed. This comes after criticism of his involvement in a loan to Northampton Town FC when he was leader of the borough council. About Â£10.25m of the public money loaned is missing and subject to a police investigation into alleged financial irregularities. The football stand remains half built. A majority of his party's local executive council said they would vote to deselect him.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old former police officer, fired a rifle into a car killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards in Balch Springs, Texas in April. The incident occurred during a response to reports of underage drinking at a house party. Initially, police claimed the vehicle reversed "aggressively" towards the officer, but footage discredited this claim. Oliver was fired for policy violations and charged with four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon by a public official. He faces five to 99 years in prison if convicted of murder. This would be the first police officer convicted of murder in Dallas County since 1973.

The president-elect's wife, Melania Trump, and their son Barron will move to Washington after the school year ends. Some people criticized this decision on social media, but others defended it. There have been other First Ladies in history who did not live in the White House during their husbands' presidencies, such as Martha Washington and Anna Harrison. Families have coped with moving to the White House in different ways in the past, and Melania has said that Barron is her top priority. The role of the First Lady is mainly ceremonial, but some have also taken on public roles and supported causes like education and anti-drug campaigns.

The man died in Inverness on 27 October. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc) is scrutinizing the initial police response to the man's call. Police Scotland is cooperating with the investigation, and a report on the commissioner's findings will be submitted to the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS).

The passage describes a yellow wind warning issued for several counties in the west of the mountains, with gusts up to 75mph possible due to an unusual easterly direction. This may cause disruption to travel on roads and at sea. A tree has already fallen due to the winds, closing a main route into Menai Bridge on Anglesey. Clean-up work is expected to keep the road closed for most of Monday.

The Giants won their opening game against the Panthers with a short-handed goal by Derrick Walser. Jeff Dimmen equalized for the Panthers in the first period. In the second period, Mike Forney scored a powerplay breakaway goal making it 2-1, but Andy Bohmback equalized soon after. Mike Radja and James Desmarais then scored for the Giants, making it 4-2. David Ling of Nottingham got one back before the end of the match. The two teams will face each other again on Saturday night in their second match of the double-header. Currently, Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 points and Belfast with 25 points.

World champion Lewis Hamilton started from the back of the grid, suffered a broken front wing on lap one, and did five pit stops in the Chinese Grand Prix. Despite his efforts, he faces a 36-point deficit in the remaining 18 races of the season. Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel came second after colliding with teammate Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap, while Raikkonen fought back to fifth place. The race was shaped by an incident-packed opening, leading to a safety car being introduced on lap four. Mercedes F1 boss Toto Wolff said Hamilton's car had lost a lot of aerodynamic performance due to damage from his collision with Sauber's Felipe Nasr.

In an interview, former German footballer Thomas Hitzlsperger publicly revealed his homosexuality to advance discussion on the topic in German football. He received support from fellow players and figures in German football administration, with some calling it a courageous step towards fighting homophobia. The announcement is seen as a significant moment in Germany's struggle with homophobia in football.

The passage discusses the achievements of Steve Sidwell, a 34-year-old midfielder who has played a significant role in helping Brighton & Hove Albion achieve promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years. With his contract set to expire, Sidwell expresses his desire to sign a new deal and continue playing for the team. He believes that with their recent success, they can stay in the top flight. Sidwell has previously played in the Premier League for various clubs such as Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham, and Stoke.

In a closely contested match, Blackpool and Colchester United ended with a 1-1 draw. The Seasiders took the lead in the first half with a goal from Jamille Matt, but Colchester equalized soon after. Both teams had chances to score a winning goal, but were denied by impressive saves from the respective goalkeepers. In injury time, Colchester's Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle, leaving the team to finish the game with 10 men.

The 29-year-old player previously made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season during their relegation from League One. He has played for other teams such as Charlton, Bradford, and Preston. He may make his debut for the U's in an upcoming EFL Cup first-round match against Aston Villa. Colchester recently suffered a 3-1 defeat against Accrington in their season opener. For football transfer updates, visit our dedicated page.

The murder of PC Keith Palmer in an attack outside the Houses of Parliament in March has led to a greater emphasis on the need for a permanent memorial. The UK Police Memorial Trust is appealing for Â£1.5m towards its construction at the National Memorial Arboretum, which will bear the names of over 1,400 officers and staff. The memorial, dedicated to the courage and sacrifice of fallen officers over the past 250 years, is expected to be completed by 2019. The government has committed Â£1m towards the Â£4m needed for its construction.

Manchester United won 1-0 against Sunderland, maintaining a 15-point lead at the top of the table with eight games left. Manager Ferguson focuses on upcoming matches and praises the team's record. Injuries occurred during the match, and changes are expected for the FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea.

The passage discusses Google's tax payments in the UK and its stance on taxation. Mr Schmidt, Google's chairman, states that the company follows the law and pays the legally required amount of taxes. He believes it is up to the government to change the tax system if they want companies to pay more. Google paid Â£10m in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011. Margaret Hodge, head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, suggests a new committee to oversee major firms' tax arrangements. Google has been criticized for organizing its tax affairs to minimize UK payments. EU leaders agreed to tackle tax avoidance through an "automatic information exchange between tax authorities." Mr Schmidt argues that corporate taxes should be levied where economic activity and risks occur, rather than where products are consumed, and calls for international tax reform.

NHS Improvement wants to reduce the agency bill by Â£1bn by the end of this financial year, as last year Â£3.6bn was spent on agency staff. A cap introduced in October has saved Â£600m so far, but hospitals are still 10% behind where they want to be. The aim is to reduce overall costs and reliance on agency staff, who are more expensive due to fees and employer costs. NHS Improvement plans to publish league tables of best and worst-performing trusts and collect information on the 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust.

The Longford Town Centre, once a symbol of the Celtic Tiger's economic growth in the Republic of Ireland, now stands as a reminder of the country's economic crash. Local traders, however, see signs of improvement with businesses like Matt O'Brien's men's clothing shop experiencing an increase in sales after a difficult period. Despite this, Fianna FÃ¡il criticizes the government's handling of the midlands region and calls for improvements in areas such as broadband. The government points to investments like the planned Center Parcs tourism development in Ballymahon as evidence of support for County Longford. However, local traders argue that more could be done to boost business, such as providing free parking in the town centre. Overall, while there are signs of economic recovery in the midlands, more efforts are needed to support local businesses and encourage growth.

The competition ends on May 29th and has eight teams competing in a round-robin format, with the top four advancing to the playoffs. BBC Sport provides coverage of scores, fixtures, and results. Four England players are participating: Eoin Morgan, Jos Buttler, Sam Billings, and Kevin Pietersen. Fixtures and results are provided with all times listed in BST.

The number of plastic carrier bags has increased by 200 million since 2013, causing environmental issues such as pollution in landfills and rivers. To address this problem, England will implement a 5p charge for plastic bags starting in October, following the example of supermarkets in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland that have already seen a decrease in bag usage due to similar charges. The goal is to encourage reuse and reduce the number of bags being thrown away, ultimately benefiting the environment.

A school roof was damaged and hundreds of homes experienced power cuts in Wales due to strong winds. Train delays, speed restrictions, and lane closures also occurred on major bridges. The winds were part of a yellow 'be aware' warning that lasted until midnight on Friday. Irish Ferries cancelled six fast sailings between Holyhead and Dublin, while Arriva Trains Wales warned of possible delays and speed restrictions. Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle were closed by the National Trust due to expected high winds. Winds eased in the evening, but a blustery forecast for the Christmas weekend led to the postponement of Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip.

Michael B. Jordan is excited to work with director Ryan Coogler again in the upcoming Black Panther film, and looks forward to working with co-stars Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman. Jordan previously played the Human Torch in Fantastic Four, while Nyong'o won a best supporting actress Oscar for 12 Years a Slave and played Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens. Black Panther is set to release in February 2018.

The theatre, founded in 1875, is set to be restored and used for various events such as theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music. The BBC studios will also be repaired and refurbished. If fundraising efforts are successful, the theatre aims to reopen in 2018 as part of a larger east wing restoration project to transform Alexandra Palace into a new cultural destination. The Heritage Lottery Fund (HLF) and Haringey Council are contributing Â£18.8m and Â£6.8m respectively towards the Â£26.6m project cost. The Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust have committed to raising the final Â£1m by summer 2017.

The passage discusses a former Manchester City player, aged 30, who won 61 caps for England between 2009 and 2016. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships but only played three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps since 2004. He scored his first and only international goal during the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers in a match against Moldova.

A house in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador caught fire, engulfing the entire building. Marcy Smith and her family were able to escape but their dog and cats did not survive. The fire was started by rubbish burned in a wood stove and the alarm did not go off. The community has since supported the family with donations. Marcy Smith is proud of her son David for waking them up and saving their lives.

The energy drinks company is considering a Â£200m offer for the Premier League club, which was valued at Â£105m when Sullivan and Gold bought a majority stake in 2010. They now own over 85% of the club and have been linked with takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups since moving to London Stadium in August. Last year, Sullivan mentioned the possibility of selling a minority shareholding to clear debts but intended for the ownership to eventually pass on to their children.

The passage describes a ceremony where fan-voted awards were given out, including best kiss and best shirtless performance. The Fault in Our Stars won best movie, with Shailene Woodley also winning best female performance and other awards. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for American Sniper, while Channing Tatum and Meryl Streep won awards for their comedic and villainous roles respectively. Other winners included Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, and Rose Byrne. Kevin Hart was honored with the comedic genius award, and Robert Downey Jr received the Generation Award with fellow Avengers stars presenting. Clips from upcoming movies were also shown during the event.

The passage discusses the loaning of a young football player named Smith, aged 21, from Dons to United in July. He has scored five goals this season and previously made his Aberdeen debut in 2012, scoring four times in 89 appearances for the Pittodrie side. St Mirren's boss Jack Ross praises Smith as a brilliant acquisition and believes he will be a good fit for the team, providing another option in the attacking area. St Mirren is set to host Falkirk on Saturday.

The Northumberland County Council is using Jetpatcher machines to fill 145 potholes daily for the next four months due to warm weather. Additionally, extra staff will repair damaged drainage systems and clear debris from gutters caused by heavy rain.

In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors working on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland were exposed to low levels of alpha radiation while removing pipework during shutdown activities. The workers were not wearing proper personal protective equipment and have since faced health concerns, including potential cancer risks. EnQuest claims the exposure was less than 1% of the reportable level and has taken additional precautionary steps. Wood Group maintains a commitment to employee safety and conducted medical assessments following the incident. The Health and Safety Executive was informed but did not investigate as the incident was not reportable under current regulations.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) bought a stolen bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 in 2007 from Art of the Past, which later admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities. The allegations were revealed during a 2012 court case against the firm for trafficking antiquities. The sculpture is believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India. After discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and India's Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), the ACM decided to return the sculpture. The ASI submitted an official request for its return in May. ACM will take legal action to seek compensation for the apparent fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca, Italy at a depth of 15.5km, with no immediate reports of injuries or damage. The tremor was felt in Milan and Florence, and several aftershocks were reported. Phone lines and power supplies were disrupted in the Garfagnana area, and schools were evacuated for safety checks. This earthquake serves as a reminder of Italy's vulnerability to seismic activity, as seen in the 2009 L'Aquila quake that killed nearly 300 people.

The passage describes a situation where Austin Grant from Sheffield had doubts about the suitability of South Yorkshire's climate for growing fruit. However, he has finally seen some positive results as the fruit is still attached to the plant and not yet ripe enough to eat. The 62-year-old grandfather expresses his excitement by saying he was "literally jumping for joy."

The game's release has been delayed until 24 March due to the need for extra testing and polish. Online heists will be available on consoles before the PC release date, with screenshots from the PC version showing greater detail and support for up to 4K resolution and triple monitor configurations. Minimum specifications required to run GTA V have also been published.

The 76-year-old artist, shortlisted in 1991, won the Â£25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his work Squint (19) at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. Judge Ansel Krut described the painting as "quite extraordinary" and "a little bit like a tone poem." The artwork depicts a leper squint, with Simpson explaining that it was one of a series of paintings he has been working on. The prize money will be spent on art materials. The biennial John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with previous winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig.

The daily Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit newspaper offices were attacked by four masked assailants. No casualties were reported, but the buildings' windows were shattered and spent bullet casings were found at both scenes. Both papers support President Erdogan's AK Party. Police have cordoned off the area and are searching for the attackers, but no group has claimed responsibility yet.

A 24-year-old football player, previously contracted with the Stags, is set to join Marcus Bignot's team on a free transfer. He played for Crawley on loan earlier this season, scoring three goals in 23 appearances. The former Burton player will officially become part of the Mariners on January 1st and is Bignot's first signing for the team.

The passage discusses ArsÃ¨ne Wenger's views on Gareth Southgate potentially becoming the permanent manager of the England national football team. Wenger, who is currently the manager of Arsenal, believes that Southgate has gained valuable experience and is a good observer of the national team's situation. Wenger focuses on his own job and does not directly address the rumors linking him to the role. Southgate will have a chance to prove his competency in the upcoming World Cup qualifier against Scotland and a friendly match against Spain. Additionally, Wenger mentions that Hector Bellerin and Aaron Ramsey are important players for Arsenal, with Bellerin being offered a new contract and Ramsey expected to miss one or two more games due to injury.

Summary: A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker around 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are conducting a joint inquiry, with the company's full cooperation.

The Transport Minister announced a new charter arrangement to resolve the seafarers' pay dispute on two freight boats. The RMT union claimed workers were paid less than Â£4 an hour, and the change will see contracted out services return to operator Serco Northlink. Seatruck, which operates the vessels, argued that the national minimum wage was not applicable to its non-UK resident crew members. Serco Northlink offered to bridge the pay gap but was declined by Seatruck. The new arrangements will be implemented next month, ensuring all crew members are paid at least the minimum wage.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in the hospital on May 14 after an incident at Rockley Park site in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted to intervening in an argument between Mr. Dickie and his mother. The trial revealed that Mr. Mitchell and Mrs. Mitchell had been in a relationship for years and were going through a rough patch when the incident occurred. On May 7, Mr. Mitchell accompanied his mother and Mr. Dickie to the holiday park bar and got intoxicated. A confrontation ensued between the two men, resulting in Mr. Mitchell pleading guilty to common assault. Both he and his mother also admitted to attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying about the events. They will be sentenced on February 6.

Rod Temperton, a renowned songwriter known for his work with Michael Jackson and Heatwave, has passed away at the age of 66 after a brief battle with cancer. Temperton wrote several hits for Jackson including Off The Wall, Rock With You, and Thriller. He also penned songs for other artists such as Anita Baker, Donna Summer, Aretha Franklin, and The Brothers Johnson. Temperton won a Grammy Award in 1990 and was nominated for two Oscars in 1986.

A team of researchers from Swansea University, the universities of Exeter and Reading, and Brazil's SÃÂ£o Paulo and BelÃ©m discovered over 450 ancient earthworks, or "geoglyphs," in the western Brazilian Amazon. The geoglyphs are possibly 2,000 years old and were concealed for centuries by bamboo-dominated rainforest until modern deforestation revealed them. The purpose of these sites is still unknown, but they are unlikely to be villages as few artifacts have been found during excavation. Researchers believe they may have been used sporadically as ritual gathering places. Dr. Neil Loader analyzed soil samples to reconstruct ancient vegetation and found that the geoglyphs were likely constructed amongst taller vegetation, not visible above the forest canopy. This challenges previous assumptions that the Amazonian forests were pristine ecosystems before the arrival of Europeans in the early 16th century. Instead, it appears humans transformed their environment by focusing on economically valuable trees such as palms, creating a "prehistoric supermarket" of useful

Australian tennis player Nick Kyrgios, ranked 12th in the world, won his match against Sam Querrey (world number 29) with a score of 6-4 6-4 in just 53 minutes. Despite his victory, Kyrgios admitted to being bored and tired during the match, attributing it to fatigue from winning the Japan Open and the travel involved in reaching the Qi Zhong Stadium in Shanghai. Last year, Kyrgios was fined $1,500 for an outburst at the same tournament.

The passage discusses the push for the human papilloma virus (HPV) vaccine to be extended to boys in Wales, as it is currently only given to girls aged 12 and 13 to protect against cervical cancer. Scientists and charities argue that the vaccine can also protect against head and neck cancers, which are increasingly affecting younger people, particularly men. The Welsh government is waiting for advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making a decision on whether to extend the vaccination program.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old suffering from a rare form of blood cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, passed away. He had been documenting his life and treatment on social media under the page "Jak's Journey" and gained support from thousands of people in West Lothian and beyond. Jak briefly attended his school prom but left due to feeling unwell. His family collected awards on his behalf at the event. Despite receiving news that his cancer had spread throughout his body and doctors deciding not to pursue further treatment, Jak remained positive and continued to share his experiences with others. In honor of Jak, a special football match will be held to raise money for charity.

In a closely contested match, Egypt managed to secure a 1-0 victory over Uganda with a late goal from Abdallah El Said, assisted by Mohamed Salah. The win means Egypt will face Ghana in their next match, while Uganda is out of the tournament.

Lancashire County Council has identified land at the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for potential development. The council, in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, plans to establish a railway station in Skelmersdale, which could provide two direct trains per hour to Liverpool. The decision follows a comparative study of sites near the Concourse shopping center. The selected location is large enough for future expansion and offers good highway access and connectivity. The authority will now begin acquiring the necessary land.

Summary:
Plants were discovered in an elaborate grow house during a warehouse search near Ashbourne on Saturday. A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

A 28-year-old woman in Hamelin, Lower Saxony was found with serious injuries after being dragged by the neck through several streets. She underwent an emergency operation and was flown to a specialist clinic. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old man from nearby Bad Muender, later handed himself in to authorities. Both the victim and the suspect are German citizens of Kurdish origin. The motive for the attack is not yet clear, and police have secured the area where the woman was found, calling for witnesses to come forward.

The Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin conducted a study on 4,600 workers that found women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise but less likely to receive one. The study eliminated the impact of part-time workers earning less than full-time counterparts by comparing full-time males with full-time females and part-time males with part-time females. When like-for-like male and female workers were compared, men were 25% more likely to get a pay rise when they asked. The researchers took into account factors such as employer size, industry, parental status, and qualifications. The study was based on data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey.

The Oxford City Council has been searching for a new burial site for years, but suitable land within the city is scarce. Money has been used for ground investigations of possible sites, but none have been found. Two cemeteries still have space, but they are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021. After these cemeteries are full, only reopening family plots, using reserved plots, and interment of ashes will be possible. The last increase in burial space was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival will have an app that lets visitors access online information about the event, including videos and band interviews. It takes place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, with acts like The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Lucy Spraggan. The festival director, Caroline Maclennan, says the new augmented reality experience is an extra feature for attendees and allows people worldwide to interact with the festival and get a feel for its atmosphere.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse named Many Clouds collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The horse suffered from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage", which is a rare occurrence in horses with no underlying health issues. The British Horseracing Authority is determined to understand the cause of these symptoms and explore preventive measures. Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia but had never collapsed before. Trainer Oliver Sherwood described him as the "horse of a lifetime".

In 2004, a 15-year-old girl met David Ayrton in a Portsmouth garage and was later raped by him while two others slept nearby. The defendant, now known as Davina, denied the charge and will be sentenced on March 4th. Judge Ian Pearson remanded her into custody, stating that she would likely be held at a male prison due to substantial risks if released on bail. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties, attempted suicide last summer and spoke about her sexuality during the trial. She changed her name in 2012 and confessed to the attack in 2014 to a care home worker.

The Serbian tennis team, including world number one Novak Djokovic, lost to Brazil's Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in the Rio Olympics. This loss occurred a day after Djokovic was defeated by Argentine Juan Martin del Potro in singles competition. Despite a surprise defeat at Wimbledon in July, Djokovic went on to win his 30th Masters title in Toronto prior to the Olympics.

The passage describes a chainsaw carving competition taking place in Carrbridge, Cairngorms on Saturday. Over 20 competitors from various countries will participate, using only chainsaws to carve logs into animal and human shapes. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher, will return to defend his title and compete for the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, a 27-year-old rugby player, has not played since September due to a serious foot injury. He is close to returning and getting fit for the Six Nations in February. Webb has renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down offers from other teams. He stated that he wants to put himself in the best possible position to play for his country and is happy to stay with his home region. Wales begins their Six Nations campaign away to Ireland on Sunday, 7 February.

On Tuesday, US border agents encountered two men carrying backpacks containing 58lb of ecstasy near Sumas, Washington. One man fired at the agents and fled while the other, Jeffrey Laviolette, was taken into custody. Canadian and US police searched for the fugitive and arrested Nathan Hall in British Columbia. Kali Henifin and Ryan Lambert were also arrested for planning to transport the drugs to San Francisco. The area is a known smuggling route for drugs and firearms. All three defendants face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges.

The NSPCC's Childline service has seen a significant increase in the number of children seeking help for online abuse, with over 4,500 counselled in the past year compared to 2,400 in 2011-12. The true number of victims is believed to be much higher. Children as young as seven have reported being tormented, abused, and scared to go to school due to online trolls. Childline's president, Dame Esther Rantzen, warns that bullying can ruin young people's lives and calls for adults, parents, and teachers to intervene. Schools must take this issue seriously, and children should ask for help. The Anti-Bullying Alliance is coordinating efforts to combat cyberbullying during Anti-Bullying Week.

The Israeli government has postponed a vote on authorising new homes in settlements in East Jerusalem, following a request from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office. This comes ahead of a speech by US Secretary of State John Kerry on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and after the US abstained from vetoing a UN Security Council resolution calling for an end to settlement construction. The decision to abstain angered Mr Netanyahu, who accused the White House of helping draft the language of the resolution and pushing for its passage. The Security Council resolution stated that the establishment of settlements "has no legal validity and constitutes a flagrant violation under international law". Israel rejected the resolution and summoned ambassadors of the countries that voted in favour.

In a BBC interview, Prince William paid tribute to Queen Elizabeth II on the eve of her 90th birthday, calling her a "guiding example" of what a good monarch should be. The Queen and Prince Philip met staff and viewed an exhibition at Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office to mark the occasion. The royals also opened a new bandstand in Alexandra Gardens and met pupils from six schools involved in its decoration. Prime Minister David Cameron and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn expressed their admiration for the Queen at Prime Minister's Questions. Ten stamps have been released to celebrate the Queen's birthday, featuring four generations of the Royal Family. On her actual birthday, the Queen will walk around Windsor and unveil a plaque marking The Queen's Walkway, a self-guided walking trail connecting 63 points of significance.

In a football match, West Ham United played against Cheltenham Town and won 2-0. Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew scored goals for West Ham United in the first half. Both teams had chances to score more goals, but in the end, West Ham United was the better team and moved on to the next round of the EFL Cup.

A man named Aidan McNicholl died in a car accident because another man, Andreas Werner, didn't see him while turning his car. Andreas said he was sorry and that it was an accident. The people in Aidan's family didn't want Andreas to go to jail. The judge made Andreas pay money and not drive in the UK for two years.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old British jihadist from Southall, west London, is facing life imprisonment for his involvement in the Syrian conflict. He was an active member of Rayat al Tawheed, a group affiliated with Islamic State that targeted young British Muslims through slick propaganda videos and appeals for donations. Khawaja's intentions upon returning to the UK are unclear, but he attempted to fake his own death and conceal his entry into the country. He has admitted to four offences and is considered extremely dangerous.

Summary:
Kayden Jackson, 22, has joined Barnsley as their third signing for the upcoming season after scoring four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season. He will be playing in the League One play-off final at Wembley on Sunday. Caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom praises Jackson's pace and ability to get past defenders, saying he will fit well into the team's style of play. Jackson declined a contract offer from Wrexham for the next season.

Bottles of Vanish detergent have washed up on Poldhu Cove and other nearby coves in Cornwall, posing a risk to wildlife. National Trust volunteers are clearing the bottles away, but some have already leaked. It is believed that a container went overboard from a ship during stormy weather, and while the MV Blue Ocean lost a container containing Vanish bottles near Land's End in May, there is no direct evidence linking these bottles to that incident. The impact on sensitive marine life is a major concern, and authorities including the Maritime and Coastguard Agency and Natural England will be monitoring the affected beaches. The public is advised to keep children and dogs at a safe distance from the bottles and not attempt to recover them.

Summary:
An incident occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness around 14:00, resulting in minor injuries to several people. The road was closed and diversions were set up through the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland is currently investigating the incident.

Dervite, a French centre-back, made 14 appearances last season to help Wanderers finish second in League One and secure promotion. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances in all competitions. Manager Phil Parkinson praised Dervite's contribution towards the end of the campaign. Dervite is among several players, including David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan, who have signed new contracts with Bolton following their promotion to the Championship.

The passage discusses the conflict between the Liberal Democrats (Lib Dems) and Labour Party in the UK, particularly regarding their differing stances on Brexit. The two parties had previously teamed up to challenge the government on issues related to EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal, but this cooperation ended when MPs rejected the proposed amendments. Lib Dem Lord Oates accused Labour of being prepared to "concede everything," while Baroness Smith, the opposition's leader in the Lords, said her party was giving people "false hope." A Labour source criticized the Lib Dems for grandstanding and building false hope, while the Lib Dems accused Labour of supporting the government's hard Brexit plans. Despite these tensions, both parties have a history of forming alliances on various issues, and there may be future opportunities for cooperation.

This passage discusses the UK's defense priorities and military capabilities in light of upcoming elections. Most political parties are not focusing on defense, as it is not a top concern for voters. The UK has been making significant cuts to its armed forces, and its commitment to spend 2% of its GDP on defense is in question. The future government will likely have to make more cuts in defense spending, but there is no consensus on how much or where those cuts should be made. The nuclear deterrent program and plans for new aircraft carriers also face potential changes and challenges.

The Spanish football club Barcelona has made a payment of â¬13.5m ($15.7m) to the Spanish authorities in relation to the transfer of Neymar from Santos in 2013. This is due to allegations that the original fee paid for the player was under-reported, leading to potential tax evasion. The club denies any wrongdoing and maintains that they have fulfilled their fiscal obligations. The case is ongoing, and it remains unclear whether the payment will result in the case being dropped.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old man from Nottingham, died in a motorway accident when a Mazda Premacy, driven by 84-year-old Albert Kenneth Newman who was going the wrong way, collided with the van he was a passenger in. The family of Mr. Luciw called for regular driving tests for retired people, while Age UK emphasized the importance of older people being able to drive for as long as possible. Currently, drivers over 70 in the UK must renew their licenses every three years through self-assessment without a medical or driving test. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) has no plans to restrict licensing based on age, stating that evidence does not show older drivers are more likely to cause serious accidents.

The passage discusses concerns over the safety of implants used to treat incontinence, with many women reporting debilitating side effects. An independent review recommended that procedures should not be routinely offered to women with pelvic organ prolapse and suggested a range of treatments with informed choice. Despite calls for a ban, the recommendations will still be implemented. The chairwoman of the independent review apologized for failing to unite panel members around the final report. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have had mesh or tape implants, with some suffering complications, leading to legal action against health boards and manufacturers.

Laura Muir broke Eilish McColgan's 25-year-old British indoor 5,000m record by 14 seconds with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow. McColgan initially raised concerns about whether Muir's race met all the criteria for record-breaking attempts but later confirmed that her time was expected to be classified as official. Muir has the ability to run even faster and is considered world-class by McColgan.

Jung won on Sam, replacing Fischertakinou who had an infection. Astier Nicolas of France took silver and Phillip Dutton of the US won bronze. William Fox-Pitt finished 12th after a coma due to a fall. He led after dressage but dropped to 21st after cross country penalties. Jonty Evans finished ninth on Cooley Rorkes Drift.

In a tennis match, Andy Murray won against Fabio Fognini after two hours and 39 minutes, securing a place in the last 16. The match was tense and had some up and down moments, with Murray managing to win five games in a row to avoid a fifth set. He will face Frenchman Benoit Paire in the fourth round on Monday. Johanna Konta also reached the second week of the competition for the first time after defeating Maria Sakkari.

Paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven for a sudden death on 6 October 2014. Police found people still at the bar, with alcohol being served until 04:49 BST. The bar was ordered closed for three months due to licensing violations. Colleen O'Neill and James Thomas faced charges for allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. The judge expressed concern about the premises not being run properly and Ms. O'Neill's appalling record. Both were fined, with Ms. O'Neill receiving a Â£3,000 fine and Mr. Thomas receiving a Â£1,000 fine.

The Ulster Unionist Party's manifesto, 'Real Partnership', focuses on tackling waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, prioritizing the York Street interchange, standing up for the LGBT community, and ensuring no group is worse off due to Brexit. Party leader Mike Nesbitt emphasizes the importance of partnership over domination and wants the election to be a referendum on the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle. Despite controversy over his comments about transferring votes to the SDLP, Nesbitt remains confident in his position and believes voters will consider issues such as incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and corruption when casting their ballots.

The Justice Minister of Northern Ireland, Claire Sugden, has confirmed that a motion will be presented to the assembly for approval. This motion aims to bring Northern Ireland in line with England and Wales by introducing automatic pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences. Named 'Turing's Law' after World War Two code-breaker Alan Turing, it allows posthumous pardons for those who were convicted and also enables living men to apply for a pardon. The motion is expected to contain similar provisions and allow for pardons both posthumously and for living gay and bisexual men. The minister has secured executive agreement to ask the assembly to pass a legislative consent motion to pardon convictions related to abolished sexual offences. Ms Sugden stated that arrangements would be implemented as soon as possible to ensure equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland, just like their counterparts in England and Wales.

The passage discusses the achievement of Scottish runner Laura Muir, who finished second in a 1500m race with a time of 4:19.12, breaking Yvonne Murray's 1994 Scottish record and moving to second on the British all-time list. Muir now holds both the Scottish 1500m and mile records. She is excited about her performance and hopes to secure an Olympics place for Great Britain in Rio at the British trials in Birmingham from 24 to 26 June. Muir fits her training around her veterinary studies and recently completed her fourth year of vet school.
Summary: The passage mentions pictures of 26 beaches in Scotland with excellent water quality.

The passage discusses the case of Alexander Litvinenko, who was poisoned with radioactive substance polonium-210 in London in 2006. UK officials believe suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi were responsible for his death, but they deny any wrongdoing. Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC stated that the Russian state likely sponsored the plot and had motives to wish Litvinenko harm or death. He added that the fact polonium caused Litvinenko's death suggests Russian state participation. However, he clarified that this does not implicate Russian President Vladimir Putin directly. Litvinenko had defected to the UK in 2000 after accusing the FSB of murder and corruption, which could have been seen as an act of treachery. Mr Horwell also mentioned that the risk to the public from polonium radiation will never be known, and that Litvinenko had been poisoned twice before his death. The suspects left a trail of polonium and had no credible answer to the scientific evidence against them. Attempts to extr

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed as the new captain of the Australian cricket team for both one-day and Twenty20 formats. He will replace Michael Clarke, who retired after the recent Ashes series. David Warner, 28, has been named as Smith's vice-captain despite his history of disciplinary issues. The appointments were made by national selector Rod Marsh, who praised Smith's talent and leadership qualities.

The passage discusses a person's stance on LGBT-plus rights and equal marriage. They are passionate about defending these rights and believe that equal access under law should be provided to all people, regardless of their sexuality. However, when asked if they believed homosexual sex was a sin, they refused to give a direct answer, stating that "we are all sinners." They also mentioned their support for extending marital rights for transgender people. In the past, they voted against the Equality Bill in 2007 due to concerns about protection of individual liberties but now firmly stand for equality.

Accord Healthcare will be using the former Sanofi drug manufacturing site in Fawdon for its pharmaceutical production, potentially hiring ex-Sanofi staff. The investment is expected to have a positive impact on the area and strengthen Newcastle's reputation as a hub for science and healthcare. Accord Healthcare is a global company that develops, manufactures, and distributes over 130 pharmaceutical products to around 60 countries worldwide.

Richard Ellis, Ciaran Monaghan, and Ewan Sutherland are leaving their positions at the local authority. Ellis is departing due to the end of his contract, while Monaghan and Sutherland are taking advantage of a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. The opposition SNP group leader, Stephen Flynn, believes these departures indicate the council's difficulty in retaining senior staff and expects more to come. Ellis was previously the interim director of corporate governance and deputy chief executive. Monaghan served as head of the chief executive's office, and Sutherland was head of human resources and customer services. Council chief executive Angela Scott expressed gratitude for their dedication and professionalism.

The English rider crashed at this year's TT and experienced mechanical problems with the Fireblade bike. He initially announced quitting road racing but later clarified his position on Facebook, stating he has no plans to do any more road racing on the Hondas this year. He did not race at the North West 200 and will not compete in next month's Ulster Grand Prix. The rider mentioned that he didn't enjoy the TT, as it turned into a test rider role for him. After testing at Cadwell, he expressed concerns about the bike's competitiveness at the Ulster Grand Prix, leading to his withdrawal from the event. The rider now wants to focus on racing classics and oddball stuff.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governor posts in recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the People's Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari will be inaugurated on May 29th after defeating President Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP lost control in key northern states and managed to hold onto Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The APC made historic gains while the PDP failed to get a national spread of votes, doing well only in the south-east and the oil-rich Niger Delta.

Mighty, a US-based environmental lobby group, has accused Singapore-based agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main stakeholder, Singapore state-owned investment company Temasek, of turning a blind eye to unsustainable palm oil trading practices that may contribute to haze caused by fires. Both companies reject the allegations. Olam buys 99% of its palm oil from third party suppliers and accounts for less than 1% of the global market. Mighty claims Olam and Temask could be unwittingly encouraging unsustainable practices through their supply chain. Temasek dismissed the allegations, stating they fully support no-burn policies for land clearance. The palm oil industry is often accused of deforestation, burning of plantations, and unfair labor practices.

Summary:
A restaurant started serving puppy platters following a new law that permits dogs to dine at outdoor restaurants.

Summary:
Forward Fernando Forestieri is a doubt due to his knee injury, while David Nugent may return from his groin injury. Jacob Butterfield hopes for a recall after scoring the late equalizer against Huddersfield.

Pakistan's telecoms regulator has lifted a ban on YouTube after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version of the site. The ban was initially imposed in 2012 due to an anti-Islam film. While many young Pakistanis have welcomed the move, some activists are calling for greater transparency regarding the terms agreed between Google and the government. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) will make requests for blocking offending material directly to Google, which will then restrict access for users within Pakistan if content is deemed illegal.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding Domenico Scala, head of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, and his potential conflict of interest due to sharing nationality with one of the presidential candidates, Gianni Infantino. Musa Bility, LFA boss, threatens to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday. The election to replace Sepp Blatter as FIFA president will take place in 18 days, and five candidates are competing for the position.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed at Harford Attachments in Spar Road on Monday. They are believed to have been working in a paint-spraying area when a flashover explosion occurred due to a build-up of toxic fumes and an ignition source. The men's bodies were removed on Tuesday afternoon, and a forensic search has been conducted at the company, which makes digger buckets. Significant progress has been made with forensic inquiries and witness statements. The Health and Safety Executive is also gathering evidence.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints against Caf during the 2015 Nations Cup but apologized, allowing their participation. Morocco was banned from the 2017 Nations Cup for refusing to host the 2015 event but had the ban overturned by Cas. Both countries are now preparing for a bright future in African football. Tunisia's participation in the 2017 Nations Cup was uncertain until a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou led to a resolution of their issues. Tunisia will face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A while Morocco will play Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F.

In a game at Etihad Stadium, Chelsea won 3-1 against Manchester City. During the match, Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho from City were sent off, while Cesc Fabregas from Chelsea faced no further action. Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's involvement in an incident. Aguero received a four-match ban for violent conduct, and Fernandinho got a three-match ban. Both clubs have until December 8th to respond to the charge.

The passage discusses a pilot scheme in the Cynon Valley and Neath Port Talbot area that focuses on early cancer diagnosis for patients without clear symptoms. The scheme was inspired by a visit to Denmark, which has improved its cancer survival rates. The concern is that some patients in Wales with unclear symptoms may have to wait too long for diagnosis, leading to delayed treatment. The hope is that the pilot will help reduce waiting times and improve early detection. A similar clinic will be established at Neath Port Talbot Hospital as part of another trial by the Abertawe Bro Morgannwg University Health Board. The project was developed over 12 months by Welsh experts returning from Aarhus. Denmark's success in establishing diagnostic centers prompted concerns about Wales' position regarding cancer survival rates. Dr. Gareth Davies, Director of the Wales Cancer Network, believes the plan will alleviate patient anxiety and speed up the process. If successful, the pilot could make a significant difference in patients' lives and lead to faster diagnoses.

England won by a big margin against Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series. Joe Root was named man of the match for his outstanding performance, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second. England's captain, Alastair Cook, praised Root's responsible play at number three. Pakistan struggled in both innings, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 in the first two Tests. The series is expected to be tight, but England is confident after their strong performance.

Head coach Warren Gatland leads the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand, with interim coach Rob Howley as part of his team. Forwards coach McBryde will assume head coach responsibilities for the third time, having led Wales on previous tours in 2009 and 2013. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour to assist McBryde. WRU chief executive Martyn Phillips hopes to confirm the full management team next week. Union chairman Gareth Davies believes the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit the national team, providing a summer of opportunity for Welsh rugby in the years ahead.

Hull City secured their first league win since 20 August, ending a six-game losing streak with a 2-1 victory over Southampton. Charlie Austin's penalty put Southampton in control early on, but Hull made a quickfire double just after the hour mark through Snodgrass and Dawson to turn the game around. Despite late pressure from Southampton, Hull held on for the win, with Clucas making a remarkable goalline clearance in the final minute of added time.

A motorcyclist was killed in a collision with a tractor on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, Lincolnshire. The incident occurred around 14:15 BST. The motorcyclist was a local resident, but no further details have been released by the police. The tractor driver was unharmed. Lincolnshire Police are seeking witnesses to the crash and have closed the B1191 between Woodhall Spa and Horncastle.

The President of Macedonia has cancelled an investigation into claims of abuse of power revealed by covert recordings, in order to "put an end to the agony" before early elections in June. This move has been condemned by both the opposition and EU officials. The crisis was sparked by recordings that appear to show ministers plotting vote-rigging and the cover-up of a murder. Opposition leader Zoran Zaev has been releasing these recordings since February 2015, accusing the government of wiretapping 20,000 people and revealing corruption at the highest levels of government. The government denies these accusations and accuses Mr. Zaev of trying to destabilize the nation.

Swansea City's assistant manager, Alan Curtis, and Paul Williams will take charge of the upcoming match against Bournemouth after the sacking of Bob Bradley. The club aims to appoint a new manager as soon as possible, with former Derby manager Paul Clement being their top choice. Curtis believes that the current squad is good enough to avoid relegation but emphasizes the importance of stability in management and retaining key players. He also highlights the need for the team to regain its identity, known as the "Swansea Way," which has been diluted since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014.

Dagenham & Redbridge were relegated from League One after losing to Leyton Orient, who kept their play-off hopes alive. The Daggers needed a win to maintain their survival chances but ultimately returned to the National League under manager John Still. Despite reaching the Football League for the first time in 2007, Dagenham now has the worst goal difference in League Two and has conceded 20 more goals this season than last. Meanwhile, Leyton Orient is two points away from the play-off spots after sacking player-manager Kevin Nolan and appointing Andy Hessenthaler as interim manager.

Former Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard is returning to the club as a youth coach in February, following his retirement as a player. Gerrard, 36, has expressed interest in becoming a manager in the future and is currently working towards his UEFA A coaching license. Liverpool manager JÃ¼rgen Klopp praised Gerrard's appointment and believes he has a bright future in management due to his playing experience and willingness to learn.

McManus scored early in the game to open the scoring, followed by a deflected strike from Ross Forbes that doubled Morton's lead. Alloa attempted a comeback with a shot by Kyle McAusland before half-time, but McManus and Denny Johnstone secured a comfortable win for the hosts with their late goals.

Ofsted found evidence of children being taught in poor conditions in three places in Birmingham, which have now closed. Anyone running an unregistered school could face jail time. The government is consulting on plans to regulate places teaching for more than 6 to 8 hours a week. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools in England, said the cases found were likely just the "tip of the iceberg" and expressed concern about children being at risk of abuse or radicalization. Ofsted has closed three places in Birmingham and is investigating the owners under suspicion of running an illegal school. A team of six inspectors has been funded by the government to investigate unregistered schools. The Education Secretary intends to prepare cases for prosecution against unregistered schools identified by Ofsted.

Lilliard Gin is a small-scale gin distillery located at the Born in the Borders visitor center in Jedburgh, Scottish Borders. It is the region's first gin distillery since 1837 and aims to make the Scottish Borders a "region of distilling excellence." The gin is made using local botanicals from the Teviot valley and is named after a legendary Borders figure, Lilliard, who fought in the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545. The distillery's lead, Kate Macinnes, hopes that people will appreciate the local flavor palette and Borders 'terroir' captured in their gin.

In August 2013, Harry Whitlam was fatally struck by a reversing vehicle driven by Gary Green, who was over the legal driving limit and had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer. The incident occurred at Swithens Farm, Rothwell, near Leeds. Green was jailed for 16 months and two weeks after admitting to failing to ensure the safety of others. The case was prosecuted under health and safety legislation as it took place on private land. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed her hope that her son's life would be remembered beyond the tragic accident and that the family could cherish their memories of him.

Luis Suarez can now train and play in friendly matches with Barcelona, following a Cas ruling that allowed him to take part in all "football-related activities". However, he still cannot play in "organised" matches and must serve the remaining eight games of his nine-match ban in competitive international games. His competitive debut for Barcelona is expected to be against Real Madrid on 26 October. Suarez's lawyers argued that Fifa's punishment was too strong, but Cas ruled it as generally confirmed.

Richard Blake-Smith and Anna won a race against Vytautas Kirkliauskas and Neringa Kirliauskiene by completing a 380-meter course with hurdles, a steep slope, and water pistols. They will compete in the World Championships in Finland in July.

The paper system for car tax discs will be scrapped in October and replaced with an electronic system, potentially affecting job roles at the Driving and Vehicle Licensing Agency center. Minister Stephen Hammond assured that any reductions in staff will be managed through redeployment to other growth areas of the business. The new system will allow people to pay the charge by monthly direct debit, which may lead to a natural reduction in refunds received and changes to job roles due to new processes.

The passage discusses Hungary's response to EU objections regarding the country's tight controls on asylum seekers, NGOs, and a higher education law. Hungary's Foreign Minister states that the country will not backtrack on these issues and believes that European institutions should refrain from interfering with domestic matters. Poland has promised to veto any move to strip Hungary of its EU voting rights. The passage also mentions the potential closure of the Central European University due to the higher education law and the expected draft legislation on NGOs.

Emma Watson will play Belle, Dan Stevens will play the Beast, and Luke Evans will play Gaston in the upcoming live-action adaptation of Beauty and the Beast. The film is set to release on 17 March 2017 in US cinemas, with Bill Condon directing.

A columnist for the Sunday Times named Adrian Gill had been diagnosed with a type of cancer called "the full English" and had been receiving chemotherapy. He wrote about his experience with the illness in his final column, which will be published in the newspaper. Gill was known for his wit, writing style, and fearless reporting. He had worked for the Sunday Times since 1993 and was considered a giant among journalists. Gill also faced controversy due to some of his writings and comments, but he was still respected by many fellow writers and journalists. He passed away after battling his illness, leaving behind a legacy as an extraordinary and unique writer.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper known as Amraa, was allegedly attacked on stage during a performance in Ulan Bator. He was reportedly hit over the head with a bottle and kicked in the face. The Russian embassy is investigating but claims local press reports are "distorted." Amraa wore a traditional Mongolian robe embroidered with a swastika, a symbol that pre-dates Hitler in Mongolia. His father stated that he spent 10 days in a coma after the attack and displayed a book of traditional swastika patterns to emphasize it is not a hate symbol in Mongolia. The Russian official accused of the attack has not been identified, and the Russian embassy denies any wrongdoing.

Plane Stupid campaigners protested against the airport's expansion plans on Monday, resulting in charges of aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area. The protest occurred on the northern runway at 03:30 BST, and the demonstrators will appear in court on 19 August. In response to the incident, the Metropolitan Police announced a review of airport security.

Nick Selman scored a century for Glamorgan, but seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles ensured wickets fell regularly in cloudy conditions. Gloucestershire struggled against the bowlers, and the match ended evenly balanced. Selman's performance was a welcome return to form after a string of low scores, while Taylor and Miles performed well in the afternoon. The day ended with Glamorgan reaching a consolation bonus point.

Craig Hughes, a 33-year-old man from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police after chatting online with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. He admitted to planning a false report to lure police officers and then shoot them on the Dee Estuary. The threats were made while Hughes was drunk and on two occasions late at night. He has a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009. Hughes's legal team stated he had no intention of killing himself or carrying out his threats against police officers. He will be sentenced next week.

Surrey defeated Yorkshire by 19 runs in a cricket match, with Davies and Ben Foakes scoring 130 runs together. Yorkshire's run-chase was disrupted by Stuart Meaker, who took three wickets in nine balls. Despite Tim Bresnan's 68, Yorkshire was all out for 236. Surrey captain Gareth Batty praised the team's performance, while Yorkshire captain Alex Lees expressed disappointment in their loss.

The passage describes a 56ft trawler that was 6 miles west of South Stack when it encountered water ingress issues. The crew contacted coastguards at 07:00 BST, and Holyhead coastguards were unable to manage the water with the boat's pump. The RNLI lifeboat crew provided assistance by supplying an additional pump and towing the vessel to Holyhead.

The passage discusses middle distance runner Laura Muir's decision to prioritize her veterinary medicine studies over competing in the Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast in April. Despite expressing disappointment, Muir plans to focus on her final year of university and aims to participate in the World Indoor Championships in March. She also mentions her recent achievements in the 1500m and 5,000m races at the World Athletics Championships, setting a new outdoor personal best.

The passage discusses Liverpool's struggles this season and how they are far from repeating last season's title challenge. It highlights their lack of goals due to the loss of Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge's injury, as well as their defensive issues. The article also talks about Steven Gerrard's importance to the team and his potential future with Liverpool.

The passage discusses the construction of a Â£45m facility in Kilmarnock, which will include primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare center. East Ayrshire Council plans to name the campus after renowned writer William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock. McIlvanney was passionate about education and became an influential author, earning the title "Godfather of Tartan Noir." He wrote the acclaimed Laidlaw trilogy and other Glasgow-based works, as well as being a poet, journalist, and broadcaster. The novelist passed away on 5 December.

A British sea mine from the 1940s or 1950s was spotted on Monday, leading to an evacuation of three streets near the swimming pool in Gourock. Residents were advised to stay indoors and avoid going outside, while an exclusion zone remained in force on the river. The local area commander emphasized that the evacuation was precautionary, and there was no immediate danger. Ferry services were disrupted due to the operation, and small boat owners were told not to sail. The Royal Navy's Northern Diving Unit is working to safely deal with the deteriorated mine. Inverclyde Council thanked residents and businesses for their patience during the evacuation and cordon procedures.

UK Sport has cut funding for badminton, despite its success in the Rio Olympics, while cycling has had its funding reduced by over Â£4m. A total of Â£345m will be invested in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for the Tokyo games, with Team GB aiming to win 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals. Sports minister Tracey Crouch said UK Sport's approach has been successful in previous years and the goal for Tokyo is ambitious. Basketball, handball and volleyball have lost their funding since 2012 and 2014 respectively.

A six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks will replace three Victorian hotels at East Cliff in Bournemouth. English Heritage objected to the scale of the development in the conservation area, but councillors voted in favor, stating it would help tourism. The site will include a 90-room hotel and 122 assisted-living apartments. Despite objections from residents and the Ancient Monuments Society, the council received 246 letters supporting the plans.

A soldier named Pte Matthew Boyd was attacked by Jake Vallely while he was out at night in Brecon. Pte Boyd was off-duty and had been training nearby. He was found unconscious by the police and later died from his injuries. Vallely admitted to attacking him but his friend, Aaeron Evans, was not involved and was cleared of any charges. The community of Brecon is shocked by this event and the family of Pte Boyd is devastated by their loss.

Andrew Travers has left his position as chief executive of Barnet Council by mutual agreement after an error resulted in voters being turned away from all 155 polling stations due to missing names on the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched, and deputy chief executive John Hooton will temporarily take over while longer term arrangements are made. The council apologized for the problems and offered emergency proxy votes to affected residents. A statement from Mr. Travers blamed electoral registration lists for the issues, and the council's review will conclude by the end of May with findings presented publicly to the General Functions Committee.

In a closely contested match, Gateshead emerged victorious against Wrexham with a 2-1 score. Josh Gillies and Ryan Bowman scored for Gateshead, while Sean Newton's goal was the only one for Wrexham. Both teams had their share of chances, but it was Gateshead's ability to convert their opportunities that made the difference in the second half. The managers acknowledged their opponents' performance and recognized the need for improvement in certain areas.

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014, released on October 1st, 2014, measures the social and economic welfare of individuals over 60 years old in 96 countries. Norway ranks as the top country, while Afghanistan is ranked worst, followed by Mozambique.

The OneWeb project aims to deliver broadband links from orbit to every corner of the globe, with a constellation of at least 600 spacecraft and potentially over 2,000. Airbus is leading the manufacturing effort, which requires new assembly line methods similar to those used in car and plane production. The first 10 satellites are set to launch in April 2020, with nearly 300 in orbit by the end of 2020 and more than 600 by 2021. OneWeb has raised $1.7bn in equity and is in talks for necessary loans. The UK Space Agency will license the company as it is registered in the UK's Channel Islands. The project also aims to set new standards in debris mitigation, committing to de-orbit old spacecraft within two years.

The UK government's recent spending review has put "unprecedented pressure" on public expenditure in Scotland, according to Mr Swinney. Despite this, Scottish ministers will have Â£390m more in spending available to them next year. However, the Scottish government argues that cuts imposed by the UK government since 2010 mean that its discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 than it was in 2010-11. Mr Swinney said schools, hospitals and the police service in Scotland would not be sacrificed to the chancellor's austerity obsession.

The passage discusses the challenges faced by people with severe disabilities and their families when trying to find suitable toilet facilities in public places. It highlights the need for Changing Places toilets, which have extra features and more space than standard disabled toilets, to help meet the needs of those who require assistance from carers or special equipment like hoists. Currently, there are 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK, but campaigners are calling for them to be made compulsory in larger buildings such as shopping centres, cinemas, and sports stadiums. The lack of these facilities can cause stress and isolation for families, and some have resorted to using "pop-up" changing places at events or parties. While architects and businesses acknowledge the importance of accessible facilities, logistical and financial barriers can make it difficult to install Changing Places toilets in existing buildings.

A group of Italian consumers' organizations have filed a formal complaint with the European Commission against McDonald's, accusing the fast food giant of forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees. McDonald's defended its practices, stating that it shares risks and rewards with its licensees. The Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and European unions are supporting the antitrust complaint. The consumer organizations claim that franchisees are prevented from switching to competitors due to longer-than-average contracts and leasing premises from the company at above market rates, resulting in poorer consumer choice and higher prices in franchise stores compared to those owned directly by McDonald's.

The #prayforjosh hashtag, started by Bangor Elim Church where Josh's father is on the pastoral staff, has gone viral on social media in support of 13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. A mystery donor paid for a billboard featuring the hashtag to be erected at Holywood playing fields. Josh's classmates have also used the hashtag on Twitter to show their support.

The UK government plans to close Brecon Barracks, a historic military site in Wales since 1805, as part of a restructuring plan. Conservative MP Chris Davies condemns the decision and launches a petition against it, arguing that it shows a lack of respect for the barracks' history and may negatively impact the town's military tourism industry. However, Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon states that the reorganization will create a specialist light infantry center at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan.

The House of Lords has warned that the UK fishing industry may be marginalised during Brexit negotiations, despite being a key concern for many in the industry. The Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) has been blamed for negatively impacting British fishing, leading to calls for regaining control over UK waters post-Brexit. However, the House of Lords European Union Committee report highlights the risks and opportunities for the industry, emphasising the need for continued market access and cooperation with neighbouring states. The report also suggests retaining elements of the CFP and basing total allowable catches and quotas on scientific advice.

The passage discusses Edward Snowden, a former technical worker for the CIA, who leaked information about the US National Security Agency's (NSA) surveillance program called Prism. The program allegedly gave the US government access to individual chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data of individuals through backdoor access to the servers of major technology companies. The US government confirmed requesting millions of phone records from Verizon, which included call duration, location, and phone numbers of both parties on individual calls. The passage also highlights concerns about data protection laws and privacy issues related to government monitoring activities in the interest of national security.

The passage discusses the launch of Open AI, a venture backed by influential figures such as Elon Musk and Peter Thiel. Its aim is to focus on research that has a positive human impact, without financial obligations. Some scientists warn that advances in AI could pose a threat to humanity, while others argue the risk remains remote. Open AI's statement emphasizes the potential benefits and risks of human-level AI and its commitment to distributing AI "as broadly and evenly as possible." Only a small portion of the $1bn pledged will be spent in the next few years.

L/Bdr Parkinson, a Doncaster-based soldier who was seriously injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006, carried the Olympic torch on June 26. Since then, he has received thousands of friend requests on Facebook, but due to the site's limit of 5,000 friends per personal page, he cannot accept all of them. He spends his time in the gym and rehab, walking with crutches and raising money for military charities as the patron of Pilgrim Bandits. His mother Diane said the family has been overwhelmed by the support and friendship shown to Ben.

The poverty rate in the US was 15% in 2011, with 46.2 million Americans living in poverty. Median household income dropped by 1.5%, and the average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality increased by 1.6%, while the percentage of uninsured Americans decreased to 15.7%. Poverty reached a record high in 2010 at 15.1%.

A 25-year-old cricketer moved to the Red Rose team from Somerset in 2013 and signed a deal until 2019. He is known for his fast-paced scoring in ODIs, with three of England's fastest centuries. The cricket director and head coach praised his talent, presence in the T20 Blast final, and international experience. Buttler has been playing in the Indian Premier League and will return to Lancashire for an upcoming T20 Blast game.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates, HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall, are in Portsmouth Harbour awaiting bids for their sale. Bidders had until January 23 to register interest, and viewings will take place in late February and March. The government's Disposal Services Authority aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess the country's industry capacity. Penny Mordaunt, MP for Portsmouth North, hopes at least one ship can be saved from scrapyard and turned into a reef or diving attraction for tourism purposes. The Ministry of Defence is considering all options to ensure the best financial return for taxpayers.

The passage discusses the political and racial tensions in Fiji since 1987, which have led to instability and international isolation. Key events include a coup in 1987 overthrowing an Indian-dominated coalition, a further coup in 2000 led by George Speight, and a bloodless military takeover in 2006. Fiji was suspended from the Commonwealth in 2009 due to its lack of progress towards democracy but reinstated as a member after free elections in 2014. The population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with minimal mixing between the two groups. Fiji's economy relies on industries such as sugar, tourism, mining, services, and light manufacturing but faces persistent trade and budget deficits.

Syria is working to destroy its chemical weapons but has missed a deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. A shipment of weapons was attacked twice on its way to the port of Latakia, and the country's Deputy Foreign Minister claims that terrorist groups are supported by the US. The Syrian government denies reports that rebels have seized most of Aleppo's central prison, while fighting continues in the area. The UN-backed plan for destroying Syria's chemical weapons is falling behind schedule, with only 4% of the stockpile having left the country so far.

The Booker Prize shortlist includes six authors, with Mukherjee's The Lives Of Others being the favorite to win. This is the first year that the prize is open to all authors writing in English, regardless of nationality. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall on Tuesday night. The shortlisted authors are Howard Jacobson, Ali Smith, Joshua Ferris, Karen Joy Fowler, Richard Flanagan, and Mukherjee. We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves by Karen Joy Fowler is the best-selling book on the list. The announcement of the final six caused a sales spike for all the books on the shortlist.

A man is appealing to the Supreme Court against a ruling that lifted a ban on him being named in the media in England and Wales. The court will decide if the appeal should be allowed or dismissed, with an interim injunction remaining in place until the end of the hearing. The man, referred to as PJS, argues he has a right to privacy and took legal action after The Sun on Sunday wanted to publish an account of his alleged extra-marital activities. The story had spread across the internet and on Twitter, making it difficult for PJS to obtain a permanent injunction.

Fosse Park, purchased for Â£345.5m in August, plans to improve parking, traffic congestion, and unit appearance. Blaby District Council leader Ernie White said the new owners see it as an investment they can enhance.
